story:
The Philippines were recently struck by the most violent and malevolent storm recorded in human history. The town of Hingatungan is a mere 43 miles away from Tacloban where the death toll has exceeded 10,000. The Hingatungan shores have been riddled by a consistent tide of bodies. Amidst the chaos and desperation, survivors have had no choice but to dispose of the bodies immediately to eliminate risk of disease. There is a shortage of gasoline and electricity contributing to an already dire situation for the newly homeless and abandoned citizens.

My family has roots and relatives deep within the foundations of the Hingatungan community. Between my immediate family and friends in California, we have accumulated a small fund of $1200 to send for Hingatungan relief.  We now ask for any gracious individuals who would like to contribute to a venerable cause. 100% percent of your donation will go towards providing food rations to survivors and repairing damaged property. The relief fund will be in the hands of the citizens, including members of my family, and the church community of Hingatungan.

Any and all contributions will be greatly appreciated! Your help can make a huge impact for the people of Hingatangan. I will provide weekly updates detailing the utilization of our relief fund and the tangible effects of our generosity on the local community.

story:
Hanfmatratzen - Strohmatratzen - Seegrasmatratzen - Heumatratzen
und ander Ausführungen, nie exotisches und immer kompostierbar.

Vorwort:

Ich habe festgestellt, dass einige sich wundern, dass ich 1.000 Euro suche, aber schon 25.000 Euro bekomme.
Das hat zwei Gründe. Ich bekomme das große Geld erst wenn die Maschine als Gegenwert hier ist. Also habe ich nichts vor dem Produktionsbeginn zur Verfügung.
Ferner habe ich den Zuschuss begrenzt, um nicht in eine höhere Antragsstufe zu rutschen. Das wäre mehr Arbeit und der Antrag hätte noch länger gedauert.

Das werde ich tun:

Ich werde echte Naturmatratzen bauen, die aus Getreidestroh, Hanfstroh, Flachsstroh, Heu, Seegras und anderen natürlichen Materialien hergestellt werden. Alle Rohstoffe wachsen vor Ort (Hanf und einige Kräuter direkt hier, dort wo er gebraucht wird) oder werden aus europäischen Nachbarländern bezogen (Filz, Faden, Stoff, Demeter Stroh, Seegras). Allen ist gemein, dass der Rohstoff nicht mit Kunststoff vermischt ist oder viel Energie in die "Veredelung" gesteckt wird.
Die Matratzen haben keine Kunststoffanteile und werden von mir nach Gebrauch zum Kompostieren zurück genommen.

Ich mache folgendes anders:

Normal werden Matratzen aus Kunststoffen oder Kunststoffanteilen hergestellt. Auch sogenannte Naturmatratzen haben Kunststoffgarne und der verwendete Latex hat Chemieanteile (Grenzwerte). Diese Matratzen können nicht kompostiert oder wieder verwendet werden, obwohl das geschrieben wird.
Ich will mit dieser Matratze eine Idee umsetzen, an der ich seit rund 2 Jahre arbeite. Es soll für mich ein Einnahmequelle werden, aber auch zeigen wie Matratzen hergestellt und komplett wieder in die Umwelt eingegliedert werden.

Die Matratzen haben folgenden Vorteil:

Meine Matratzen gewährleisten dem Schläfer keine Ausgasungen aus Kunststoff oder Chemikalien. Der Nutzer kann sogar Teile der Matratze aus Kräutern herstellen lassen, die auf den Körper bestimmte Wirkung haben.

Zum Beispiel Goldrute (Bild oben): Das Gelb des Herbstes, wirkt beim Problemen der Niere, Harnwege und Blase. Aber auch die normal verwendeten Rohstoffe habe sehr positive Eigenschaften.

Zum Beispiel Roggenstroh u.a.: Die Kieselerde oder Kieselsäure, in der Homöopathie "Silicea terra" genannt, ist maßgeblich für die Stabilität der Strohhalme zuständig. Roggenstroh ist durch Kieselsäure sehr stabil und spreizfähig, mehr wie andere Strohsorten. In der menschlichen Gesundheit ist Kieselsäure ebenfalls sehr wichtig.  Auch hier wirkt es besonders auf das Binde- und Stützgewebe.

Die Matratzen bestehen aus 2 Schichten, a etwa 7 cm. Diese werden lose ins Bett gelegt und durch den Bettrahmen fixiert. Jede Schicht kann gegen eine neue getauscht werden. Es muss also nicht die ganze Matratze erneuert werden, sonder es kann nur eine der Schichten erneuert werden.

Ich nehme die Matratze zurück. Sie wird nicht über den Sondermüll und dann über eine Verbrennung entsorgt, sonder bei mir kontrolliert kompostiert. Der fertige Kompost wird auf die Felder gestreut.

Ich werde vormachen, dass man Matratzen sehr natürlich herstellen kann.

Es gibt zu viel Produkte, die nach Gebrauch wertlos sind. Das geht sogar soweit, dass der Akku defekt ist, der nicht getauscht oder die defekte LED nicht durch eine neu ersetzt werden kann. So wandern viele gute Produkte auf dem Müll. Es wird zwar in Deutschland und sicher auch bald in Europa ein Wertstofftonne geben, doch die gesammelten Geräte und andere Produkte lassen sich nur zum kleinen Teil wieder verwenden. Ich habe mich besonders über einen Anbieter der konventionelles Stroh in der Matratze hat. Er schreibt, es werden keine Pestizide eingesetzt. Natürlich wird Roggenstroh kurz gespritzt und das geht nicht ohne Chemie. Wenn er den Lieferanten nicht kennt ist nicht bekannt was sonst noch eingesetzt wird. Aber was versteht der Kunde schon davon. Dei Tricks der Verkäufer und Produktentwickler werden immer dreister. Der Verbrauch von Ressourcen oder der ökologische Fußabdruck wird immer größer.
Dabei muss es bei einer vernünftigen Produktentwicklung nicht so sein. Ich will vormachen, dass es bei einem Produkt wie die Matratze geht, einen geschlossenes Kreislauf zu haben.
Der moderne Name dafür ist: Ökoeffektivität oder auch "cradle to cradle".

 

Das Geld von hier, hilft mir einige Arbeiten zu finanzieren, die ich bis zum Start machen muß!

Ich werde im November oder Dezember eine Maschine bekommen, deren Finanzierung steht (etwa 25.000 Euro). Diese Maschine kommt aus dem Raum Bremen, sorgt hier also für Arbeit. Sie steppt eine 6 cm dicke Schicht aus den Materialien in einer Stoffhülle (das geht nicht oder nicht in der Qualität mit Handarbeit, das habe ich versucht). Ich werde 4 Wochen bevor die Maschine da ist, die Matratzen bewerben und erste Verkäufe haben. Dadurch plane ich die restliche Finanzierung (Leinen, Garn, Faden zum Steppen u.a). Was mir aber fehlt, ist vorher etwas Kapital (1000 Euro). Ich muss Material einkaufen, wozu es im November oder Dezember zu spät ist. Der landwirtschaftliche Boden hier muss für Hanf- und Roggenanbau (Sommerroggen-Test und Hanf)  im nächsten Frühjahr vorbereitet werden. Ich werde testweise Hanf bereits im Herbst säen. Ich muß 2 Tonnen Stroh aus Deutschland holen und anderes. Ich will zwei Vorrichtungen bauen. So gibt es einige Sachen die vorher dringend erledigt werden müssen, um einen sauberen Start zu haben, für die mir aber das Kapital fehlt.

 

Und was gibt es sonst?

Ich informiere unter www.facebook.com/naturmatratze über den Fortgang des Projektes und zu andern Themen.

Betreut werde ich bei dem Projekt von einer staatlichen Organisation, die besonders neue Ideen fördert. Sie nennt sich (übersetzt) Kurlands Business Inkubator (gibt es mit anderen Namen in allen Gebieten Lettland) www.kbi.lv (LV/RU/EN).

Für den KBI und die Finanzierung der Maschine, die von der EU und Lettland kommt (läuft über eine staatliche Bank), habe ich einen cash-flow in Lettisch, Finanzplan in Deutsch und Lettisch, sowie Businessplan und Marketingplan in Englisch erstellt.

story:
"Find someone who's doing something good and right, and help them do it faster, better, and more efficiently."

 Become a "Friend of Frankincense" 

We're creating a small eco-preserve to grow endangered Frankincense (and other Torchwood) trees. It's Frankincense and Myrrh, the trees that produce fragrant, oily resins, and key medicinals spoken of in the Bible... along with another of the precious holy oils like Balm of Gilead (commiphora gileadensis known as "Gold" in antiquities,) and also Agarwood trees (aquilaria) the source of Oudh, one of the most heavenly perfume scents on earth.  

All are endangered, some critically so, or increasingly found only in specimen gardens. Pure biblical Frankincense, Boswellia Sacra, the source of royal hougari comes from Oman. Those groves are environmentally threatened by climate change and human conflict. The hundred year old trees are stressed, over - tapped, abused, poisoned, poached, and trafficked... And what we do to the Frankincense, we do to children. 

But in this garden and SAFE haven, we will PROTECT and NURTURE both. We'll propagate, and proliferate the Frankincense and other Torchwoods to share with all. Once secured and abundantly propagated, we will use the mature trees to help secure an inheritance and brighter future for children ...especially endangered, trafficked, and orphaned children. 

One of the best places we can help each other reconnect, and open our hearts to childlike awe and wonder again, and renewed sense of innocence is in the midst of nature.  

What do we need?  To put down roots - literally. 

  • Frankincense seedlings, from a rare collection, are ready and waiting to be sent. Yet, we need all the accoutrements necessary for gardening and experimental agronomy in order to properly and safely receive them.   
  • We need a larger space; land, a greenhouse, water, a classroom, the trees themselves, container pots in various sizes and kinds (clay, plastic, smart pots, etc) for cultivation and for growth. We need to move some dirt around, so we need all gardening tools, other implements, and equipment, hardscape/ softscape elements, grow-lights, bees, butterflies, worms, seeds, companioning trees, and other biblical plants and herbs, electronic equipment, and education materials.
  • If you would like a complete garden list, I've made one. If you want to see a business plan, I've written one, with a projected three-year budget. 
  • If you'd like to donate land itself, we’d be grateful for 1-5 acres which numerically, means: "a certain small something, not much but enough to build on" or upwards to 50.  

Why Frankincense?

  • We're focused on Frankincense, pure biblical Frankincense - Boswellia Sacra (not b. Carteri from Somalia, or b. Serrata from India) - because of its history, and universal importance.  Frankincense is universally recognized around the globe as beneficial and valuable by all cultures and traditions for its spiritual, natural, and medicinal qualities, as an expression of good will, and source of wellbeing, peace, and enlightenment.
  • Frankincense being so universally loved and in demand gave rise and cause of the world's first global economy, and was the reason for our first peaceful trade routes and treaties. For those reasons, Frankincense sets an important, even priceless precedence. 
  • Frankincense is a banner tree for all humanity: A tree of abundance, good health, peace, and unity - symbolizing the best of human endeavors.
  • Frankincense has historically been the gift of royalty-acceptable in every realm, and it is still a fitting gift to royal houses, or heads of state, popes, ambassadors, and other world dignitaries.  
  • The wise men carried Frankincense to the baby Jesus in his Nativity, because they believed him to be the King of kings. Yet, it transcends borders, barriers, and ranks of all kinds. We must not let this bridge-builder go on being endangered. 
  • If the above isn’t cause enough, Scientific research is now re-discovering how Frankincense works at the DNA level to accomplish its good work.  Researchers believe it may be an effective treatment for some cancers. 
  • Frankincense is part of the new post 2012 paradigm - One word for a newly awakened and aware human race and its Economy of Grace: Frankincense.  It is a priceless gift placed here for all God's children.
  • "The leaves of the trees are for the healing of the nations."

What will it look like?      

  • We'll begin with the preservation of Frankincense as our most immediate focal point and purpose. We'll add the other torchwood trees, and beyond the greenhouse nursery, we'll cultivate the outdoor biblical garden, and a small companion grove of fruiting and nutting trees, fragrant and flowering bushes, and other precious biblical herbs and rare medicinal plants.  Ultimately, with our 30,000 organic, non-hybrid heirloom seeds we purchased, we'll put in a permaculture food-forest to mature and bring forth their produce.
  • We need to locate near a natural water source (a spring, river, or irrigateable land) and for sustainability, build a water reclamation tower with friends who know how from recycled (local-sourcing) materials. We'll create a water feature with flowing water: a fountain or pool.
  •  

Find someone who's doing something right, and help them do it faster, better, and more efficiently."

YOU:  I can't do it alone - How can you help?

As Helen Keller once said, “ I am only one person, and alone I can do nothing, but together, we can do something, so I will not refuse to do the one thing that I can do.”

  • Saving these precious trees on the planet would be enough, but the garden preserve will act as a retreat, and outdoor classroom, to interact with students and adults. It will be a living library and visible index of love and wisdom descending out of heaven and taking shape in the world around us.  
  • We will create curriculum and an educational program to raise awareness, using an open-sourced educational platform. We’ll start immediately raising awareness, designing, planting, educating, and continue networking and collaborating. 
  • This is a sustainable plan to make the dream of helping orphaned children a tangible and lasting reality. Once secured, and abundantly propagated, the sales from the mature trees, valuable seedlings, saplings, oil, and derived botanical products will help secure a better future and inheritance for all children.
  • We'll begin immediately working with cultural exchange and youth organizations, and ecology, environmental, and preservation groups to increase the worldwide presence, and availability of Frankincense trees. We'll create educational curriculum about all the Torchwood trees, their history, and use. 
  • With this fundraiser, if you elect to donat just a small portion of the $144,000 goal, we will be on our way, and I will make it my work to multiply your giving. I invite anyone, and everyone, to be a part of helping restore a little innocence to the earth by making a place of belonging and safety for two very precious "least of these" which we've left endangered, and all but abandoned.  Please don’t let "no room at the Inn" be our problem!  

WHO: Who is organizing this? 

  • We are a small but growing global network of indiviuals ("HomeTribe") concerned about the plight of children and the condition of the planet. "HomeTribe" pledging to help this cause evolve from its first inkling: “To protect innocence and help provide for a more sustainable future and a thriving humanity.”  They're individuals who have been steadily offering support; their skills, interest, and hard work as needed.
  • I myself (Carla), am a Christian minister ordained in an ecumenical tradition (M Div) and an educator (BS in Early Childhood Education) awaiting my teacher certification status, by the Arizona Board of Education (my "Bread & Butter")  
  • I’m a theologian with a ministry in eco-justice, focusing in sustainability: *Sustainable Earth (care of creation) *Sustainable Structures (Architecture, and Educational platforms) & *Sustainable Lives (children and community.) My project draws these three areas together. 
  • I've been searching for a catalyst to springboard support to the care for orphaned and endangered children. I belive this is it. 

 

HOW: Proven Track record 

  •  Welsh Frankincense Tree Project (http://www.frankincensetree.com/#!project) has shown the trees can be carefully cultivated and propagated.  This took 6-8 years of careful cultivation.  They should now however be moved out of isolation and private collections and given worldwide distribution, if their full protection and benefit for mankind is to be realized.
  • We've done a similar large-scale garden project in San Diego, where we restored an historic garden, involved lots of people and groups, master gardeners, various community groups, neighbors, and local businesses. Once to a certain stage, we opened its beauty and peace up to wider enjoyment which is still going on today. It was a success and good training ground, for this project of worldwide importance.  
  • Here in Arizona, we are uniquely situated in the perfect climate to ensure future success and survival of the trees. The tree is non-invasive and in fact, it’s nearly impossible to grow them from seed. Few can, even fewer have done so, and yet it has been accomplished for this project.  
  • Many individuals and groups will be involved in this project: Nature and Youth organizations, scouting, adventure, conservation, environmental, and ecological groups. We will also lobby the World Parliament of Religions, to adopt Frankincense as a Tree of great importance and common global interest. 
  • We’re following in the footsteps of others in the Swedenborgian ecological tradition: Naturalists John (Appleseed) Chapman, John Muir (Sierra Club) George Innes (Landscape painter) and Eliza Lovell Tibbets (experimental agronomist, abolitionist, grower of the seedless navel orange and Mother of the Citrus industry) who were also considered spiritual entrepreneurs.
  • This protective Oasis, is to become a place of peace, meditation, beauty, and good uses.  No matter what though, even if we don't reach our goal, the nursery can go forward with whatever funds and means are received, just at a slower pace.  If we exceed our donation goals, we'll accelerate our plans and help to the children.  

IF you've learned all you need to GO FUND, then GREAT! Be an angel and check out the 12 PERKS to see which level suits you!  

 

If you want to learn more, please feel free to read on...

What's happened so far? 

  • We have starter trees, of rare and incomparable value; they exist nowhere else on the planet in this plentiful way. They will be a gift from The Welsh Frankincense Tree Project (WFTP.) They are ready and waiting to be shipped.  http://www.frankincensetree.com/#!project.
  • Stateside, we have appropriate mentoring from my close minister-colleague, the grower and horticulturist at the WFTP.  I've been under tutelage for almost two years, but now need to be in receipt of the seedlings. We have a reliable, reputable resource for how to grow and care for the Frankincense.
  • HomeTribe also has 30,000 organic, non-hybrid, non-GMO seeds for fruits and herbs. We're already creating energy for the project and community involvement until we have our own land. We've begun one beautiful community garden, and will help facilitate more.

 

THE CHILDREN:  Not sure what is the connection is between the trees and children? 

  • There is an attack on innocence. 
  • The Frankincense trees are endangered through climate change and environmental destruction, and human conflict. The groves are further abused, by being over-tapped abused, plundered, poached, and their resin and oil trafficked.  
  • Like a canary in the mines, the trees are a litmus test on how we're doing as a humanity. What we do to the earth, we do to children. 
  • We are experiencing worldwide devastation of the earth, its flora and fauna (by the most conservative estimates, 27,000 species go extinct every year), and its natural resources. The United Nations’ biodiversity chief in 2010 warned that nations risk economic collapse and loss of culture if we do not protect the natural world and its biodiversity. Humankind is faring no better.
  • The abolitionist movement estimates 27 million individuals trafficked worldwide—mostly women and children, enslaved in forced labor or outright captivity.
  • And if that wasn’t enough, there are between 143 and 210 million orphans worldwide with 2.1 million in the United States, and 10 million in Mexico (UNICEF, 2009). There is an ongoing and sustained attack on innocence that must be countered.
  • Perhaps you have a desire similar to ours, to help restore endangered, at-risk children to a level of renewed hope, health, safety, and happiness, playful joy, belonging, and a regained sense of innocence.  

One of the best places we can help each other reconnect, and open our hearts to that childlike awe and wonder, and renewed sense of innocence is in the midst of nature. 

 

AND: Other Ways You Can Help - Please Share & Get the word out. 

  • Even if you can't contribute a whole heap of dollar$ or even a few, we still need you. We need your awareness, your well wishes, your prayers and help talking it up. We ask that you share this extremely important project with nature enthusiasts, gardening friends, spiritual folks who love peace, AND good health, lovers and caretakers of the earth, and anyone who cares about a future for children. 

Ask them to get the word out and make some joyful noise about this campaign.

Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

All are endangered, some critically so, or increasingly found only in specimen gardens. Pure biblical Frankincense, Boswellia Sacra, the source of royal hougari comes from Oman. Those groves are environmentally threatened by climate change and human conflict. The hundred year old trees are stressed, over - tapped, abused, poisoned, poached, and trafficked... And what we do to the Frankincense, we do to children. 
But in this garden and SAFE haven, we will PROTECT and NURTURE both. We'll propagate, and proliferate the Frankincense and other Torchwoods to share with all. Once secured and abundantly propagated, we will use the mature trees to help secure an inheritance and brighter future for children ...especially endangered, trafficked, and orphaned children. 
One of the best places we can help each other reconnect, and open our hearts to childlike awe and wonder again, and renewed sense of innocence is in the midst of nature.  
What do we need?  To put down roots - literally. 

Frankincense seedlings, from a rare collection, are ready and waiting to be sent. Yet, we need all the accoutrements necessary for gardening and experimental agronomy in order to properly and safely receive them.   
We need a larger space; land, a greenhouse, water, a classroom, the trees themselves, container pots in various sizes and kinds (clay, plastic, smart pots, etc) for cultivation and for growth. We need to move some dirt around, so we need all gardening tools, other implements, and equipment, hardscape/ softscape elements, grow-lights, bees, butterflies, worms, seeds, companioning trees, and other biblical plants and herbs, electronic equipment, and education materials.
If you would like a complete garden list, I've made one. If you want to see a business plan, I've written one, with a projected three-year budget. 
If you'd like to donate land itself, we’d be grateful for 1-5 acres which numerically, means: "a certain small something, not much but enough to build on" or upwards to 50.  
Why Frankincense?

We're focused on Frankincense, pure biblical Frankincense - Boswellia Sacra (not b. Carteri from Somalia, or b. Serrata from India) - because of its history, and universal importance.  Frankincense is universally recognized around the globe as beneficial and valuable by all cultures and traditions for its spiritual, natural, and medicinal qualities, as an expression of good will, and source of wellbeing, peace, and enlightenment.
Frankincense being so universally loved and in demand gave rise and cause of the world's first global economy, and was the reason for our first peaceful trade routes and treaties. For those reasons, Frankincense sets an important, even priceless precedence. 
Frankincense is a banner tree for all humanity: A tree of abundance, good health, peace, and unity - symbolizing the best of human endeavors.
Frankincense has historically been the gift of royalty-acceptable in every realm, and it is still a fitting gift to royal houses, or heads of state, popes, ambassadors, and other world dignitaries.  
The wise men carried Frankincense to the baby Jesus in his Nativity, because they believed him to be the King of kings. Yet, it transcends borders, barriers, and ranks of all kinds. We must not let this bridge-builder go on being endangered. 
If the above isn’t cause enough, Scientific research is now re-discovering how Frankincense works at the DNA level to accomplish its good work.  Researchers believe it may be an effective treatment for some cancers. 
Frankincense is part of the new post 2012 paradigm - One word for a newly awakened and aware human race and its Economy of Grace: Frankincense.  It is a priceless gift placed here for all God's children.
"The leaves of the trees are for the healing of the nations."
What will it look like?      

We'll begin with the preservation of Frankincense as our most immediate focal point and purpose. We'll add the other torchwood trees, and beyond the greenhouse nursery, we'll cultivate the outdoor biblical garden, and a small companion grove of fruiting and nutting trees, fragrant and flowering bushes, and other precious biblical herbs and rare medicinal plants.  Ultimately, with our 30,000 organic, non-hybrid heirloom seeds we purchased, we'll put in a permaculture food-forest to mature and bring forth their produce.
We need to locate near a natural water source (a spring, river, or irrigateable land) and for sustainability, build a water reclamation tower with friends who know how from recycled (local-sourcing) materials. We'll create a water feature with flowing water: a fountain or pool.
 
Find someone who's doing something right, and help them do it faster, better, and more efficiently."
YOU:  I can't do it alone - How can you help?
As Helen Keller once said, “ I am only one person, and alone I can do nothing, but together, we can do something, so I will not refuse to do the one thing that I can do.”

Saving these precious trees on the planet would be enough, but the garden preserve will act as a retreat, and outdoor classroom, to interact with students and adults. It will be a living library and visible index of love and wisdom descending out of heaven and taking shape in the world around us.  
We will create curriculum and an educational program to raise awareness, using an open-sourced educational platform. We’ll start immediately raising awareness, designing, planting, educating, and continue networking and collaborating. 
This is a sustainable plan to make the dream of helping orphaned children a tangible and lasting reality. Once secured, and abundantly propagated, the sales from the mature trees, valuable seedlings, saplings, oil, and derived botanical products will help secure a better future and inheritance for all children.
We'll begin immediately working with cultural exchange and youth organizations, and ecology, environmental, and preservation groups to increase the worldwide presence, and availability of Frankincense trees. We'll create educational curriculum about all the Torchwood trees, their history, and use. 
With this fundraiser, if you elect to donat just a small portion of the $144,000 goal, we will be on our way, and I will make it my work to multiply your giving. I invite anyone, and everyone, to be a part of helping restore a little innocence to the earth by making a place of belonging and safety for two very precious "least of these" which we've left endangered, and all but abandoned.  Please don’t let "no room at the Inn" be our problem!  
WHO: Who is organizing this? 

We are a small but growing global network of indiviuals ("HomeTribe") concerned about the plight of children and the condition of the planet. "HomeTribe" pledging to help this cause evolve from its first inkling: “To protect innocence and help provide for a more sustainable future and a thriving humanity.”  They're individuals who have been steadily offering support; their skills, interest, and hard work as needed.
I myself (Carla), am a Christian minister ordained in an ecumenical tradition (M Div) and an educator (BS in Early Childhood Education) awaiting my teacher certification status, by the Arizona Board of Education (my "Bread & Butter")  
I’m a theologian with a ministry in eco-justice, focusing in sustainability: *Sustainable Earth (care of creation) *Sustainable Structures (Architecture, and Educational platforms) & *Sustainable Lives (children and community.) My project draws these three areas together. 
I've been searching for a catalyst to springboard support to the care for orphaned and endangered children. I belive this is it. 
 
HOW: Proven Track record 

 Welsh Frankincense Tree Project (http://www.frankincensetree.com/#!project) has shown the trees can be carefully cultivated and propagated.  This took 6-8 years of careful cultivation.  They should now however be moved out of isolation and private collections and given worldwide distribution, if their full protection and benefit for mankind is to be realized.
We've done a similar large-scale garden project in San Diego, where we restored an historic garden, involved lots of people and groups, master gardeners, various community groups, neighbors, and local businesses. Once to a certain stage, we opened its beauty and peace up to wider enjoyment which is still going on today. It was a success and good training ground, for this project of worldwide importance.  
Here in Arizona, we are uniquely situated in the perfect climate to ensure future success and survival of the trees. The tree is non-invasive and in fact, it’s nearly impossible to grow them from seed. Few can, even fewer have done so, and yet it has been accomplished for this project.  
Many individuals and groups will be involved in this project: Nature and Youth organizations, scouting, adventure, conservation, environmental, and ecological groups. We will also lobby the World Parliament of Religions, to adopt Frankincense as a Tree of great importance and common global interest. 
We’re following in the footsteps of others in the Swedenborgian ecological tradition: Naturalists John (Appleseed) Chapman, John Muir (Sierra Club) George Innes (Landscape painter) and Eliza Lovell Tibbets (experimental agronomist, abolitionist, grower of the seedless navel orange and Mother of the Citrus industry) who were also considered spiritual entrepreneurs.
This protective Oasis, is to become a place of peace, meditation, beauty, and good uses.  No matter what though, even if we don't reach our goal, the nursery can go forward with whatever funds and means are received, just at a slower pace.  If we exceed our donation goals, we'll accelerate our plans and help to the children.  
IF you've learned all you need to GO FUND, then GREAT! Be an angel and check out the 12 PERKS to see which level suits you!  
 
If you want to learn more, please feel free to read on... 
What's happened so far? 

We have starter trees, of rare and incomparable value; they exist nowhere else on the planet in this plentiful way. They will be a gift from The Welsh Frankincense Tree Project (WFTP.) They are ready and waiting to be shipped.  http://www.frankincensetree.com/#!project.
Stateside, we have appropriate mentoring from my close minister-colleague, the grower and horticulturist at the WFTP.  I've been under tutelage for almost two years, but now need to be in receipt of the seedlings. We have a reliable, reputable resource for how to grow and care for the Frankincense.
HomeTribe also has 30,000 organic, non-hybrid, non-GMO seeds for fruits and herbs. We're already creating energy for the project and community involvement until we have our own land. We've begun one beautiful community garden, and will help facilitate more.
 
THE CHILDREN:  Not sure what is the connection is between the trees and children? 

There is an attack on innocence. 
The Frankincense trees are endangered through climate change and environmental destruction, and human conflict. The groves are further abused, by being over-tapped abused, plundered, poached, and their resin and oil trafficked.  
Like a canary in the mines, the trees are a litmus test on how we're doing as a humanity. What we do to the earth, we do to children. 
We are experiencing worldwide devastation of the earth, its flora and fauna (by the most conservative estimates, 27,000 species go extinct every year), and its natural resources. The United Nations’ biodiversity chief in 2010 warned that nations risk economic collapse and loss of culture if we do not protect the natural world and its biodiversity. Humankind is faring no better.
The abolitionist movement estimates 27 million individuals trafficked worldwide—mostly women and children, enslaved in forced labor or outright captivity.
And if that wasn’t enough, there are between 143 and 210 million orphans worldwide with 2.1 million in the United States, and 10 million in Mexico (UNICEF, 2009). There is an ongoing and sustained attack on innocence that must be countered.
Perhaps you have a desire similar to ours, to help restore endangered, at-risk children to a level of renewed hope, health, safety, and happiness, playful joy, belonging, and a regained sense of innocence.  
One of the best places we can help each other reconnect, and open our hearts to that childlike awe and wonder, and renewed sense of innocence is in the midst of nature. 
 
AND: Other Ways You Can Help - Please Share & Get the word out. 

Even if you can't contribute a whole heap of dollar$ or even a few, we still need you. We need your awareness, your well wishes, your prayers and help talking it up. We ask that you share this extremely important project with nature enthusiasts, gardening friends, spiritual folks who love peace, AND good health, lovers and caretakers of the earth, and anyone who cares about a future for children. 
Ask them to get the word out and make some joyful noise about this campaign.
Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
PeopleTowels is going back to school with a new eco-habit campaign that will save 130 million trees and help stop filling landfills with used paper towels.

We are raising money to give thousands of free PeopleTowels -- along with environmental and cultural themed lesson plans -- to kids in schools and clubs around the country.  With Kids 4 the Planet, PeopleTowels is introducing kids to the decades-old Japanese custom of using personal hand towels rather than paper towels.  The campaign is asking kids to enter a design competition for a new line of PeopleTowels that will be given away to kids in schools, clubs or organizations nominated in the campaign. 

Just like the canvas shopping bags and metal water bottles everyone now carries, PeopleTowels are designed for portability. The custom-made fabric is absorbent, yet it dries quickly for on-the-go use. The winning art is expected to be a fun, whimsical design that will be printed with eco-friendly dyes, to encourage the B.Y.O.Towel™ habit.  Convenient hangtags even allow kids to clip or loop PeopleTowels to a backpack or tuck into lunch bags or bento boxes.

The Kids 4 the Planet program has two parts:

1. We want kids to design our PeopleTowels!

In the fall of 2012, we will launch a Kids 4 the Planet National Art Project for kids ages 8-18.  We want children to submit their vision of what trees mean to them, their neighborhood, their future, and the planet.  Several of the children’s designs will be chosen to print on PeopleTowels as part of our free school distribution.

2. We're giving away thousands of Free PeopleTowels!

From January 2013 to Earth Day in April 2013, PeopleTowels will distribute free PeopleTowels to children around the country.  Each distribution will include teacher lesson plans about trees and their importance to the environment, as well as a closer look at another country’s culture and customs.

We are a small start-up trying to change the world, one child, one paper towel at a time. 

The more you pledge, the more kids we reach!

 We’re raising $100,000 for this initial national roll-out

That way, over 15,000 children will receive Free PeopleTowels plus a lesson plan on the environment and a look at different cultures’ green habits.

Here's how we're spending the funding:  

1. Manufacture and print special edition Kids 4 the Planet PeopleTowels

2.  To advertise, promote and administer the Kids 4 the Planet art program to schools nationwide and get as many kids involved as possible in sending their designs

3.  Create and distribute instructor lesson plans for different age groups

4.  Ship PeopleTowels to selected schools, clubs and children’s organizations.

5.  Donate a portion of the rewards to plant trees through the nonprofit Trees for the Future

PLEASE Help Us Promote our Project and Spread the Word!

  • Email your friends, family, colleagues, and neighbors and include the link to our Indiegogo page.  The more people who see our Indiegogo page, the more likely we are to meet our goal and save 130 million trees!
  • Help our little Tree Mascot go viral – Share her videos on YouTube.
  • Post our Indiegogo page link on your Facebook, or LinkedIn pages and encourage people to make a donation.
  • Tweet about our Indiegogo project, include our link, and encourage people to make a donation.
  • Email or call your local newspaper or radio station and encourage them to report on the Kids 4 the Planet national art contest
  • Write a post about our project on your blog, include our link, and encourage people to make a donation.

                       Thank You Everyone…

Change is at hand for our kids, our trees AND the landfills!

story:
Every September 1st, an annual hunt beings; a hunt for wild dolphins. From September to March, wild dolphins are hunted and driven into a natural cove of water along the shores of Taiji, Japan. Some are sold into captivity, most are slaughtered for human consumption.

In November 2010, I went to the Cove as a volunteer for one week. At the end of that week, I extended my stay to three weeks. At the end of three weeks, I extended my stay in Japan to four months. For 110 days I stood on the rocky shores of the Cove and watched, helplessly, while the lives of dolphins were shattered by my own species. The only way I could fight was via my photography and writing. So I wrote and I photographed and I sent those words and pictures around the world.

I left Japan in March of 2011 and now, finally, it's time to go back. This coming September I will travel to Japan for the third time and stand with Ric O'Barry (star of the Academy Award winning documentary, The Cove) and the incredible people of Save Japan Dolphins. The purpose of our being there is not to encourage anti-Japan feelings and actions, but to work with the local people and raise awareness about the importance of cetaceans and the dangers of consuming their mercury-laden meat.

In order to make this odyssy possible for me, I need to fundraise a minimum of $3,000 to cover airfare ($1,500), train travel within Japan, rental car in Taiji, food, accommodation, International driver's license and any emergency needs that arise while overseas.

During the week I am in Japan, I will be video blogging so that you can follow, should you choose, the work we are doing at the Cove. These video blogs will show exactly what we do while at the Cove, how we interact with local people and the behind-the-scenes work that happens when involved with an International campaign. Diplomacy and respect are key and are two aspects of my work in Japan that mean the most to me as a person and as a conservationist.

In addition to standing with Ric O'Barry and supporting Save Japan Dolphins, I will also be representing my own marine conservation non-profit, Blue Ocean Foundation. All donations to this campaign are tax-deductable due to my 501c3 status.

Please, support my work and help me raise awareness about the Cove.

For more information, watch the documentary, The Cove.

For the Salty Ones,

Liberty

story:
Hola! :)

My name is Danais and I was reared on the island of Vieques, Puerto Rico. My homeland was used as a training range for the U.S. Navy for sixty years, from 1943 until 2003. Growing up I did not understand the consequences of the navy's presence in Vieques, though it affected my family and friends greatly. Today those who are left on the island are living with the toxic waste left behind as a result of the six decades of experimental testing and practice bombings which were dropped on the island. Though the facility has closed, warships and planes have left behind unexploded bombs, rockets and other munitions as well as contaminated waters.

According to the Puerto Rico Department of Health, residents of Vieques, where the naval occupation took place, are more likely to have hypertension, skin diseases, infertility, low birth weights, elevated risks of asthma, cancer, diabetes and heart disease at a higher rate than other Puerto Ricans who live on the mainland of Puerto Rico.

Residents of the island are either sick or have friends or relatives who are ill as a consequence of contaminants deployed by the U.S. Navy. Currently, there is a remnant of citizens who are uniting to present crucial evidence at an upcoming legal proceeding where they will attempt to tangibly illustrate the disastrous effects of the navy's presence on the island. However, in order to do this, there is a need for additional equipment that will enable researchers to go deep sea diving in order to capture the needed evidence for the trial.

The team needs a specialized camera for the photographs because they will be taken so far beneath sea level. These photographs will allow the people of Vieques to capture vital evidence in presenting their case during upcoming legal proceedings. Without this camera they will be unable to present the needed evidence of the physical pollutants and toxins that are affecting so many people. Without this instrumental piece of evidence, their case and lawsuit will most likely be dismissed. However, with your help, we can not only allow them to capture these photographs, but we can also assist in bringing closure to the suffering of a multitude of victims and offer them an opportunity to begin to bring healing to their community and my homeland.

The Impact:
I am hoping to raise these funds which will go towards purchasing a Hero3:Black Edition-Surf camera for the community. With your help we can easily reach this goal, but if for some reason I am unable to raise the total amount, I will still send whatever I am able to raise over to the activists and fishermen who are leading this movement, one of which is my cousin. If we raise more than our goal, the contributions will go towards funding the investigative research that will play a pivotal role in proving the citizens of Vieques’ case.

I thank you for taking the time to learn a little bit about the current situation in Vieques, Puerto Rico. I would love your support in any way possible. Let's make some noise about this campaign! Help me by donating, using the Indiegogo share tools, facebook, twitter and word of mouth!

 

twitter: @LaTainaBori

dtagilliard@gmail.com

story:
Skip To Renew: Going Beyond Bike Lube

Hey Everyone! At Skip To Renew we make machine lubricants out of plant and algae oils. In order to scale-up our algae growing operation, we need $4,020 for growth equipment and $4,090 to run all the neccesary tests for getting our product into trucks. We thank you for helping us build the post-petroleum economy by sharing our link and making a contribution! 

Our Mission, Progress, and Impact

Our mission is to provide high-quality renewable, non-toxic, biodegradable industrial lubricants made from sustainably-sourced plant and algae oils to help transition to a clean, post-petroleum economy. Every unit of bio-based product that we sell is a vote for petroleum independence and a cleaner, more resilient economy.

We are a team of Dominican University greenMBAs, a Biochemist, a former Air Force Flight Engineer, a 10 year sales veteran, and 1 UC Berkeley Business School grad...all working for sweat-equity (aka free) to make Skip To Renew happen.


                       

 

 

 

 

 

 

We launched our first product, Re:Cyclist Bike Chain Lube, in July 2011 as our first step toward displacing petroleum with plant & algae. It's sold in independent bike shops nationwide. We can make a 64x larger impact by finishing development of our algae-based greases and hydraulic fluids-- think about selling gallons and barrels of algae lube vs. 2oz. bottles-- but as a young start up we need your help to get there. 

 

Pioneering Algae Technology

 

In order to roll-out our hydraulic fluid and begin to revolutionize heavy industry, we need $4,020 to invest in equipment that will grow, extract, and process batches of home-made algae oil. 

Every gallon of algae oil we produce sequesters about 20 lbs. of CO2. When grown in our A-Pod growing systems, the algae does not compete for land with food crops, can be grown with gray-water, and can be powered by alternative energy. 

 

 

 

S2R team + fans around our algae pilot tank, the Oracle

 

 

Patents. Sexy, Sexy Patents.

Securing our patents ensures that we can continue producing algae based lube for years to come. We've found a wonderful friend who's willing to help at a discount, but patent work does not come free-- we need $4090 to run necessary tests, pay legal & patent filing fees, and secure our international patent.

How You Can Help:

1.  Support our algae efforts financially

We need $8,110 for purchasing algae equipment, filing patents, and running tests before we can roll out our algae based hydraulic fluid. Every contribution counts toward helping us go head-to-head against Big Oil.

2.  Spread the word

The easiest (but not the only) way is by using the "Share With Friends" tools shown above.  Use facebook, use your blog, use your email, use your voice. 

3.  Buy a bottle of Re:Cyclist lube from your local bike shop

If they don't have it, ask them to carry it and J&B Importers will sell it to them nationwide. Every bit of customer support helps us move our project.

4.  Refer us to your networks 

Know an investor? A potential customer of Re:Cyclist or our future industrial products? Tell 'em about Skip to Renew!
 

Use of Funding:

In-House Algae Production Equipment

Making & Operationalizing 4 A-Pods for growing algae: $1120

Lab Testing for optimizing growth rates: $100

Centrifuge for seperating water from algae: $1200           

Expeller press, for extracting the oils from the algae: $1600

                                     

From left: Centrifuge, Expeller Press

  

      

Patent Expenses

Filing Fees to the gu'mint : $380 Chemical Utility Application & $310 Utility Search Fee

Fees to legal advisors: $400 (a steal!)

International Patent Protection: $1,500

Performance Standard Testing: $1,500 to pay Midwest Laboratories to test and certify our products

Goodies for You!

In addition to peace of mind that you are contributing to the "new green economy," check out our Perks section & Gallery. Let your imagination run wild!


...if we don't reach the goal, at least you'll be able to spread the word about Re:cyclist with your awesome t-shirts, stickers, and lube for your bike. And that  kind of community participation is priceless

Thanks for your support, and rock on with your bad self.
story_txt:
Skip To Renew: Going Beyond Bike Lube
Hey Everyone! At Skip To Renew we make machine lubricants out of plant and algae oils. In order to scale-up our algae growing operation, we need $4,020 for growth equipment and $4,090 to run all the neccesary tests for getting our product into trucks. We thank you for helping us build the post-petroleum economy by sharing our link and making a contribution! 
Our Mission, Progress, and Impact
Our mission is to provide high-quality renewable, non-toxic, biodegradable industrial lubricants made from sustainably-sourced plant and algae oils to help transition to a clean, post-petroleum economy. Every unit of bio-based product that we sell is a vote for petroleum independence and a cleaner, more resilient economy.
We are a team of Dominican University greenMBAs, a Biochemist, a former Air Force Flight Engineer, a 10 year sales veteran, and 1 UC Berkeley Business School grad...all working for sweat-equity (aka free) to make Skip To Renew happen.


                         
 
 
 
 

 
We launched our first product, Re:Cyclist Bike Chain Lube, in July 2011 as our first step toward displacing petroleum with plant & algae. It's sold in independent bike shops nationwide. We can make a 64x larger impact by finishing development of our algae-based greases and hydraulic fluids-- think about selling gallons and barrels of algae lube vs. 2oz. bottles-- but as a young start up we need your help to get there. 
 
Pioneering Algae Technology

 
In order to roll-out our hydraulic fluid and begin to revolutionize heavy industry, we need $4,020 to invest in equipment that will grow, extract, and process batches of home-made algae oil. 
Every gallon of algae oil we produce sequesters about 20 lbs. of CO2. When grown in our A-Pod growing systems, the algae does not compete for land with food crops, can be grown with gray-water, and can be powered by alternative energy. 
 
 
 
S2R team + fans around our algae pilot tank, the Oracle
 
 
Patents. Sexy, Sexy Patents.
Securing our patents ensures that we can continue producing algae based lube for years to come. We've found a wonderful friend who's willing to help at a discount, but patent work does not come free-- we need $4090 to run necessary tests, pay legal & patent filing fees, and secure our international patent.
How You Can Help:
1.  Support our algae efforts financially
We need $8,110 for purchasing algae equipment, filing patents, and running tests before we can roll out our algae based hydraulic fluid. Every contribution counts toward helping us go head-to-head against Big Oil.
2.  Spread the word
The easiest (but not the only) way is by using the "Share With Friends" tools shown above.  Use facebook, use your blog, use your email, use your voice. 
3.  Buy a bottle of Re:Cyclist lube from your local bike shop
If they don't have it, ask them to carry it and J&B Importers will sell it to them nationwide. Every bit of customer support helps us move our project.

4.  Refer us to your networks 
Know an investor? A potential customer of Re:Cyclist or our future industrial products? Tell 'em about Skip to Renew!
 
Use of Funding:
In-House Algae Production Equipment


Making & Operationalizing 4 A-Pods for growing algae: $1120
Lab Testing for optimizing growth rates: $100
Centrifuge for seperating water from algae: $1200           
Expeller press, for extracting the oils from the algae: $1600
                                     
From left: Centrifuge, Expeller Press

  

      
Patent Expenses
Filing Fees to the gu'mint : $380 Chemical Utility Application & $310 Utility Search Fee
Fees to legal advisors: $400 (a steal!)
International Patent Protection: $1,500
Performance Standard Testing: $1,500 to pay Midwest Laboratories to test and certify our products
Goodies for You!
In addition to peace of mind that you are contributing to the "new green economy," check out our Perks section & Gallery. Let your imagination run wild!
...if we don't reach the goal, at least you'll be able to spread the word about Re:cyclist with your awesome t-shirts, stickers, and lube for your bike. And that  kind of community participation is priceless


Thanks for your support, and rock on with your bad self.

story:
*I have decided to greatly condense the contents of this pitch from the original and get straight to the point with it, though you can learn much more about it at http://www.y2y.org if you'd like.

This campaign was set up to donate, free-and-clear, the domain name http://www.y2y.org to the Yellowstone to Yukon Conservation Inititative (currently located at http://www.y2y.net), a non-profit, along with 50% of all donations made here to their cause!

The other 50% of donations will go towards the Inkblot Identity Mechanism located at http://www.Inkblot.com

Thanks!

Kyle Sandau a.k.a. Inkblot

*The Yellowstone to Yukon Conservation Initiative (Y2Y) is not affiliated with the Inkblot Identity Mechanism (Inkblot) nor have they yet to endorse this funding campaign in any way, shape or form. They are currently just a major beneficiary of said campaign in the end and nothing more.

story:
Each year the team at Hawaii Five-0 organize a major big toy drive in Hawaii that the whole cast and crew donates to. The toy drive benefits pupils at local schools, the money raised and donated by the cast and crew buys every single child a present and the remaining funds are used to purchase school supplies, art supplies, sporting equipment and library books.

You may remember our first campaign last year when we raffled off a copy of the 100th episode fan book. Well, this year those lovely folk at Five-0 have been in touch again to find out if we would like to be involved in this year’s event. Never one to shy away from a challenge, we put our thinking caps on and launched our second campaign.

Please give generously - it is an incredibly worthy cause which should be well supported.

Help us support the cast and crew of Hawaii Five-0 in raising funds for Pu'uhale Elementary School

International shipping charges apply. I will contact the winners with shipping information.


All proceeds raised will go directly to the Toy Drive.

story:
Cycas pectinata, a gravely threatened species is distributed in India, Bangladesh, Bhutan, Nepal, Myanmar, Thailand, China and Vietnam. The species is a taxonomical puzzle and is regarded as complex group comprising several species which need to be discovered.

I am seeking support for carrying out fieldwork to study natural populations of Cycas pectinata in Bangladesh, Bhutan, Nepal and Myanmar. I am working on the Indian side of its populations for the last 9 years. However without studying the populations in neighbouring countries, I wouldn't be able to solve the taxonomic puzzle of this complex species. 

Please support my research work in exploring this rare and magnificient group of plants of Jurassic Age.  

JS Khuraijam, Indian Cycad Biologist

Cycad Conservation Program, Northeast India

story:
Short Summary

 

  • My name is Vince Radice and I am the executive director of the newly formed 501 c3 non profit based in San Carlos, Sonora Mexio called WorldsAqaurium. For the last 15 years we have fought for the protection of marine turtles, whales, dolphins sea lions and sustainable fishing practices in the Sea of Cortes. Our ground breaking documentary “El Oro de Cortes” and the Thallasa TV3 French documentary on our efforts showed government complicity in the illegal dorado fishery in Mexico.

 

  • The Mexican government has spent aproximatly 30 million dollars over the last 10 years on Vaquita conservation. Much of that money was unwisely spent. Vaquita are on the brink of extinction. Due to the highly endangered status (Around 60) of the small Vaquita porpoise in the northern gulf region of the Sea of Cortes WorldsAquarium (WA) is funding an independent observer program to monitor the newly enacted governmental ban on gill net fishing with in Vaquita habitat. The Mexican government in conjunction with the international committee for the Recovery of the Vaquita (CIRVA) have welcomed the participation of non governmental organizations (NGO) to actively engage in the observation of the recently installed total gill net ban within the habitat range of the Vaquita.

Where the money goes

The goal is to fund a multi month observation program within the Vaquita range of habitat starting around at the end of November with the goal of extending the program indefinitely, since Vaquita conservation will be a decades long process. WorldsAquarium has two vessels that would work well in the area. One vessel is a shallow drafted 40 foot double A cutter rigged trimaran capable of heavy weather sailing and extended time at sea. The other is a very fast 25 foot super panga with twin 115 horse power four stroke engines. Both these vessels will patrol the Vaquita habitat and be in constant communication with each other.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

  • Two pairs of night vision googles: one for each vessel: $2000
  • Two radar units: $5000
  • Two smart cell phones: $250
  • One Sat phone: $2500
  • Four staff members: Two per vessel: Salaries for hired boat hands 10,000 pesos per month for boat hands for two months total of 40,000 pesos or @ $3000 dollars.
  • 100 gallons of gasoline per week for the 25 foot speed boat for 8 weeks for a total of 800 gallons of fuel for a two month observer program. $3000 at 14 pesos per liter.
  • 100 gallons of diesel fuel for our 36 foot Trimaran for two month program $2000 dollars at 30 pesos per gallon.
  • Provisioning of boats, food and drink $2000
  • Accommodations in San Felipe. House, apartment or hotel rentals. $1000
  • Haul out and bottom job for 40 foot trimaran: $1000
  • Insurance for crew and boats $5000
  • miscellaneous expensives spare boat parts oil mechanics fees $2500

Total; $28,700.00 dollars

The Impact

WorldsAquarium has battled the illegal dorado fishery in Mexico for many years now and is intimately familiar with the nature of illegal fishing in the Sea of Cortes. Our determined commitment to conservation over the last decade is well documented.

By funding this campaign you are greatly increasing transparency on the part of the Mexican government and the chances that Mexico will indeed finally take the necessary actions in Vaquita conservation seriously as well as directly aiding in Vaquita recovery in the northern gulf region of the Sea of Cortes.

After 10 years of concentrated conservation effort and approximately 30 million dollars spent the desert porpoise refereed to as La Vaquita is on the brink of extinction. One of the biggest causes of Vaquita mortality is incidental by catch from gill net fishing. There exist several gill net fisheries, legal and illegal, within the habitat range of Vaquita. Shrimp is perhaps the most lucrative of all the legal fisheries but according to many experts it is the illegal totoaba fishery that is driving the Vaquita to the brink of extinction. Totoaba is a fish of the croaker family and it is highly prized for its air bladder which is smuggled to the United States and then shipped to markets in China. It is common knowledge that drug cartels have become involved in this illegal fishery.

Risks & challenges

Drug cartels are better funded than we are and the strong northwesterly winds of winter make for huge challenges for protecting Vaquita.
Illegal drug cartel sponsored totoaba fisherman set their nets quickly under the cover of darkness, mark the position with GPS and then rapidly exit the area. These illegal gill nets will stay in the water up to 48 hours or longer. Illegal fisherman will, again under the cover of darkness retrieve their nets. The governmental agency of PROFEPA, Mexico’s version of the Environmental Protection Agency has not only been proven incapable of protecting Vaquita but also accused of taking bribes and regulating illegal fishing within Vaquita habitat. This means that the Mexican navy will now take on a greater role in patrolling the Vaquita Refuge.
Since 2006 the Mexican military has been mandated to take a greater role in combating drug cartels and drug trafficking. The Mexican military has been called open to do a job it is not trained for. The military has also come under increased criticism for corruption and violation of human rights. Recent revelations show that the military has been mandated to “Bring Down Criminals in Hours of Darkness”. It is also been shown that ex members of the military have been lured into working with drug cartels. It is under this back drop that the small solitary desert porpoise makes its last stand where the once great colorado river now trickles into the Sea of Cortes. The Mexican navy has also come under criticism for allowing illegal fishing practices to take place in marine protected areas. It is crucial that independent non governmental organizations monitor the Mexican navy while it takes on the huge task of protecting Vaquita habitat, which is a huge area that stretches from San Felipe in Baja Norte all the way to Puerto Penasco on the main land in the state of Sonora.
This drug cartel sponsored illegal fishery is one of the greatest threats to the survival of Vaquita as a species. It will be this activity specifically what WA will be on the look out for. Our 25 years of living in the Sea of Cortes and our past committment to conservation mean we are up to the challenge of patrolling and observing within the Vaquita range of habitat. Please help us make this campaign a reality!


This was our special report on Vaquita from our first Indiegogo Campaign! The post can be found here.



Our Team


Aaron Quintanar


Aaron Quintanar first traveled the entire Baja California peninsula overland with his parents during the winter of 1969-1970. His exploration of the peninsula continued in search of remote fishing and surfing areas. Aaron, a 25-year lifeguard veteran in San Diego, helped establish lifeguard agencies in Tijuana, Ensenada, Punta Abreojos and Todos Santos. From, 2000 to 2005 he led the conservation efforts at the conservation organization Wildcoast. During this period, he led a conservation team in working to protect Bahia Concepcion, Laguna San Ignacio, and Bahia de los Angeles from large-scale development and industrialization efforts. In 2002, Aaron and attorney Rodrigo Jara filed a successful legal challenge against the Escalera Nautica – a project of the Mexican Federal Government calling for the construction of 27 resort marinas on both sides of the Baja California peninsula. From 2006 to 2008, he structured an innovative new conservation model designed to protect Midriff Island region of the Sea of Cortez. Aaron structured the strategy to address border energy issues involving the Sierra Juarez and Sierra San Pedro Martir. He also led the American Bird Conservancy’s effort to protect a newly established colony of Laysan Albatross on Isla Guadalupe from commercial longline fishing impacts. He is a graduate of the University of California, San Diego.


John Layman



John has been a partner in the Layman law firm located in Spokane Washington since 1983. His practice involves serious personal injury complex litigation, with an emphasis on traumatic brain injuries and spinal/aquatic injuries.

Because of his extensive and diverse experience with brain injuries and his extremely successful representation of its victims, John garners the highest level of respect within the medical community, and has been honored by his peers as one of the State of Washington’s “Super Lawyers”. John also was named as one of Washington’s top 100 trial lawyers by the American Trial Lawyers Association. Feel free to review the testimonials of several of John’s peers in the medical community.

John is an active sportsman who loves mountain biking, skiing, fishing and free diving. John has a second home in San Carlos Sonora and has been coming to the Sea of Cortes to fish for over 20 years. He is greatly concerned with the conservation of marine resources.


Chip White



Chip White began began his Sea of Cortes odyssey in the mid 80’s windsurfing. The wind and waves of the beach at La Managa in San Carlos Sonora helped to fuel a lifelong love of the Sea.  Chip graduated from the University of Colorado with a Business degree.  After school he became a banker then a member of the board of directors of the First National Bank of Durango.  Chip also was one of the co-founders and President of the international ski head wear company Bula.  Chip has been guiding back country snowmobile & mountain biking tours for over 15 years out of Durango.  An accomplished free diver and sailor Chip currently spends his time between Durango Colorado and San Carlos, Sonora Mexico.  His love of the Sea of Cortes and his commitment to conservation continue to be a driving force in his life.


Vince Radice



Vince moved to San Carlos, one of the true jewels of the Sea of Cortes, in 1990. As a child growing up in the suburbs of Chicago his curiosity for all things aquatic were fueled by the late great under water explorer Jacques Cousteau. After graduating from the University of Arizona with a B.S. In microbiology and a minor in chemistry and the realization that working in the lab could never compare to exploring the Sea of Cortes; Vince made the move from Tucson to San Carlos to run his own water sports company. After years of fishing, sailing, windsurfing, kayaking, kiteboarding and scuba diving and thus personally bearing witness to the rape and pillage of marine resources in the Gulf of California, Worlds Aquarium was born.  In 2008, with support from many in Cabo San Lucas and San Carlos, he filmed the well known (in the Sea of Cortes) documentary El Oro de Cortes, which documented Mexico’s illegal dorado fishery and how those thousands of tons of fish  are illegally exported to the United States.

 

Tim Kuzelka



Tim is an Attorney who leverages his legal and management expertise to assist organizations dedicated to environmental concerns. Currently serving on the Board of Directors for World’s Aquarium, a 501(c)(3) focused on ocean life conservation in the Sea of Cortez. As a legal consultant, brings 30+years experience to deliver solutions and develop organizations that make the world a better place to inhabit.


Some of the Perks for the campaign!

story:
Hello! Our name's are Cameo and Christophe. I'm a hairstylist by trade and Christophe is the Harbour Master of a small Marina, working in a remote island community near Bella Bella, B.C.  Here is my story!

Behold, Moonlight Gambler!  

This home built steel boat was the pride and joy of it's creator, Paul Wyatt. He lived on it for years, putting over 40,000 miles of blue water sailing beneath her keels. One of his main goals was to be the oldest man to sail solo and non-stop around the world! As he was preparing for his voyage, a man just a few years older than he had completed the very same dream and had broken the record. Paul took it surprisingly well, biding his time until he was old enough to be the oldest man to circumnavigate. Unfortunately that dream would never be fulfilled. He was diagnosed with cancer and died quite suddenly, so Moonlight Gambler drifted in limbo.  

The rest, I'm afraid, does not get much better. The two step sons inherited the vessel by default, in spite of the fact that they had little desire to sail. It was not longer than a month before she would be hauled out and left to rust in a storage yard. Shortly after that, the brothers began to post ads on various websites in an attempt to sell the boat out from under each other, but due to Moonlight Gambler's strange one-of-a-kind build, there was either little interest or the sellers would not respond to the inquirers.

  My partner and I have been trying to buy this boat for a long time. We tried our best to reach the brothers any time we saw a new ad posted, each time the photos and description of the boat in the ad would give us a false sense of hope. After many attempts to purchase, we were disheartened and finally gave up.

Moonlight Gambler came back into my mind on August 7th. I decided to do a quick Google search to see if anything new came up. I was wide-eyed and had to pick my jaw up from the floor when I read that the boat had been seized by the boatyard and was put up for auction last September. So we called the boat yard where she lies, collecting dust, and spoke to the harbormaster. Moonlight Gambler was still there! When we mentioned her name we could hear a 'groan' over the phone. He went on to explain that the storage payments had stopped and that the yard now had possession. We are working out a reasonable price, though the boat is no longer as sea worthy as she once was. Somebody had broken in to the yard and began to "part her out". We called just in time, as the boatyard had been left with no choice but to schedule a demolition date for Moonlight Gambler.  Despite the fact that she is not in top condition, we are still highly motivated to take on this project. Every dollar we procure will go towards restoring what was lost/stolen/neglected. 


She will need many things replaced, as she has been left alone for 7 years and has had all of her gear stripped. Her mast and rudder are missing, and who knows what other ocean-going gear from inside. We hope to head down to where she lies to assess the damage ourselves in the fall. Please help us raise some money to bring her back to the sea where she belongs. When that dream is a reality, we will then live on the boat and sail it up to the central coast of B.C. for yet another working season before we head out into the big blue!

 Thank you for reading my story!
story_txt:
Hello! Our name's are Cameo and Christophe. I'm a hairstylist by trade and Christophe is the Harbour Master of a small Marina, working in a remote island community near Bella Bella, B.C.  Here is my story!Behold, Moonlight Gambler!  
This home built steel boat was the pride and joy of it's creator, Paul Wyatt. He lived on it for years, putting over 40,000 miles of blue water sailing beneath her keels. One of his main goals was to be the oldest man to sail solo and non-stop around the world! As he was preparing for his voyage, a man just a few years older than he had completed the very same dream and had broken the record. Paul took it surprisingly well, biding his time until he was old enough to be the oldest man to circumnavigate. Unfortunately that dream would never be fulfilled. He was diagnosed with cancer and died quite suddenly, so Moonlight Gambler drifted in limbo.  
The rest, I'm afraid, does not get much better. The two step sons inherited the vessel by default, in spite of the fact that they had little desire to sail. It was not longer than a month before she would be hauled out and left to rust in a storage yard. Shortly after that, the brothers began to post ads on various websites in an attempt to sell the boat out from under each other, but due to Moonlight Gambler's strange one-of-a-kind build, there was either little interest or the sellers would not respond to the inquirers.
  My partner and I have been trying to buy this boat for a long time. We tried our best to reach the brothers any time we saw a new ad posted, each time the photos and description of the boat in the ad would give us a false sense of hope. After many attempts to purchase, we were disheartened and finally gave up.
Moonlight Gambler came back into my mind on August 7th. I decided to do a quick Google search to see if anything new came up. I was wide-eyed and had to pick my jaw up from the floor when I read that the boat had been seized by the boatyard and was put up for auction last September. So we called the boat yard where she lies, collecting dust, and spoke to the harbormaster. Moonlight Gambler was still there! When we mentioned her name we could hear a 'groan' over the phone. He went on to explain that the storage payments had stopped and that the yard now had possession. We are working out a reasonable price, though the boat is no longer as sea worthy as she once was. Somebody had broken in to the yard and began to "part her out". We called just in time, as the boatyard had been left with no choice but to schedule a demolition date for Moonlight Gambler.  Despite the fact that she is not in top condition, we are still highly motivated to take on this project. Every dollar we procure will go towards restoring what was lost/stolen/neglected. 

She will need many things replaced, as she has been left alone for 7 years and has had all of her gear stripped. Her mast and rudder are missing, and who knows what other ocean-going gear from inside. We hope to head down to where she lies to assess the damage ourselves in the fall. Please help us raise some money to bring her back to the sea where she belongs. When that dream is a reality, we will then live on the boat and sail it up to the central coast of B.C. for yet another working season before we head out into the big blue!
 Thank you for reading my story!

story:
Summary

  • Have you ever been to a landfill? 
  • Did you know plastics amounted to at least 20% of all landfill garbage?
  • Did you know most plastic products take hundreds of years to degrade?
  • Did you know sea animals like turtle often mistake plastic as food, and die from swallowing it?
  • We want to start a movement: To replace disposable plasticware, like the disposable plastic spoon & Styrofoam cup, with a biodegradable alternative.


A Landfill: Image courtesy of FreeDigitalPhotos.net


What can you do to help?

  • Plastic product recycling - Good.
  • Reduce plastic product usage - Better. 
  • Replace plastic product with something else that can biodegrade into mere water and carbon dioxide - BEST  


Who We Are

Gomaize is a start-up founded by a group of environmentally-conscious young entrepreneurs in 2012. Based in Los Angeles, we work with global suppliers and manufacturer to produce corn-based household product. Our first line of product is the eco-friendly partyware that will biodegrade and decompose easily, and leave minimal burden on the environment. 


What We Need & What You Get

Change is hard, but we understand we have to start somewhere. 

We want to make a change, And we could use your help. 

By contributing to our movement, we will send out sets of biodegradable partyware (forks, spoons, knives, plates, bowls, and cups) to you, your family, your friends, or any organization of your choice. Replace the traditional plasticware with biodegradable one we sent you. Use it at your party, at home, at your office or at any event, anytime. 

Use that to make an impact. Use that to start a change. 


The Product

What we will ship: Disposable Partyware Set Made of Corn-Starch
  • Spoons
  • Forks
  • Knives
  • Plates
  • Cups
  • Bowls 
Main Characteristics: Biodegradable, Compostable, Eco-friendly. 
● Made from renewable resources (Non-GMO dent corn) [Not petroleum!]
● Requires less energy to produce [than petroleum based plastic!]
● Generates fewer greenhouse gases [than petroleum based plastic!] 
● Non-toxic when it breaks down (turn into carbon dioxide and water)
● Biodegrade and compost in as little as 6 months*


Main ingredient in our biodegradable partyware is the high-quality US-made PLA resins by NatureWorks (a division of Cargill). These PLA pallets are derived from field corns, the same feedstock grown for many other industrial uses (including livestock feed and corn syrup). Though other plants, including sugarcanes and potatoes, can also be used to produce PLA, corn has been chosen because of it's advantage over price and abundancy in the states. For those who are concern that using corn as manufacturing material will have adverse impact on the food prices or supply, the PLA production industry uses less than 0.0005% of the annual global corn crop today, based on a 2008 data provided by NatureWorks. Besides, we don't eat the field corn!


Products carry numerous US and Internationally recognized certifications:

  • Compostable by BPI (USA)

  • OK Compost by Vincotte (Belgium)

  • ASTM D6400

  • ISO 14855


    The Impact

    Everyone could make a difference, Even a small one. And anyone could easily start making a difference now. 

    We don't expect to change people's habit overnight. Or having an unrealistic dream of eliminating plastic completely and live in a plastic-FREE world by next week. 

    But for every set of degradable bio-plastic partyware we send out, it helps promote awareness among the public on availability of a BETTER alternative to plastic.  And that, put us a step closer to a better world. 


      Risks & Challenges

      Plastic is so ubiquitous and has been essentials in our daily lives for years. And it's been commercialized so economically that you will find any other alternatives (includes bioplastic, paper, bamboo, wood, etc) to be too expensive to be used as replacement.

      Bioplastic, like the corn-based PLA, is still at its nascent stage. Technology is not matured nor demand is great enough for the price to lower down to a competitive level, as compared to traditional petroleum-based plastic. But the least we could do is to educate the general public of the existence of these eco-friendly alternatives and to promote the awareness of the disadvanatages of petroleum-based plastic. 


        Learn more

        Click on links below to find out more and share with your friends and family.

        http://ecologycenter.org/plastics/

        http://www.bpiworld.org/

        http://science.howstuffworks.com/environmental/earth/oceanography/great-pacific-garbage-patch1.htm

        http://www.citizenscampaign.org/campaigns/plastic-bags.asp

        http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polylactic_acid

        http://www.natureworksllc.com/The-Ingeo-Journey/Eco-Profile-and-LCA/How-Ingeo-is-Made


        *Our corn-based bioplastic products biodegrade and decompose best at commercial composting facility, home-based composter, or landfill under the right temperature with right amount of humidity. Do not discard them by the street, freeway or ocean/river. It's not designed to biodegrade under those environments.
