story:
This incredible study abroad will walk us through carefully selected habitats in search of diverse and wonderful African mega-fauna and the colorful vocal birdlife with two of South Africa’s leading trackers and guides. Kersey Lawrence and Lee Gutteridge make a dynamic and knowledgeable team and will guide us through our exploration and the many regions of South Africa that they call home.

 

 

Lee is the author of six South African natural history books to date and is one of only 10 FGASA Scout Guides (the highest qualification that can be earned). Kersey, a PhD candidate at UCONN and an award-winning educator, is the only female Senior Tracker in the world.

Our group will be focused on wildlife ecology, tracking, and human culture in Southern Africa. This adventure will last for 15 days/14 nights, from August 3rd to the 17th. Our group will be staying in two locations within Kruger National Park. Each one a special environment different than the other.

 

 

Our daily activities will include GIS mapping, data collection, track casting, track and sign evaluation, camera trapping, presentations, night drives, astronomy sessions, journaling, and SO much more.

 

 

Because our camps are immersed within the South African wildlife we will be highly exposed to all it has to offer. With Safari experiences both in vehicles and on foot, we will be able to apply our learned field techniques in action. We will have the chance of observing the “BIG FIVE” (seen below) among many other highly sought-after species.

 

The Big Five - Leopard, Lion, Elephant, Cape Buffalo and Rhinoceros.

I have every intention on taking in as much as possible while on this once in a lifetime study. The educational opportunity given to me to further my studies in such a unique way will not be taken for granted. When the trip comes to an end we'll be given the opportunity to test our skills to obtain a ranking in the internationally recognized CyberTracker Track and Sign evaluation. A highly anticipated opportunity for myself.

story:
Habitat ID is a conservation group that specializes in going into underprioritised protected areas (PAs) and doing wildlife surveys that local governments and NGOs cannot or will not do. Our mission is to prove that these "paper parks" (national parks, wildlife sanctuaries, or other PAs that exist on paper but in reality get little or no real protection in the form of ranger patrols or government support) are worth being treated as "real" parks with adequate protection because of the wildlife they still shelter. We have already proven that Cambodia's Virachey National Park is still home to a plethora of wildlife (see our latest Featured video on Mongabay here), and in the Phnom Penh Post. You can also have a look at the project we did in Thailand here. Our Virachey project is ongoing, but we are in need of funds to pay for ranger patrols, especially in the Vietnam border area where poachers, miners, and loggers cross over illegally into Cambodia to plunder the park. We also need funding to pay the VNP ranger's daily supply allowance (DSA) when they check on our camera traps, and of course there are expenses for new memory cards, lithium batteries, and silica desiccants to keep the cameras dry. My work as Field Coordinator for Habitat ID was recently cited in an excellent article on dholes in The Guardian.

A rare Douc Langur comes down from the forest canopy in Virachey NP to pose for our camera trap!

And now we will be launching a new project in Sumatra, Indonesia, in the mountains south of Lake Toba called Hadabuan Hill. This large forested habitat is currently just a "community forest," but a local NGO has found evidence of a breeding population of tigers. Locals tantalizingly speak of a population of orangutans that still in habit the difficult to access areas of this range (orangutans found living outside of Gunung Leuser NP or Bukit Tigapaluh would be a very important discovery), and some even say there is a chance that Sumatran rhinoceros can still be found there. Malayan tapirs also call this forest home, but they are in danger of being poisoned by local farmers as these beautiful and shy animals are fond of feeding on the rubber trees and other crops in the surrounding plantations, which go right up to the forest edge. Clouded leopards, sun bears, leopard cats, five species of hornbill, and many other animals also call this currently "lost forest" home.

The potential for an amazing ecotourism experience in the Hadabuan Hills is simply off the charts. A 7-day trek can be organized that terminates in a swim in Lake Toba, the largest volcanic lake in Southeast Asia and the site of the largest volcanic eruption in Earth's history. Enough said!

What We Need

  • Fences for the areas of Hadabuan Hill that border rubber plantations in Sumatra. We can build a good fence for about $500, and we need at least two of them.
  • Camera-traps for the Hadabuan Hill community forest in Sumatra to conduct a wildlife survey to find out how many tigers, tapirs, and other animals inhabit this all but unknown area.
  • Daily Supply Allowance (DSA) for the tiger rangers of Hadanbuan Hill, who currently work on an unpaid volunteer basis.
  • DSA for the Virachey National Park (Cambodia) rangers to flush out and arrest both local and Vietnamese loggers, poachers, miners, and encroachers. $500 can pay for a 10-day armed patrol and we would like to sponsor several of these.
  • Memory cards, lithium batteries, silica desiccants, and DSA for the VNP rangers to check on our camera traps, which have already recorded douc langur, black bear, sun bear, clouded leopard, gaur, and many other species.

The Impact

  • The construction of fences around the rubber plantations of Hadabuan Hill will have an immediate impact. The fences will make it much more difficult for tapirs to enter plantations and eat crops, thus dramatically reducing the risk of them being poisoned by frustrated farmers who want to protect their crops.
  • A proper wildlife survey of Hadabuan Hill, combined with a robust ecotourism program (currently not a single tourist has ever visited this area) and a good management plan will boost the area's chance of being upgraded into a national park or wildlife sanctuary, thus receiving better protection than it currently gets.
  • As for Cambodia, the rangers know exactly where to find Virachey's intruders; they just need the funds to go in and get them!

story:
Le Bar à Vrac signifie...


LE PREMIER COMMERCE 100% SANS EMBALLAGES JETABLES EN PROVENCE... où vous trouverez DES PRODUITS LOCAUX DE QUALITÉ - produits alimentaires, d'hygiène et d'entretien - À DES PRIX ACCESSIBLES, vendus AU POIDS DANS DES CONTENANTS RÉUTILISABLES CONSIGNÉS, ou dans ceux que vous apporterez avec vous... 


 

LE PREMIER BAR/ÉPICERIE EN FRANCE OU VOUS POURREZ FAIRE REMPLIR VOS BOUTEILLES AU COMPTOIR de vins, de jus, mais aussi de sodas et de bières fraîches... 





UN LIEU CONVIVIAL OÙ FAIRE SES COURSES AVEC PLAISIR, au milieu des couleurs, des saveurs et des matières brutes... Un lieu lumineux et chaleureux en centre ville OÙ S'ARRÊTER, SE RETROUVER, DISCUTER autour d'un verre et de gourmandises, EN FRANÇAIS, MAIS AUSSI EN ANGLAIS, EN ESPAGNOL, plus autres langues marseillaises que vous y apporterez. Un lieu au-delà des étiquettes,  ouvert au mélange des genres. 




L'INNOVATION, L'UTILITÉ SOCIALE ET ENVIRONNEMENTALE, mais aussi LE GOÛT, LE PLAISIR, LA CULTURE DU QUOTIDIEN... En bref, UNE SENSIBILISATION JOYEUSE.





Les déchets d'emballages, y en a marre

Les emballages débordent... Ils sont coûteux, encombrants, énergivores, souvent superflus, très partiellement triés et recyclés, et même ceux qui le sont, redeviennent pour beaucoup des déchets problématiques à la fin de leur cycle de vie. Seuls le verre et les métaux se recyclent à l'infini, avec un coût économique et environnemental que l'on oublie trop facilement. Partout, dans le monde se répandent les débris de nos emballages plastique, polluant les espaces naturels, terre et mer, jusqu'aux océans. En Méditerranée, on estime à 115 000 particules par km2 les déchets qui la contaminent(1). Or la Région Provence Alpes Côte d'Azur fait figure de cancre du tri et du recyclage, bien en-dessous de la moyenne nationale, les chiffres les plus bas revenant au département des Bouches du Rhône. A Marseille même, il suffit de se promener dans le centre ville pour constater l'incroyable quantité de bouteilles, canettes, pots et autres emballages qui débordent des poubelles destinées à l'incinération, et même des caniveaux ! 
C'est dire l'urgence d'agir, ici, dans ce département et cette région, pour changer les comportements. 

(1) Voir l'étude de MED http://www.dailymotion.com/video/xn29c1_med-expedition-2011-12_news?start=21


Le pari du Bar à Vrac : innovation écologique et création d'emplois durables

Selon l'adage "le meilleur déchet est sans conteste celui qui n'est pas produit", et les constats listés ci-dessus, incluant les spécificités locales, le Bar à Vrac relève ainsi le défi de sensibiliser un éventail le plus large possible de marseillais-e-s et par extension de producteurs, distributeurs et commerçants de la région - à la consommation de produits locaux sans emballages jetables.

Nous n'inventons rien mais proposons de remettre au centre la valeur fondamentale du produit et en périphérie de celui-ci la valeur d'usage des emballages. La réutilisation des emballages est le seul moyen au coût énergétique le plus faible, de rallonger le cycle de vie de quantité de matières dont très peu sont effectivement recyclées.

De l'association     au Bar à Vrac


J'ai fondé l'association 2L Léger&Local en 2010, avec un petit groupe de convaincus, et l'objectif principal d'accompagner les producteurs, distributeurs et commerçants dans la réduction des déchets à la source, et en particulier des emballages jetables. Dans ce cadre, j'ai travaillé tous les aspects de la vente en vrac et en consigné : réglementaire, technique, logistique, marketing, y compris le design de solutions de distribution de produits liquides. Après plusieurs années au service des professionnels, nous avons fait plusieurs constats:
  • un panel important de citoyen-ne-s consommateur-rice-s est prêt et même en attente d'une offre de produits courants sans emballages jetables;
  • ce type d'offre implique un changement conséquent dans la gestion d'un commerce, et donc un investissement que les commerces déjà en place n'ont pas forcément la possibilité ou craignent de faire dans le contexte précaire actuel; 
  • les producteurs et distributeurs sont eux-mêmes soumis aux standards des commerces existants et ne peuvent investir dans une offre vrac et/ou consignée tant qu'il n'y a pas suffisamment de demandes.
En conclusion, il est apparu qu'à ce stade, pour faire avancer notre cause, il fallait choisir L'EXEMPLARITÉ. Faire nous-mêmes la démonstration de la faisabilité de ce mode de consommation. Nous possédons le savoir, mettons le au service direct des citoyen-ne-s :  ainsi est née l'idée du Bar à Vrac.


Seulement, cette nouvelle aventure ayant une dimension économique et commerciale bien plus poussée que la mission d'origine de l'association, le CA de 2L m'a encouragée à m'y lancer seule, en créant une société. 

Portrait 
Mon nom est Nathalie Boudé. Je vis à Marseille et vais fêter mes 50 ans dans quelques jours. Je suis divorcée, j'ai trois enfants, et j'élève encore le plus jeune - 11 ans. J'ai toujours travaillé sur ou autour d'initiatives citoyennes qui me paraissaient importantes et qui me donnaient envie de me battre pour elles, D'abord comme journaliste et photographe, ensuite comme chargée de projets / missions. Au fil des années, j'ai créé trois associations, j'ai été élue municipale, et je suis l'auteure de l'ouvrage Les Bâtisseurs de la Marge. Ayant consacré ces dernières années à 2L Léger&Local, passant de salariée à bénévole à temps plein, selon les ressources de l'association, je suis aujourd'hui demandeure d'emploi non rémunérée.
Le Bar à Vrac représente, pour moi, à la fois une mission d'utilité sociale et environnementale, un beau challenge, la valorisation de l'expertise acquise à travers les années investies dans 2L, sans compter mon temps, mon énergie et mes revenus, mais aussi la création d'emplois durables. Création d'emplois directe au sein de ce commerce, mais aussi indirecte via l'effet boule de neige que notre initative devrait provoquer : soutien de producteurs, reproduction du modèle !!! 

       



Pourquoi j'ai besoin de vous et ce que je peux vous offrir


J'ai besoin de 20 000 € pour constituer un apport personnel suffisant à hauteur de 30% du montant des besoins en investissement et en trésorerie de démarrage, afin que les organismes et une banque me suivent. Les besoins au démarrage s'élèvent à plus de 60 000€ en comptant un droit au bail moyen de 25 000€. Sans cet apport personnel, aucun des trois types de prêt d'investissement que je m'apprête à solliciter - prêt d'honneur, Nacre, bancaire - ni aucune garantie - Fonds de Garantie à l'Initiative des Femmes - ne me seront attribués pour monter ce commerce. 

Etant donné ma situation personnelle, j'ai besoin de vous pour faire levier sur les financements classiques. 

Je peux vous offrir en contrepartie :

  • Un immense merci;
  • la satisfaction de contribuer à un projet écologiquement et socialement très utile et d'avoir votre nom inscrit en toutes lettres sur le mur du Bar en Vrac;
  • un gros bisou de la créatrice;
  • votre nom sur le mur du Bar en Vrac;
  • Un café ou un verre avec le sourire;
  • De 1 à 4 contenants réutilisables;
  • Un kit complet découverte du Bar à Vrac rempli de bons produits;
  • Des bons de réduction de 10 à 20% sur vos premiers achats;
  • Un photo-tour découverte de Marseille en compagnie d'un photographe professionel;
  • Un repas sur l'une des bonnes terrasses marseillaises;
  • Une nuit ou un week-end complet dans un charmant 3 pièces avec terrasse dans le ciel et vue sur le port de Marseille, pour vous, en couple, en famille ou entre amis.



L'impact

  1. Votre aide est capitale pour moi, vous l'avez compris, et ce quel qu'en soit le montant ! Si je n'atteins pas l'objectif des 20 000€, j'utiliserais quand même chaque euro donné pour obtenir mes prêts.  Je devrais en réduire les montants mais je démarrerais, y compris avec moins de produits.
  2. Votre aide est capitale pour Marseille et ses habitants fatigués de vivre dans un environnement où les déchets d'emballages font partie du paysage.Donnons leur des alternatives, ouvrons de nouvelles perspectives. Si un bar/épicerie sans embllages jetables ouvre et remporte le succès escompté, d'autres suivront.
  3. Votre aide est capitale pour la Provence et la Méditerranée, d'une part parce bon nombre d'emballages jetés ici finissent à l'incinération, à l'enfouissement, ou à la mer. D'autre part, parce que si nous parvenons à changer les comportements, ne serait-ce que d'une minorité, à Marseille, l'idée essaimera sur le territoire.

              



Risques et défis

Bien sûr, le Bar à Vrac est un défi, mais un défi "right on time" porté par une personne d'expérience. Le risque est donc minime.

  • C'est le bon moment. De plus en plus de personnes veulent consommer responsable, privilégient la qualité, la provenance locale des produits et veulent réduire leurs déchets. Toutes les initiatives économiques donnant sens aux actes d'achat sont en développement positif, de nombreux territoires, dont la Région Provence Alpes Côte d'Azur, se sont portés candidats pour expérimenter la démarche Zéro Waste en France; quant à la vente en vrac, elle est en plein essor. http://www.francetvinfo.fr/france/video-consomm...
  • J'ai non seulement acquis l'expertise nécessaire à la mise en place d'une offre vrac et consigne, mais j'ai aussi participé au lancement d'une épicerie paysanne à Marseille en 2013, un commerce qui marche du tonnerre !
  • Enfin, j'ai le soutien de nombreux marseillais et marseillaises qui seront aussi mes premier-e-s client-e-s !


D'autres façons d'aider

Même si vous ne pouvez pas soutenir ce projet financièrement, vous pouvez être d'un précieux soutien. Vous pouvez aussi :

  • Faire connaître ce projet et cette campagne autour de vous, en utilisant les outils de partage Indiegogo ou tout autre moyen de diffusion;
  • Partager avec Le Bar à Vrac votre savoir, vos attentes, vos envies - produits/producteurs, emplacements pour le local, recettes, contenants malins, etc... Contactez-moi par email !
story_txt:
Le Bar à Vrac signifie...


LE PREMIER COMMERCE 100% SANS EMBALLAGES JETABLES EN PROVENCE... où vous trouverez DES PRODUITS LOCAUX DE QUALITÉ - produits alimentaires, d'hygiène et d'entretien - À DES PRIX ACCESSIBLES, vendus AU POIDS DANS DES CONTENANTS RÉUTILISABLES CONSIGNÉS, ou dans ceux que vous apporterez avec vous... 




 

LE PREMIER BAR/ÉPICERIE EN FRANCE OU VOUS POURREZ FAIRE REMPLIR VOS BOUTEILLES AU COMPTOIR de vins, de jus, mais aussi de sodas et de bières fraîches... 







UN LIEU CONVIVIAL OÙ FAIRE SES COURSES AVEC PLAISIR, au milieu des couleurs, des saveurs et des matières brutes... Un lieu lumineux et chaleureux en centre ville OÙ S'ARRÊTER, SE RETROUVER, DISCUTER autour d'un verre et de gourmandises, EN FRANÇAIS, MAIS AUSSI EN ANGLAIS, EN ESPAGNOL, plus autres langues marseillaises que vous y apporterez. Un lieu au-delà des étiquettes,  ouvert au mélange des genres. 









L'INNOVATION, L'UTILITÉ SOCIALE ET ENVIRONNEMENTALE, mais aussi LE GOÛT, LE PLAISIR, LA CULTURE DU QUOTIDIEN... En bref, UNE SENSIBILISATION JOYEUSE.






Les déchets d'emballages, y en a marre


Les emballages débordent... Ils sont coûteux, encombrants, énergivores, souvent superflus, très partiellement triés et recyclés, et même ceux qui le sont, redeviennent pour beaucoup des déchets problématiques à la fin de leur cycle de vie. Seuls le verre et les métaux se recyclent à l'infini, avec un coût économique et environnemental que l'on oublie trop facilement. Partout, dans le monde se répandent les débris de nos emballages plastique, polluant les espaces naturels, terre et mer, jusqu'aux océans. En Méditerranée, on estime à 115 000 particules par km2 les déchets qui la contaminent(1). Or la Région Provence Alpes Côte d'Azur fait figure de cancre du tri et du recyclage, bien en-dessous de la moyenne nationale, les chiffres les plus bas revenant au département des Bouches du Rhône. A Marseille même, il suffit de se promener dans le centre ville pour constater l'incroyable quantité de bouteilles, canettes, pots et autres emballages qui débordent des poubelles destinées à l'incinération, et même des caniveaux ! 

C'est dire l'urgence d'agir, ici, dans ce département et cette région, pour changer les comportements. 



(1) Voir l'étude de MED http://www.dailymotion.com/video/xn29c1_med-expedition-2011-12_news?start=21



Le pari du Bar à Vrac : innovation écologique et création d'emplois durables
Selon l'adage "le meilleur déchet est sans conteste celui qui n'est pas produit", et les constats listés ci-dessus, incluant les spécificités locales, le Bar à Vrac relève ainsi le défi de sensibiliser un éventail le plus large possible de marseillais-e-s et par extension de producteurs, distributeurs et commerçants de la région - à la consommation de produits locaux sans emballages jetables.
Nous n'inventons rien mais proposons de remettre au centre la valeur
fondamentale du produit et en périphérie de celui-ci la
valeur d'usage des emballages. La réutilisation des emballages est
le seul moyen au coût énergétique le plus faible, de rallonger le
cycle de vie de quantité de matières dont très peu sont
effectivement recyclées.

De l'association     au Bar à Vrac




J'ai fondé l'association 2L Léger&Local en 2010, avec un petit groupe de convaincus, et l'objectif principal d'accompagner les producteurs, distributeurs et commerçants dans la réduction des déchets à la source, et en particulier des emballages jetables. Dans ce cadre, j'ai travaillé tous les aspects de la vente en vrac et en consigné : réglementaire, technique, logistique, marketing, y compris le design de solutions de distribution de produits liquides. Après plusieurs années au service des professionnels, nous avons fait plusieurs constats:

un panel important de citoyen-ne-s consommateur-rice-s est prêt et même en attente d'une offre de produits courants sans emballages jetables;


ce type d'offre implique un changement conséquent dans la gestion d'un commerce, et donc un investissement que les commerces déjà en place n'ont pas forcément la possibilité ou craignent de faire dans le contexte précaire actuel; 


les producteurs et distributeurs sont eux-mêmes soumis aux standards des commerces existants et ne peuvent investir dans une offre vrac et/ou consignée tant qu'il n'y a pas suffisamment de demandes.

En conclusion, il est apparu qu'à ce stade, pour faire avancer notre cause, il fallait choisir L'EXEMPLARITÉ. Faire nous-mêmes la démonstration de la faisabilité de ce mode de consommation. Nous possédons le savoir, mettons le au service direct des citoyen-ne-s :  ainsi est née l'idée du Bar à Vrac.


Seulement, cette nouvelle aventure ayant une dimension économique et commerciale bien plus poussée que la mission d'origine de l'association, le CA de 2L m'a encouragée à m'y lancer seule, en créant une société. 
Portrait 
Mon nom est Nathalie Boudé. Je vis à Marseille et vais fêter mes 50 ans dans quelques jours. Je suis divorcée, j'ai trois enfants, et j'élève encore le plus jeune - 11 ans. J'ai toujours travaillé sur ou autour d'initiatives citoyennes qui me paraissaient importantes et qui me donnaient envie de me battre pour elles, D'abord comme journaliste et photographe, ensuite comme chargée de projets / missions. Au fil des années, j'ai créé trois associations, j'ai été élue municipale, et je suis l'auteure de l'ouvrage Les Bâtisseurs de la Marge. Ayant consacré ces dernières années à 2L Léger&Local, passant de salariée à bénévole à temps plein, selon les ressources de l'association, je suis aujourd'hui demandeure d'emploi non rémunérée.
Le Bar à Vrac représente, pour moi, à la fois une mission d'utilité sociale et environnementale, un beau challenge, la valorisation de l'expertise acquise à travers les années investies dans 2L, sans compter mon temps, mon énergie et mes revenus, mais aussi la création d'emplois durables. Création d'emplois directe au sein de ce commerce, mais aussi indirecte via l'effet boule de neige que notre initative devrait provoquer : soutien de producteurs, reproduction du modèle !!! 
       

Pourquoi j'ai besoin de vous et ce que je peux vous offrir

J'ai besoin de 20 000 € pour constituer un apport personnel suffisant à hauteur de 30% du montant des besoins en investissement et en trésorerie de démarrage, afin que les organismes et une banque me suivent. Les besoins au démarrage s'élèvent à plus de 60 000€ en comptant un droit au bail moyen de 25 000€. Sans cet apport personnel, aucun des trois types de prêt d'investissement que je m'apprête à solliciter - prêt d'honneur, Nacre, bancaire - ni aucune garantie - Fonds de Garantie à l'Initiative des Femmes - ne me seront attribués pour monter ce commerce. 
Etant donné ma situation personnelle, j'ai besoin de vous pour faire levier sur les financements classiques. 
Je peux vous offrir en contrepartie :

Un immense merci;
la satisfaction de contribuer à un projet écologiquement et socialement très utile et d'avoir votre nom inscrit en toutes lettres sur le mur du Bar en Vrac;
un gros bisou de la créatrice;
votre nom sur le mur du Bar en Vrac;

Un kit complet découverte du Bar à Vrac rempli de bons produits;

Votre aide est capitale pour Marseille et ses habitants fatigués de vivre dans un environnement où les déchets d'emballages font partie du paysage.Donnons leur des alternatives, ouvrons de nouvelles perspectives. Si un bar/épicerie sans embllages jetables ouvre et remporte le succès escompté, d'autres suivront.
Votre aide est capitale pour la Provence et la Méditerranée, d'une part parce bon nombre d'emballages jetés ici finissent à l'incinération, à l'enfouissement, ou à la mer. Enfin, j'ai le soutien de nombreux marseillais et marseillaises qui seront aussi mes premier-e-s client-e-s !

story:
Think we can lessen our impact on the environment by having more fun?  Then it’s time to learn about Operation Green Fun!

We are 20-somethings, 30, 40, and 50-somethings.  We are entrepreneurs and students.  We are men.  We are women.  We are from the east and from the west. We all have different skills and believe we can come together and make a difference by promoting environmentally friendly, fun products that need a little push to gain the traction needed to effect great positive change.  Our first focus:

What if there was a cup that was so cool and fun, that nobody would throw it away, and even if they no longer wanted it, could be recycled instead of trashed?  

What if you could easily play a part in reducing all this cup waste?

There is, and you can!  By participating in our campaign, you help give away thousands of reusable and 100% recyclable, handle-stacking cups to bars, restaurants, venues or organizations that use traditional throwaway cups to serve beverages.  For every 210 cups funded, we’ll ship a case of these fun, eco-friendly cups, to the top vote getter, free of charge!  Best of all, you get to help decide who receives them!  We’ll even reward you with prizes, including cups of your own! 


Where the Funds Go:

What You Get:

**For every $3 contributed without a reward claim, we'll add another cup to the donation pool**

The Impact:

If we reach or exceed our funding goal, for every 210 cups donated, we’ll put a case up for vote. Our funders will decide which bars, restaurants (or other venues that serves beverages) will receive them.  If we can distribute enough cases, and customers of the establishments who receive them, like the product, the consuming public will have an opportunity to reduce the number of disposable cups in our landfills by millions in the USA.

Links:

See the environmental impact potential here.
Case Study #1 - Central Park Festival
Case Study #2 - Coco Bar
Case Study #3 - SuperSports Park Stadium


Risks & Challenges:

No crowdfunding campaign is guaranteed to meet with success.  We simply don’t know how popular our idea will be, how much people will want to participate, and how much it will be shared. 

Who we are:

We are a team of about 30 people representing almost twenty different states. We have social media experts, graphic designers, PR pros, brand ambassadors on college campuses, and a management team with over 50 years of professional business experience on hand to guide us along. Want to see us?


Other Ways You Can Help:

Get more people to advocate using handle-stacking cups, here.

If you are seeking a fun college internship or know someone who is, we provide virtual internships. You may even be able to get college credit.  Click this link to signup up or feel free to pass it along to college students who might be interested

story:
The current climate crisis is urgent, but solutions to address it already exist: small-scale farmers can cool the planet as they feed the world. Contribute now to help us at Fair World Project spread this message of hope and promote critical work!

With your contributions, we’ll distribute a new image created by political artist, Favianna Rodriguez especially for this campaign and complete and distribute our short documentary, featuring Vandana Shiva and other food sovereignty luminaries, on how small-scale farmers can mitigate climate change through regenerative organic agriculture.

Fair World Project works to create a just economy that respects our environment and treats all people with dignity. This requires conscious production and conscious consumption. We believe education is the way to get there and are dedicated to spreading big ideas that support key projects in this endeavor.

Small-scale regenerative organic farming uses widely available and inexpensive methods. If we switched all agricultural practices to follow this model, greenhouse gas emissions that propel climate change could be significantly reduced and we could sequester 100% of current carbon dioxide emissions. But to do it, we need to stand with small farmers. To achieve a critical mass of support, we need to get the word out.

And this is where YOU come in. We commissioned renown artist and cultural organizer Favianna Rodriguez to create a beautiful work of art illustrating this message of hope. Favianna's art depicts the planet with naturally cleansing sunflower petals. It shows farmers opening their hands releasing seeds and the seeds turning into water. A community celebrates the farmers that can feed the world through regenerative organic growing methods represented through vegetables and fruits. Your contributions will allow us to spread this image widely with posters, t-shirts, and our own publication, For a Better World.

We are also creating a video, Small Farmers Cool the Planet, about small-scale farmers and their role in climate change, both their vulnerability if we do not act, and their potential to mitigate climate change if a critical mass will stand with them. Your contributions will allow us to complete production and share the video with the world. We’ve already conducted interviews with environmental and food sovereignty luminaries to be included; check out this clip of our chat with legendary food and justice activist Vandana Shiva: 


For even more info about organic regenerative agriculture, check out the web page we created with resources, info graphics, and opportunities to take action to transform our agricultural system to one that reverses rather than contributes to climate change.

What We Need & What You Get

Help us get the message out! Choose a giving level that gives you what you want. You can be among the first to get a t-shirt or poster with Favianna’s artwork or get some amazing products from fair brands working with small-scale sustainable producers who are leading the way to a new model of farming.

Our goal of $8,000 will allow us to complete our 5 minute documentary video and distribute it to the world through hundreds of grassroots events happening the first two weeks in May. It will allow us to use Favianna Rodriguez’s art on t-shirts, promotional materials, and our newsletter that will raise further funds and spread the campaign far and wide.

*Please note that perks can only be sent within the United States and territories. 

The Impact

Temperatures are warming, “unusual” weather events are becoming the norm, super storms are increasing in frequency, glaciers are melting, and crops as universal as coffee are in jeopardy. Even though we know we are in trouble, we are failing to take action and global greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions continue to rise as we are bombarded with false solutions such as technological fixes or corporate-led “climate smart” agriculture policies. Increasing use of technologies that are themselves carbon-intensive have brought about new problems such as global food shortages as food as diverted to fuel and increased environmental degradation due to fracking and other extractive technologies that are offered as “alternatives.” And the latest proposed agricultural policy solution, “climate smart” agriculture, is being led by corporations like Walmart and McDonalds who want credit for making their industrial practices just a little less worse.

Currently, our industrial food system accounts for 30-50% of global greenhouse gas emissions that propel climate change, with industrial agricultural activities accounting for as much as 15% alone. But if we switched all agricultural practices to follow the model of small-scale regenerative organic farming, GHG emissions could be significantly reduced, including sequestering 100% of current carbon dioxide emissions. This is fantastic news for planet earth and everyone on it!

Risks & Challenges

These regenerative organic management practices are widely available and inexpensive but their widespread use won’t happen automatically. We need to safeguard and invest in small-scale farmers through laws and policies, as well as pressure the marketplace to signal that these are the kinds of farms we want our food, fiber, and other agricultural goods to come from. That means we have to stand together.

Other Ways You Can Help

●  Please help us spread the word!

●  Use the Indiegogo share tools! Post and share far and wide!

●  Celebrate World Fair Trade Day on May 9th, 2015, and support ethical brands committed to working with small-scale producers.

Even though we know we are in trouble, we are failing to take action and global greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions continue to rise as we are bombarded with false solutions such as technological fixes or corporate-led “climate smart” agriculture policies. Increasing use of technologies that are themselves carbon-intensive have brought about new problems such as global food shortages as food as diverted to fuel and increased environmental degradation due to fracking and other extractive technologies that are offered as “alternatives.” And the latest proposed agricultural policy solution, “climate smart” agriculture, is being led by corporations like Walmart and McDonalds who want credit for making their industrial practices just a little less worse.
Currently, our industrial food system accounts for 30-50% of global greenhouse gas emissions that propel climate change, with industrial agricultural activities accounting for as much as 15% alone. But if we switched all agricultural practices to follow the model of small-scale regenerative organic farming, GHG emissions could be significantly reduced, including sequestering 100% of current carbon dioxide emissions. This is fantastic news for planet earth and everyone on it!   Risks & Challenges  
These regenerative organic management practices are widely available and inexpensive but their widespread use won’t happen automatically. We need to safeguard and invest in small-scale farmers through laws and policies, as well as pressure the marketplace to signal that these are the kinds of farms we want our food, fiber, and other agricultural goods to come from. That means we have to stand together.   Other Ways You Can Help 
●  Please help us spread the word!●  Use the Indiegogo share tools! Post and share far and wide!●  Celebrate World Fair Trade Day on May 9th, 2015, and support ethical brands committed to working with small-scale producers.

story:
The Yooper Honey Bee Project 2015

I moved here to the tip of the Upper Peninsula 13 years ago, my other half was going to MichiganTech to finish off her PhD in Computer science. When we arrived I couldn't believe how beautiful and lush everything was in the Upper Peninsula. I grew up in Minnesota the Land of 10,000 lakes, and even the Boundary Waters Canoe Area where I worked for several years with the DNR can not match the beauty of the U.P.

  As the years went by I learned they... no scratch that. "WE" don't say Upper Peninsula, we say U.P. or Yoopers.

"Say Hey to the U.P. Eh"

In the past five years I have noticed a sharp decline in the bee population, and because of this, I have also taken note and documented the decrease in fruit production and flowers.

I am not quite sure for certain if it is because the dramatic weather changes,
or because of the pesticides and GMO crops that farmers have been planting,
or the toxic clouds from the wood and coal mines and factories that creep down from Canada.

Honeybee's are very finicky and fragile creatures and are considered a keystone species because of their role in the environment . If the bees die, so do all sentient life. Because the bees are what keep the cycle of life going with their pollination of plants.

I am not a tree hugging hippie EPA nut. I just have a passion, to see the future of our planet continue.

I am reaching out to people who share my passion,
To see a project like this grow.

The goal.
*To build 100-200 hives made of untreated lumber and fastened together with sap and wood pegs, to be distributed in the state parks across the Upper Peninsula Michigan.
(With the permission from the DNR with the help of H. Russel from MSU to erect these stands in designated areas of the state forest to avoid human interaction. State Parks that are participating in this venture are ...
-Porcupine Mountains,
-Ottawa State Forest
-Nicolet State Forest
-Isle Royale
-Hiawatha State Forest )
*To monitor and document the health and population level of each hive.
*To monitor the environment around the hives in 5 mile increments.
*To sell the honey to use the monies for upkeep and travel expense to maintain, and to build more hives, and to pay the helpers.

This is a non-profit venture.

My passion is nature, I have no interest in making money off this personally, but there is the initial overhead.

What We Need & What You Get

We need wood, wood and more wood. To build these hives. Also fuel to transport each of these to locations in a 250 mile diameter. Since we cant exactly ask for wood on here, we are asking for monies to purchase wood.

The rest you can see on the side.

The Impact

With GMO Companies trying to change the way crops are farmed just so they can patent seeds and make more money, and the use of some very toxic pesticides and herbicides the bees are dying off at an alarming rate. There is also a new disorder amongst bee colonies that causes the queen bee to literally suicide herself leaving the rest of the bees with out a matron or direction and eventually dying.

By contributing you will be helping the future of bees.


Other Ways You Can Help

You can help by spreading the word of this project. The more people know about it. The faster this project will grow.

The idea is to keep the bee population healthy and abundant so crops and plant life are lush and beautiful.

Please help.

By raising the extra monies, More hives can be supplied to private land owners wanting to bee keep.

(added Sept.23:) Represent Perk

story:
If you don't see the PayPal link you can find it right here. 

You've seen us in action before: Cambodia's Virachey National Park, Thailand's Khlong Saeng Wildlife Sanctuary, and now Sumatra's Hadabuan Hills in North Sumatra province. I paid to have the memory cards changed in the cameras back in September out of pocket (see the tiger and bear pics sprinkled throughout this fundraiser) and the results were beyond my expectation. However, I can't bite the bullet and pay the whole shebang again myself, so I'm looking for any assistance I can get. Any donation helps!

story:
What's this all about?

The community blockade of the Metagasco gasfield project at Bentley, has quickly become one of the most significant social movements in Australia.  Bentley has a permanent protectors camp on private property that is full of average Australians, grandparents, children, farmers and other people from all different walks of life. We're not protesters we're protectors. A slight, but massive, paradigm shift. With a sudden surge the camp has grown from dozens to hundreds and at times thousands of people. The need for electricity grows exponentially. A large diesel generator was hired to meet the needs. As soon as possible we want to replace the noisy, smelly fossil fuel burner with a sustainable solar system. We feel we need to walk the talk and show the world an alternative exists. Camp needs power for recharging radios and phones, computers, evening lighting, and refrigeration. Rainbow Power Company (RPC) has designed a stand alone solar system to handle these requirements.

Northern Rivers Guardians Inc. (NRG) is donating $250 to help build this system which will fit in a trailer for use at Bentley and will be later available for other similar projects.

Your contribution will help us make this dream a reality.

What is the Bentley blockade all about?

Coal Seam Gas (CSG) and other forms of unconventional gas mining and the use of hydraulic fracking threatens so much; the land, the air, the water, the people and the health of all living things that require clean elements for survival. We believe that every single gas well (and there can be thousands of them in a relatively small area) contaminates the environment. Recently NSW EPA fined a company drilling in the nearby Pilliga State Forest for contaminating an underground water aquifer with uranium, lead and arsenic. From the gasfield horror in the USA to the town of Tara in Southern Queensland in Australia, the impacts are very real indeed, devastating almost every other existing industry.

The community has tried everything, from lobbying local politicians at all forms and levels of government. Northern Rivers area has been surveyed door to door with an overwhelming result in most areas being between 90 to 100% against gasfield development. 87% voted no to CSG at the local referendum in Lismore. All that is left to us is to put our bodies on the line in non violent direct action.

Our Goal and what we need:

To Raise $11,000 for a portable medium sized solar system so we can cover our electrical power needs.


 We don't want to be pumping fumes into the atmosphere and chucking dollars at petrol stations.


 By supporting renewables at Bentley  you will help us show the world that we can "walk the talk" and don't need to use fossil fuel to oppose a gas field.


For more Info:

Find us on Facebook https://www.facebook.com/renewables4bentley

Northern Rivers Guardians https://www.facebook.com/groups/286399414727653/

NRG web site to info list http://northernriversguardians.org/

For more information about Unconventional Mining in Northern NSW 

 http://gasfieldfreenorthernrivers.org 

To find out how to Lock the Gate from CSG in your Community 

http://www.lockthegate.org.au 

Thank You!

story:
Un objetivo común

¡ Consigamos 4,000 euros para que Rainfer sobreviva este invierno!

Somos la Plataforma La Tortura No Es Cultura (LTNEC) que reúne a 38 organizaciones de protección animal y queremos hacer un llamamiento para ayudar en un caso desesperado.

El mayor centro de primates en España, Rainfer, situado en Madrid y resultado de 20 años de sacrificio rescatando estos animales de terribles situaciones de maltrato, abandono, tráfico ilegal y circos, está al borde del cierre por falta de fondos.

El Estado cobra importantes cantidades en multas cada vez que rescatan un animal, de dinero en multas, no aporta nada para su alimentación y mantenimiento. 

Durante 20 años, la familia que creó Rainfer se ha dejado la vida y el patrimonio familiar por estos animales de los que tanto nos hemos aprovechado los humanos. 

Como consecuencia de la crisis, se encuentran ahora en una situación desesperada. El Estado sólo les ofrece una solución: el sacrificio.  Sin embargo dedica más de 600 millones de euros al año a la tauromaquia. 

No lo permitamos: 

Consigamos entre todos que Rainfer pueda sobrevivir al invierno
Entre todos, podemos conseguir que los lemures, chimpancés y Boris, el orangután puedan seguir olvidando los maltratos de su pasado y que Rainfer no cierre este invierno.

Proponemos varias acciones para ayudarles.

  • Participa en esta campaña Indiegogo #SOSRainfer Centro de Primates. El centro necesita 4.000 euros mensuales en calefacción para proteger a los animales del invierno. Aportemos esa cantidad para el mes más frío del año. Difunde esta campaña en tus redes sociales, mensajería instantánea y mails a tus conocidos y amigos.

  • Firma esta Petición Change para que los políticos se movilicen y difúndela.
  • Apadrina un primate, hazte voluntari@ y/o haz una donación aquí. 
  • Apúntate al Teaming de Rainfer, aportando solo 1€/mes ayudarás con otras personas al mantenimiento y alimentación de los animales. Difúndelo. 
Gracias a todos y todas. Juntos lograremos que todos los habitantes de centro sigan disfrutando de la segunda oportunidad que Rainfer les ha dado.

story:
Short Summary

The main goal of the first Greening Villages Project is to support a social agricultural cooperative which works on Italian land confiscated from the mafia, by providing this community with a renewable energy installation. It's a win-win situation! By supporting our project, you will be contributing to fostering a model that can help villages in the world become more environmentally and economically sustainable. We would sincerely appreciate your support and reward you with quality organic-products from the social cooperative in Southern Italy. If our first project succeeds, it will pave the way for future projects. We are not lacking in enthusiasm or ideas. We just need support to realize our goals.

Greening Villages is a young and ambitious start-up, focused on providing the comprehensive needs of agricultural cooperatives and farms in the full range of energy production and consumption, as well as community forest management. Greening Villages will be able to offer an “ad hoc” solution to every client in order to reach the highest possible level of energy efficiency and economic and social development. Our company is promoting a new business trend that incorporates a strong social element. Our work has the goal to develop itself in two very close business areas - ecopreneurship and social entrepreneurship. For more information, please visit our website www.greeningvillages.com.

A Special Thank You 

A special THANK YOU to United Rebels Production for being with us all along the way supporting us in all technical, video and design aspects of the campaign preparation. The production company is specialized in music and environmental videos and has produced short independent movies. We invite you to visit their website or Facebook Page and see the diverse range of services the company offers.

What We Need & What You Get

The cooperation between “Greening Villages” and the agricultural cooperative “Cooperativa Sociale Terre di Puglia – Libera Terra” will contribute to achieving several significant benefits. To learn more about the social Cooperative, please visit their website www.hisotelaray.it. The main portion of the “greening villages” project is the installation of solar panels on the roof of a warehouse. The warehouse will be built to store agricultural tools while the roof will be used as a firm surface for installing solar panels. An additional benefit is that no valuable agricultural land will be used for the solar panel installation. Through the solar panel installation, the agricultural cooperative will be supplied with more electricity for its needs, which can also boost the production of organic agricultural products. Moreover, the surplus of produced electrical energy can be sold to the national smart grid, and generate additional income. In this way, the Cooperative will be able to offer more job positions thanks to the production boost, which in turn will increase activities combating the social structures built by the Mafia in the area. 

Fund raising

Our campaign goal is to raise 77.000 $ in order to be able to complete the first phase of our project which consists of building a warehouse.

If we reach the amount of 116.000 $, we are going to be able to build the warehouse including buying all the materials for the solar modules installation, as well as the modules themselves.

If we reach the amount of 155.000 $, we are going to be able to build the warehouse, buy the necessary materials, install the modules on the roof of the warehouse and conduct social research covering all the costs through your support.

If these goals are not reached, it will be necessary for us to find other funding resources (such as EU funds or Italian funding resources). Otherwise, it will be necessary to use conventional financial institutions. In the latter case, the Cooperative would need to spend the money earned through the solar technology to pay back the credit, and money could be better spent to fight mafia rather than loan payments.

We definitely need your support, but we would also like to show sincere gratitude for your interest, time and support. That is why we have prepared various organic products from the social cooperative as small rewards for your valuable support. 

If we don’t reach our funding goal, all the money raised will be saved until the next crowd funding campaign, or until another funding resource (such as EU regional funds etc.) is provided. We are aware that our project is complex and consists of many phases for which funds have to be raised. However, we don’t lack motivation and patience to complete it by combining different funding strategies. 

Rewards

*Due to customs regulations of the respective destination country, the perks include an alcoholic and non-alcoholic product. If the regulations in your country forbid alcohol shipping, then you will get the other products specified in the perk descriptions as substitute for the bottle(s) of wine.

Other ways you can help

One of the messages that should come across through the work of Greening Villages is that every individual can make a change regardless of his or her social status or income. If for any reason, you are not able to support our project through the donation of a small amount, but are nonetheless are fascinated or inspired by it, or believe in our cause and share our concerns, then we would like to know about it. Every type of support is welcomed and appreciated. Write us an e-mail or visit the section Partners on our website. Give us proposal ideas for future projects and partners.

We would especially appreciate your support regarding spreading the word about our project. Every potential interested friend, colleague or member of your network can be very valuable for us. Financial support is one way to help but we are also very concerned with spreading the message. Namely, that in some areas of the world, certain social problems such as Mafia really exist and the most efficient means to defeat them is via publicity and not turning your head in the other direction. Spreading the word is made simple through the Indiegogo share tools.

Thank you very much in advance! We cannot describe you how much we appreciate your support because this project is much more than it looks. It contains ideas, dreams, a year and a half hard-work, and numerous good intentions which will result in various benefits in the long run. Thank you for being responsible Earthlings like us!

The Impact

The project should bring a better future for the agricultural cooperative and the people living in the village of San Pietro Vernotico in a social, economic and environmental context. One of the goals is to provide finances for renovating the villa of an ex mafia boss, which is now given for use by the Cooperative. The Cooperative plans to renovate the villa and convert it to a place where different events with educational initiatives take place. That way a positive sign will be given to the people of the community. The point is to strengthen the community’s cohesion and trust, reduce the fear of the mafia that many people living in the community still have, as well as to raise awareness about environmental issues. By enhancing the demand for organic products and showing the benefits from solar energy, the project will achieve its main goal – showing everyone that eco-friendly practices can be socially beneficial and profitable.   

The goal of our project is to improve environmental, social and economic conditions and the general quality of life and living in San Pietro Vernotico. We chose the challenging rural community of San Pietro Vernotico to implement our projects and create a change.

An innovative element introduced by “Greening Villages” is the funding concept, as well as the social research following the technology installation.

We know that agricultural cooperatives in disadvantaged regions don’t have enough funds to invest in renewable energies, or for tackling the social problems which affect the area they are settled in. One method to support them is by providing financing from different resources such as from international organizations, corporate sponsorships, and crowd funding. Each of our projects is tailor-made for the needs of the target community, based on in-depth analysis and site visits.

Moreover, an analysis that incorporates environmental, social and economic aspects follows the project implementation. After installation of the solar panels, Greening Villages will conduct qualitative research study to investigate how this change has affected the community. The research will focus on the community’s perception about the Cooperative, the community’s relationship with the Mafia, and the community’s relationship with the Cooperative itself. Greening Villages will then be able to provide the Cooperative with ideas on how to use their earnings from the resale of their energy. The use of this income must be reinvested to enhance social and economic development in benefit of the local community. This is mandated not only by the Cooperative’s statute, but also by Italian law. Our focus is on offering jobs related to the solar panels, while also attempting to solve the difficulties the Cooperative faces concerning social acceptance within the community.

The Mafia has been using agriculture as a way to offer jobs, as well as to control people. Next to raising awareness, confiscation is a very efficient method to defeat criminal organizations, as well as the reusing of the land for socially beneficial projects. Regarding raising awareness, “Libera Terra” organizes international community service work camps annually. As a result, volunteers have the chance to experience and directly support a daily, non-violent fight against the Mafia. Our installation is implemented to help the Cooperative in its fight against the criminal organizations and their social consequences on the territory.

By implementing the project, we create a basis for the community for further improvement. One of our goals is to show them that change can happen if the effort and motivation exist, even if one doesn’t possess the funds. We don’t only provide communities with technology, but we also inspire and enable them!

The ‘Greening Villages’ start up is managing the San Pietro Vernotico project for the agricultural cooperative “Cooperativa Sociale Terre di Puglia – Libera Terra”. The crowd funding money will be directly deposited into the account of the Social Cooperative.

The Project ‘San Pietro Vernotico’ is the first “Greening Villages” project that should pave the way for further projects of this kind. Its success is decisive for further projects. By supporting this project, you are supporting an innovative idea that gradually can lead to making numerous villages worldwide greener.

Fund raising







Our campaign goal is to raise 77.000 $ in order to be able to complete the first phase of our project which consists of building a warehouse.



If we reach the amount of 116.000 $, we are going to be able to build the warehouse including buying all the materials for the solar modules installation, as well as the modules themselves.
If we reach the amount of 155.000 $, we are going to be able to build the warehouse, buy the necessary materials, install the modules on the roof of the warehouse and conduct social research covering all the costs through your support.
If these goals are not reached, it will be necessary for us to find other funding resources (such as EU funds or Italian funding resources). Otherwise, it will be necessary to use conventional financial institutions. In the latter case, the Cooperative would need to spend the money earned through the solar technology to pay back the credit, and money could be better spent to fight mafia rather than loan payments.
We definitely need your support, but we would also like to show sincere gratitude for your interest, time and support. That is why we have prepared various organic products from the social cooperative as small rewards for your valuable support. 
If we don’t reach our funding goal, all the money raised will be saved until the next crowd funding campaign, or until another funding resource (such as EU regional funds etc.) is provided. We are aware that our project is complex and consists of many phases for which funds have to be raised. However, we don’t lack motivation and patience to complete it by combining different funding strategies. 
Rewards
*Due to customs regulations of the respective destination country, the perks include an alcoholic and non-alcoholic product. If the regulations in your country forbid alcohol shipping, then you will get the other products specified in the perk descriptions as substitute for the bottle(s) of wine.
Other ways you can help
One of the messages that should come across through the work of Greening Villages is that every individual can make a change regardless of his or her social status or income. If for any reason, you are not able to support our project through the donation of a small amount, but are nonetheless are fascinated or inspired by it, or believe in our cause and share our concerns, then we would like to know about it. Every type of support is welcomed and appreciated. Write us an e-mail or visit the section Partners on our website. Give us proposal ideas for future projects and partners.
We would especially appreciate your support regarding spreading the word about our project. Every potential interested friend, colleague or member of your network can be very valuable for us. Financial support is one way to help but we are also very concerned with spreading the message. Namely, that in some areas of the world, certain social problems such as Mafia really exist and the most efficient means to defeat them is via publicity and not turning your head in the other direction. Spreading the word is made simple through the Indiegogo share tools.
Thank you very much in advance! We cannot describe you how much we appreciate your support because this project is much more than it looks. It contains ideas, dreams, a year and a half hard-work, and numerous good intentions which will result in various benefits in the long run. Thank you for being responsible Earthlings like us!
The Impact
The project should bring a better future for the agricultural cooperative and the people living in the village of San Pietro Vernotico in a social, economic and environmental context. One of the goals is to provide finances for renovating the villa of an ex mafia boss, which is now given for use by the Cooperative. The Cooperative plans to renovate the villa and convert it to a place where different events with educational initiatives take place. That way a positive sign will be given to the people of the community. The point is to strengthen the community’s cohesion and trust, reduce the fear of the mafia that many people living in the community still have, as well as to raise awareness about environmental issues. By enhancing the demand for organic products and showing the benefits from solar energy, the project will achieve its main goal – showing everyone that eco-friendly practices can be socially beneficial and profitable.   
The goal of our project is to improve environmental, social and economic conditions and the general quality of life and living in San Pietro Vernotico. We chose the challenging rural community of San Pietro Vernotico to implement our projects and create a change.
An innovative element introduced by “Greening Villages” is the funding concept, as well as the social research following the technology installation.
We know that agricultural cooperatives in disadvantaged regions don’t have enough funds to invest in renewable energies, or for tackling the social problems which affect the area they are settled in. One method to support them is by providing financing from different resources such as from international organizations, corporate sponsorships, and crowd funding. Each of our projects is tailor-made for the needs of the target community, based on in-depth analysis and site visits.
Moreover, an analysis that incorporates environmental, social and economic aspects follows the project implementation. After installation of the solar panels, Greening Villages will conduct qualitative research study to investigate how this change has affected the community. The research will focus on the community’s perception about the Cooperative, the community’s relationship with the Mafia, and the community’s relationship with the Cooperative itself. Greening Villages will then be able to provide the Cooperative with ideas on how to use their earnings from the resale of their energy. The use of this income must be reinvested to enhance social and economic development in benefit of the local community. This is mandated not only by the Cooperative’s statute, but also by Italian law. Our focus is on offering jobs related to the solar panels, while also attempting to solve the difficulties the Cooperative faces concerning social acceptance within the community.
The Mafia has been using agriculture as a way to offer jobs, as well as to control people. Next to raising awareness, confiscation is a very efficient method to defeat criminal organizations, as well as the reusing of the land for socially beneficial projects. Regarding raising awareness, “Libera Terra” organizes international community service work camps annually. As a result, volunteers have the chance to experience and directly support a daily, non-violent fight against the Mafia. Our installation is implemented to help the Cooperative in its fight against the criminal organizations and their social consequences on the territory.
By implementing the project, we create a basis for the community for further improvement. One of our goals is to show them that change can happen if the effort and motivation exist, even if one doesn’t possess the funds. We don’t only provide communities with technology, but we also inspire and enable them!
The ‘Greening Villages’ start up is managing the San Pietro Vernotico project for the agricultural cooperative “Cooperativa Sociale Terre di Puglia – Libera Terra”. The crowd funding money will be directly deposited into the account of the Social Cooperative.
The Project ‘San Pietro Vernotico’ is the first “Greening Villages” project that should pave the way for further projects of this kind. Its success is decisive for further projects. By supporting this project, you are supporting an innovative idea that gradually can lead to making numerous villages worldwide greener.

story:
*** Check-out the 'Updates' tab above to see progress ***

Project Summary

In today’s age of global warming, where the temperature in the tropics is reaching extremes in various seasons, I am constantly reminded of our responsibility towards preserving nature for our own comfortable living and for the future. Hence, starting this rainy season (July 2014), we are launching a project to plant and maintain indigenous trees in open spaces around the BHEL Township in Hyderabad.

Context

The United Nations Food & Agriculture organization estimates that about 13 million hectares of forests disappear each year due to human activity[1] (read: deforestation). In India alone, the annual deforestation rate is estimated to be 294 thousand hectares[2], which translates to 1,130 football fields of loss of tree-cover every day.

For most of us, this is just a statistic. But on a more conscious assessment, many of us have a tangible memory of seeing the reduction in tree cover around us. Booming real-estate prices have transformed land into an expensive commodity, ensuring use of every inch of available space for construction and not leaving place for any trees to grow. Speculators have bought land that was earlier under cultivation, and either constructed buildings or left them barren. In the past 25 years, BHEL, a small township of 2,000 households which was surrounded by dense forest and green farm lands is now completely destroyed by the sprawling city of Hyderabad. There is now a concrete jungle all around that township along with a population increase of few hundred thousand.

** Map showing densely built-up area around BHEL township

Thankfully, the township itself belongs to a public-sector industry, Bharat Heavy Electricals Limited (BHEL), and still houses less than 2,000 households, retaining much of the greenery that existed many years ago. One can clearly experience the impact of having the greenery as one enters or exits the township on a summer day; the ambient temperature just inside the boundary is 3 to 4 degrees cooler than just 100 feet outside the township.

** Pictures indicating the contrast in landscape within just 100 ft. distance

[1] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deforestation#Rates_of_deforestation

[2] http://www.currentscience.ac.in/Volumes/105/11/1492.pdf


Project Objectives

Every rainy season, governments across the country undertake mass plantation of saplings but the survival rates are near zero. Without any arrangements for maintenance and care of the saplings, or for local community engagement in the effort, such exercises become mere rituals to satisfy statutory needs rather than create true greenery.

Hence, the current campaign is not designed for mass plantation but will focus on planting and providing care for a few hundred indigenous trees. Depending on the type of tree, it may take anywhere between 3 and 10 years of support before the trees are able to grow by themselves. While doing so, the campaign aims for the following ancillary activities that shall enrich the exercise:

  • Undertake solid-waste management by way of composting bio-degradable waste from households and vegetable markets in the surroundings of where these saplings are planted.
  • Provide necessary information and assistance for those households interested in undertaking composting within their own plots.
  • Engage in rain-water harvesting to improve the ground-water level, thus possibly reducing the need to transport water for the trees at times of low/no rainfall.
  • Encourage community participation, primarily that of children and youth, providing an opportunity to learn and create a connect with nature, so that they may take up similar activities independently, to create scale.
  • Conduct events and competitions to provide opportunity see, learn and showcase/share stories of individual achievements in reducing waste.


What Kind of Trees Will be Planted?

As mentioned earlier, only indigenous trees of at least 25 different varieties shall be planted during the months of July – September 2014. A variety of plants will be chosen which will have varying growth rates. About 20% - 30% of the trees will be of edible fruit-bearing varieties so that the harvesting season becomes a means of observation, learning and celebration for the people involved. Most other trees have medicinal value. Almost all of them grow into large trees and provide shade under them. Below are a few trees that grow in this area.

** Indigenous tree varieties from this area (clockwise from top left: Gulmohar,  Jack Fruit, Rain Tree, Neem, Peepal, Eucalyptus, Tamarind, Black Plum, Cluster Fig, Copper Pod, Neem Chameli)


Where & When?

Except for a few fruit bearing trees, most others, hopefully will grow into large canopies that provide shade and beauty to the surroundings. Typically, about 70 to 100 trees can occupy an acre of open space. Thus, the 800 saplings that will be planted as part of this campaign are expected to spread over 10 acres of open land. However, as mentioned earlier, the township and its surrounding areas already retain some greenery. Hence, the open spaces are not contiguous. Some spaces are just enough for ten saplings while others are large enough for fifty trees to be planted. Hence, these saplings will be spread in multiple nearby locations in and around BHEL Township in Hyderabad.

** Open lands spread with debris, dirt and asthma causing weed

The ground work on the project will start shortly after the first monsoon rains, which typically arrive mid-June. Planting of saplings will continue from the month of July through September. Starting October 2014, an outreach exercise will be initiated with the local households to segregate their household waste such that the boo-degradable kitchen waste shall be composted in pits around the saplings. This will reduce the solid-waste generated from households which otherwise gets dumped in open landfills, while at the same time making the soil fertile and assisting in better plant growth. This entire process is expected to be streamlined by March 2015 and will continue for at least 5 years by when the trees will grow enough, needing very little support.

The current fund-raising effort is only towards the cost of managing the program for a period of 12 months. After the first year, the resource requirement for caring for the plants will be much lower. Attempts will be made to raise small funds locally or to get households to adopt some plants to continue the program for future years. Further outreach exercise will be undertaken to motivate neighborhood to replicate this model into newer areas to achieve scale.


Putting the Funds to Good Use:

The current campaign aims to raise $16,000 towards the costs of managing the program for one full year. These funds will be applied towards:

  1. Procuring saplings from local nurseries.
  2. Employing four to five daily workers for clearing the debris, preparing the pits, planting saplings, watering them, creating enclosures to secure them from animals, collecting degradable waste, composting, etc.
  3. Watering of plants. For the most part, water needed for the saplings will be collected from the houses nearby. However, this may not be possible for all the plants, and also during the summer months when the water is scarce.
  4. Creating temporary fences made of bamboo and cloth to protect them from animals. Some of these may need replacement over the period of the year.
  5. Purchase of tools for earthwork and also for a push-cart for collecting waste for composting.
The funds raised from this Indiegogo campaign will not be used for any administrative expenditure or for creation of any fixed infrastructure. The campaign managers shall contribute $150 - $200 per month for the one year period towards administrative expenditure (accounting, communication, transport, documentation, etc.), apart from our time supervising the work and participating in physical labor. Hence, as a contributor to this project, you can be assured that every dollar donated by you is used to create a better environment, while also generating employment for the underprivileged.

What if we are Over-funded?

The project is fully flexible and scalable. The extra money can help us in venturing into other aspects of sustainable living such as:

  • Growing organic vegetables in the spaces in between the large trees.
  • Running education programs for children to enable to learn about various plants and their growth patterns.

However, given that the first years present the maximum challenge in survival of the trees, we would like to limit the maximum funding under this campaign to $32,000.


People Behind the Purpose

Prashanth Bachu and Lini Bachu are a couple that hold sustainable living close to their heart. Prashanth works for a non-profit organization working towards improving public-transportation as a means of affecting climate change by reducing traffic congestion, pollution and accidents. His work has resulted in better public transport facilities for more than 200,000 urban commuters across India. In his earlier roles, he also worked as a mentor for college students in a program imparting human values. Lini on the other hand has a Ph.D in Computer Science and teaches at a nearby university as guest faculty. She has been actively involved in household waste composting, and kitchen gardening for quite some time. With a sense of responsibility, both of them now intend to take their efforts beyond their own house, to create a greener tomorrow. (https://www.facebook.com/prashanth.bachu.7/posts/10152195389562800?notif_t=like)

Other Ways You Can Help

While the express purpose of this campaign is to raise funds for the project, we hope that it will also inspire many others to take the first steps within their own homes. Please share the word with your family, friends and colleagues.

story:
I live on a croft in a remote highland  Glen. I am surrounded by astounding beauty, heather and wildflowers. The rich variety of forests surround my home, and yet, we do not have enough honey bees.  How long before I see this beauty start to decline.

Currently I own three healthy bee hives, but I wish desperately to expand. I have 30 acres of mixed land I can use but just need the hives to put on it. I hope to get as many hives as I can. I am a stay at home mum, working on my croft with my animals and bees. I can do this.

I have already made my own nucs to expand my own hives next spring, but cannot afford the extra hives and bees to go in them. 

This money raised will purchase hives and bees, and some extra simple equipment, as I have all the basics. I shallleave the majority of the honey on the bees to get them through the winters only taking the bare amount from them to fund my project.

I am passionate about bees, and obsessed with beekeeping, as any beekeeper will know, it gets you that way.

Thank you in advance for any help given. I shall be keeping a blog on my progress.

Highlandcroft.blogspot.co.uk

story:
Imagine wanting to paint your personal space as a reflection of who you are...

Now imagine Easy Color Express: Instead of choosing paint from a printed paint chip that is two to four inches wide, you:


Help save our environment ….

Order paint the earth-friendly way!

The harmful effects of the printed paint chip industry (PPCI)



Perks            

                      

                 

                 

                 

                 

                 

                  

                 

                


                

  

Working with Interior Designers


Let's Get Easy Color Express Off to a Great Start!

We have an extensive online museum of collectible memorabilia showing the history of paint and paint companies in the U.S.  A selection of these items will be perks in this campaign. 


The Impact


                              


Risks and challenges

Risks: There are always unknowns when starting a new business and service. If something unforeseen occurs, we will do our best to rectify it as soon as possible.

Challenges: Because we are located in the Atlanta, Georgia area, we are only able to offer the in-home consultation service in the Atlanta area. Our plan is to open franchises all over the U.S. as interest increases.


Other ways you can help

We realize you may be unable to contribute financially, but that does not mean that you cannot help. Please spread the word about this campaign to everyone you know. Share with your network on Facebook, Twitter, and other social media venues. Let them know that if they live in the Atlanta area, they can now have

an efficient and accurate system by which they will be better able to choose the right paint color paint for their environment. Thank you so much for your support in this campaign!

story:
What is the future you are creating?

 

Imagine a future where our current dirty fossil fuel system is completely replaced, from the drilling and mining, to the spilling freighters and exploding pipelines, to the utility companies burning the coal and oil for power while raising rates every year. In their place our communities purchase all the power they need from clean and local sources, creating local jobs, bringing hundreds of millions of dollars back into the community while giving us stable power costs and stopping climate change.

 

Our current energy system is like the computer at your desk, large boxes located centrally. We built massive power plants centrally located and stringing power lines all over the country in a giant spider web connecting our communities. New technology, much like smartphones and tablets, have allowed our computers to leave the desk and go with us wherever we are. New clean power technology is similar in that it can be “distributed” throughout the community, on rooftops, parking garages and unused land all around us. This allows us to rid ourselves of the obsolete dirty energy model.

 

 

By contributing you can help to build a future of independent communities with clean power, local jobs and economic growth, and also generate tax revenues for essential services. By proving this local power model can work, we can replicate it in communities across the United States and around the world.

We built massive power plants centrally located and stringing power lines all over the country in a giant spider web connecting our communities. New technology, much like smartphones and tablets, have allowed our computers to leave the desk and go with us wherever we are. New clean power technology is similar in that it can be “distributed” throughout the community, on rooftops, parking garages and unused land all around us. This allows us to rid ourselves of the obsolete dirty energy model. 
 
 
By contributing you can help to build a future of independent communities with clean power, local jobs and economic growth, and also generate tax revenues for essential services. By proving this local power model can work, we can replicate it in communities across the United States and around the world.

story:
*English Below*

Samedi, le 7 septembre aura lieu l'édition Montréalaise du "D.I.Y. Try-Athlon"

Il s'agit d'une course "do-it-yourself", ce qui veut dire que l'itinéraire est tracé sur google map et l'heure de départ est énoncé, c'est tout! Après, les gens sont à peu près libre de le faire comme ils l'entendent! Pas d'inscription, pas de commanditaire. Tout le monde peut y participer!

LE PARCOURS

Puisque nous allons mettre beaucoup d'efforts à faire ce triathlon, nous demandons à nos ami(e)s de nous soutenir en contribuant à une collecte de fonds pour une bonne cause. Cette année, nous allons soutenir deux projets d'agriculture urbaine: Un collectif d'apiculture et d'un jardin communautaire. 

Tout l'argent recueilli ira à développer c'est deux initiatives pour les rendres encore plus accessibles à la communauté.

Les Abeilles des Possibles

GreenPeas, potager communautaire et éducatif

 

*Évènement Facebook* (Envoye, participe... T'es capable)


-------

On Saturday, September 7th the Montreal edition of the D.I.Y Try-Athlon will take place. 

This is a "do-it-yourself" race, which means that I've traced out the route on google map, set out start time and folks are pretty much free to do it how they see fit! No registration, no corporate sponsor. Anyone can participate!

THE ROUTE

Since we're going to be putting lots of effort in doing this thing, I figured we can ask folks to support us by pitching in some cash for a worthy cause. This year we are fundraising for two small agriculture projects, an urban beehive collective and a community garden. 

All funds will go to further develop the community outreach aspects of these projects and help establish them further next year.

 The Newbees

GreenPeas educational community garden

*Facebook Event* (you know you want to participate)
