story:
About Me
Three years ago I landed in Bangkok, tired from a really long flight from Canada, worried about how I was going to get out of the airport with all my baggage/field equipment, and feeling very aware of the fact that I was completely alone on the other side of the world. Armed with some research equipment, a video camera, and a solid pair of hiking boots, I had arrived in Thailand to begin my PhD research and was moving into the jungle to study primates at UNESCO World Heritage Site, Khao Yai National Park. It was the start of my biggest adventure to date.

The for next two years I would live with Thai locals as the only foreign researcher in one of Thailand’s largest, and most celebrated, protected rainforests. And relying only on the kindness of strangers, I had to learn the local language fast and figure out how things worked to make new friends in order to survive so far away from
home.

I documented my journey in this blog (www.prime-jm.blogspot.com) for my friends and family to read, but soon the blog grew into a more meaningful enterprise. An audience was building of students and interested readers looking to learn more about the animals I study, my relationships with the Thai locals in a foreign culture, and my experiences with nature.


In a nutshell: it was the best experience of my life and I'm so thankful so
many people were interested to hear about my adventures!!

When I finished my research and returned home from Thailand at the end of 2011, I knew things couldn’t end there. I had to do more. More people need experiences like mine to gain perspective of themselves and find their place in the world; more
opportunities needed to be available for young adults to experience other ways
of life and consider the essential interrelatedness of humans and nature. And
most importantly, I had to find a way to give back to the local communities and
people who, though they had very little themselves to give, enriched my life and
shared with me all that they had, taking care of me while I lived so very far
away from home for so long.

And so, I initiated the Jackie Prime Project (www.jackieprime.org).

The Project
The main purpose of the Jackie Prime Project is to create opportunities for young adults to experience other cultures and live in nature, developing their skills of compassion, self-value/confidence and empathy, and to educate people about the interconnectedness of humans and nature.

With the help of a few of my friends and dedicated student volunteers, I have created an enthusiastic group of peers to help me build my vision and share it with others. We believe that knowledge of the connections between humans and nature through active participation in the world fosters harmony, empathy for others, and globally responsible individuals.

We're still a small group, but with your support we can create opportunities for other
students to venture outside the classroom and experience the world first hand in
a fun, safe, and educational way.

The purpose of this fundraising campaign is to help us raise funds to initiate our prospective core programs:

The Core Programs:

  • provide a public platform for students in anthropological, biological, environmental studies/work to showcase their work on our website
  • create a mentorship network to mediate opportunities for high school and undergraduate students to connect with graduate students in their prospective area of interest and gain hands on fieldwork experience for future careers/higher education
  • promote activities that teach global responsibility through experiential education trips abroad 
  • provide educational materials, resources and supplies to underprivileged youth living in rural Thailand in the Nakon Ratchasima Province of North-Eastern Thailand where Khao Yai is located
  • produce educational videos that highlight ongoing JPP activities and humanitarian work, showcase current academic fieldwork by graduate students and professors around the globe, and detail conservation and environmental topics to keep viewers informed

 We need money to:

  • continue to build and maintain an interactive website for our project
  • cover printing and translation costs for posters we made to educate park visitors and staff about the dangers of human-wildlife contact, promoting appropriate activities for nature appreciation  (e.g.: Don’t feed the monkeys, put garbage in provided dispensers, etc.)
  • cover distribution costs for our humanitarian efforts to provide clothing and school supplies to young kids living in the Khao Yai area
  • purchase additional video equipment to produce our educational videos
  • cover travel expenses for our volunteer staff trial-expedition before opening these trips to the general public through our website

Your contribution would allow us cover the production costs for developing our initiatives, permitting us to develop a strong organization of volunteers
working to create opportunities for high school and undergraduate students, and help underprivileged kids in rural Thailand go to school with the right
equipment to get the most out of their education.

story:
---für deutsche Version siehe unten ---

---di bawah adalah versi Bahasa Indonesia---

Our Story

We are four friends from Germany and Indonesia and founders of the environmental initiative Making Oceans Plastic Free. We are passionate about the conservation of our oceans and it is our aim to preserve this gift to pass on to the next generations.

The Team

We developed Tasini inspired by our different backgrounds. Roger studying ways to reduce plastic bag use in a PhD research project; Pari holding a degree in Biology and researching Indonesian society as a cultural anthropologist; Adith consulting government and businesses on cleaner production; and Lia designing fun and creative products.

Indonesia - the world’s second largest source of marine plastic pollution

With a focus on Indonesia - the world’s second largest source of marine plastic pollution - we can make a real difference. But we believe that changing behavior around the world works best when it’s easy and fun. This has been our inspiration to create Tasini.

Tasini Features - "Special Agents"

Our Aim

With our own funds we have produced the first 1000 Tasini. Now we need your support to achieve our 3 main goals:

1. Launch a big environmental awareness campaign in Indonesia:

The likeable Tasini marine animals are the right environmental ambassadors to raise awareness about plastic bag pollution. With your funding we can create a big media campaign raising environmental awareness in Indonesia.

2. Produce Tasini Bags from recycled plastic waste (PET):

Fabrics from recycled PET are not yet common in Indonesia. To produce the fabrics, large quantities need to be ordered. With your funding we will be able to fill the minimum order quantity and start using recycled plastic waste for our Tasini bags.

3. Making Tasini affordable to everyone:

The more people we reach, the greater our impact to reduce plastic bag use. This is why we want to keep the price for Tasini as low as possible. With your funding, we can reduce costs for production while securing ethical and sustainable standards.

As a thank you for your contribution we have created some great perks for you. Take a look!

 

 

If you want to fund our campaign with an amount of your choice, you can find the "Back it" button on the top right. Also small contributions will be of great help.

If you are interested in distribution or wholesale of Tasini, please contact us at ideas@MakingOceansPlasticFree.com

If you want to support our campaign but you do not have a Credit Card, please contact us at ideas@MakingOceansPlasticFree.com 

We understand that not anyone has the funds to contribute. If you like our idea and want to help you can still be of great support by sharing our campaign with your friends, family, colleagues, everyone. You can find the social media links on the top right.

What will happen after the campaign?

We are currently in the process of setting up a social enterprise. As a social enterprise we will be able to increase our outreach by producing and distributing Tasini on a larger scale. Beyond this initial crowdfunding we want to attain financial sustainability and reduce the need for external funding. We want to achieve this by financing our goals from the sales of Tasini. Using those funds we will continue with environmental awareness campaigns. We will produce Tasini bags from recycled plastic waste (PET) and we will make sure Tasini prices are as low as possible, while ethical and sustainable production standards are ensured.

What if the funding goal is not achieved? Every contribution is appreciated and will help us get closer to our goals. We will continue to work hard. The more funds we can raise, the bigger the impact of our efforts to reduce plastic bag pollution.

 

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

 

Tasini - der Schlüssel zum Erfolg über die Plastiktüte

 

Überblick

“Nichts, dass wir für 5 Minuten nutzen, sollte unsere Meere für mehr als 500 Jahre verschmutzen.”

Tasini ist eine wiederverwendbare Tasche, die wir als Meerestiere entworfen haben, um auf das Ökosystem aufmerksam zu machen, welches wir schützen wollen. Am Schlüsselanhänger befestigt und mit der faltbaren Tasche im Inneren, ist es praktisch und macht Spaß keine Plastiktüten mehr zu nutzen.

Mit eurer Unterstützung möchten wir eine mediale Umweltbildungskampagne in Indonesien starten und die Tasini-Tasche aus recyceltem Plastikmüll herstellen. Darüber hinaus wollen wir Tasini für jeden erschwinglich machen: Je mehr Menschen wir erreichen, desto mehr Plastikmüll wird vermieden.

Wer wir sind

Wir sind vier Freunde aus Deutschland und Indonesien, die Gründer der Umweltinitiative Making Oceans Plastic Free. Uns liegt der Schutz der Ozeane am Herzen: Unser Ziel ist es, dieses Geschenk auch für zukünftige Generationen zu erhalten.

Das Team

Die Entwicklung von Tasini ist durch unsere verschiedenen Hintergründe inspiriert: Roger erforscht Möglichkeiten, wie die Nutzung von Plastiktüten reduziert werden kann; Pari erforscht als Ethnologe die Indonesische Kultur und Gesellschaft und hat einen Abschluss in Biologie; Adith berät Regierungsprogramme und Unternehmen zu umweltfreundlicher Produktion; und Lia hat ein abgeschlossenes Kunststudium und ist kreative Produktdesignerin.

Indonesien - die weltweit zweitgrößte Quelle für marine Plastikverschmutzung

Mit Fokus auf Indonesien - die weltweit zweitgrößte Quelle für marine Plastikverschmutzung - können wir wirklich etwas bewirken. Aber wir denken, dass Verhaltensänderung auf der ganzen Welt am besten funktioniert, wenn sie spielerisch und leicht erlernt wird. In der Entwicklung von Tasini war das unser Ansporn.

Tasini und ihre Eigenschaften - "Special Agents"

 

 

Unser Vorhaben

Mit eigenen Mitteln konnten wir bereits 1000 Tasini produzieren. Jetzt brauchen wir deine Hilfe, um unsere 3 Ziele zu erreichen:

  1. Eine große mediale Umweltbildungskampangne in Indonesien starten. Die sympathischen Tasini-Meerestiere sind die passenden Umweltbotschafter, um die Menschen über marine Plastikverschmutzung aufzuklären. Mit deiner Unterstützung können wir eine große mediale Umweltkampagne in Indonesien starten.
  2. Tasini aus recyceltem Plastikmüll (PET) herstellen. Stoffe aus recyceltem PET sind in Indonesien noch unüblich. Um diese Stoffe produzieren zu lassen, müssen wir eine große Menge bestellen. Mit deiner Unterstützung können wir das finanzieren und recycelten Plastikmüll für die Tasini-Taschen verwenden.
  3. Tasini für alle erschwinglich machen. Je mehr Menschen wir erreichen, desto mehr Plastikmüll wird vermieden. Deshalb wollen wir den Preis für Tasini so niedrig wie möglich halten. Mit deiner Unterstützung können wir die Produktionskosten reduzieren und gleichzeitig hohe Sozial- und Umweltstandards sicherstellen.

Als Dankeschön für Deine Unterstützung haben wir diese Artikel (Perks) für Dich vorbereitet

Du möchtest uns mit einem dir freigestellten Betrag unterstützen? Oben rechts findest du den “Unterstützen” Button, jeder noch so kleine Beitrag ist eine große Hilfe.

Du bist am Großhandel bzw. Vertrieb von Tasini interessiert? Bitte kontaktiere uns über ideas@MakingOceansPlasticFree.com

Du möchtest uns unterstützen, hast aber keine Kreditkarte? Bitte kontaktiere uns über ideas@MakingOceansPlasticFree.com

Nicht jeder kann uns finanziell unterstützen, das verstehen wir. Wenn Dir die Idee gefällt, kannst du uns dennoch helfen, indem du das Projekt mit deinen Freunden, Kollegen oder deiner Familie teilst. Oben auf der Seite findest du die Social-Media-Verlinkungen dazu.

Was passiert nachdem die Kampagne vorbei ist?

Wir sind gerade dabei ein Social Enterprise aufzubauen. Als Social Enterprise möchten wir uns innovativ, pragmatisch und langfristig für die Lösung ökologisch-sozialer Probleme einsetzen. Wir möchten Tasini in größerem Maßstab produzieren und vertreiben, um einen möglichst großen Effekt zu erzielen. Mit dem anfänglichen Crowdfunding möchten wir finanzielle Nachhaltigkeit erzielen und unabhängig von externer Finanzierung werden. Dieses Ziel möchten wir durch den Verkauf von Tasini finanzieren. Wir nutzen die Gelder, um weiterhin Umweltbildungskampagnen zu machen. Wir werden Tasini mit recyceltem Plastikmüll (PET) herstellen und Tasini zum niedrigst möglichen Preis anbieten, wobei wir das nur im Rahmen fairer und nachhaltiger Produktionsbedingungen machen.

Was passiert, wenn das Fundingziel nicht erreicht wird?

Wir sind über jeden Beitrag dankbar! Er wird uns helfen, dem Ziel ein Stück näher zu kommen. Wir werden weiter hart für die Sache arbeiten. Je mehr Geld wir zusammen bekommen, desto größer wird die Wirkung des Projekts für saubere Ozeane!

 

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

"Hal yang kita gunakan selama 5 menit seharusnya tidak mencemari laut kita selama 500 tahun"

Kami mendesain Tasini dengan hewan laut untuk meningkatkan kesadaran akan ekosistem yang ingin kami lindungi. Gantungan kunci dengan tas lipat di dalamnya, akan memudahkan dan menyenangkan untuk memecahkan kebiasaan penggunaan kantong plastik. Dengan pendanaan Anda, kami akan meluncurkan kampanye kesadaran lingkungan yang lebih besar. Anda akan memungkinkan kami memproduksi Tasini dari limbah plastik daur ulang dan memastikan dampak yang lebih besar karena akan membuat Tasini menjadi terjangkau ke berbagai kalangan sebanyak mungkin.

Jika Anda ingin membeli Tasini edisi pertama maka Anda akan berpartisipasi dalam membantu kami mendanai kampanye Tasini, Apabila Anda tidak memiliki Kartu Kredit, silakan menuliskan email ke Adith@MakingOceansPlasticFree.com

Wir sind gerade dabei ein Social Enterprise aufzubauen. Als Social Enterprise möchten wir uns innovativ, pragmatisch und langfristig für die Lösung ökologisch-sozialer Probleme einsetzen. Wir möchten Tasini in größerem Maßstab produzieren und vertreiben, um einen möglichst großen Effekt zu erzielen. Mit dem anfänglichen Crowdfunding möchten wir finanzielle Nachhaltigkeit erzielen und unabhängig von externer Finanzierung werden. Dieses Ziel möchten wir durch den Verkauf von Tasini finanzieren. Wir nutzen die Gelder, um weiterhin Umweltbildungskampagnen zu machen. Wir werden Tasini mit recyceltem Plastikmüll (PET) herstellen und Tasini zum niedrigst möglichen Preis anbieten, wobei wir das nur im Rahmen fairer und nachhaltiger Produktionsbedingungen machen.
Was passiert, wenn das Fundingziel nicht erreicht wird? 
Wir sind über jeden Beitrag dankbar! Er wird uns helfen, dem Ziel ein Stück näher zu kommen. Wir werden weiter hart für die Sache arbeiten. Je mehr Geld wir zusammen bekommen, desto größer wird die Wirkung des Projekts für saubere Ozeane!
 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
"Hal yang kita gunakan selama 5 menit seharusnya tidak mencemari laut kita selama 500 tahun"Kami mendesain Tasini dengan hewan laut untuk meningkatkan kesadaran akan ekosistem yang ingin kami lindungi. Gantungan kunci dengan tas lipat di dalamnya, akan memudahkan dan menyenangkan untuk memecahkan kebiasaan penggunaan kantong plastik. Dengan pendanaan Anda, kami akan meluncurkan kampanye kesadaran lingkungan yang lebih besar. Anda akan memungkinkan kami memproduksi Tasini dari limbah plastik daur ulang dan memastikan dampak yang lebih besar karena akan membuat Tasini menjadi terjangkau ke berbagai kalangan sebanyak mungkin.Jika Anda ingin membeli Tasini edisi pertama maka Anda akan berpartisipasi dalam membantu kami mendanai kampanye Tasini, Apabila Anda tidak memiliki Kartu Kredit, silakan menuliskan email ke Adith@MakingOceansPlasticFree.com

story:
Background and Current Events

Since most of the 1.32 billion pounds of shrimp imported into the United States per year are unsustainably harvested, it is reported by Oceana and others that for every 1 pound of tropical shrimp caught through trawling the bottom of the ocean, 10 pounds of other marine life is killed. This fishing technique “clear cuts” the ocean floor, catching shrimp and everything in its path with much of the "bycatch" which could be a source of food for humans  being redirected to waste, so this key protein source is taken away from people who need it the most. The total area of seabed trawled each year is nearly 150 times the area of the world's forests that are clear cut.

Only 10% of the wild caught shrimp consumed in the United States each year comes from the Gulf of Mexico and the South Atlantic Oceans. The rest – some 1.2 billion pounds – is pond raised or wild caught in China, Thailand, Indonesia and Vietnam.

The Guardian newspaper in a June 10, 2014 investigative report states that up to 300,000 people are chattel slaves in Thailand working to produce the fish meal that is used for shrimp feed. Check the shrimp that you eat. Look on the back of the bag that says "sustainably grown" and see where that shrimp comes from. Please view the investigative report video.

Traditional shrimp farming involves the use of wild shrimp stocked in large, coastal ponds where high water-exchange rates are used to maintain acceptable pond water quality. There are a number of concerns associated with this approach, including coastal water pollution from pond effluent, crop loss from disease due to frequent exposure to shrimp pathogens, and destruction of valuable mangrove habitat for farm construction. In addition, in many places around the world, traditional shrimp farms cannot provide year-round production due to a limited growing season.

This picture is of a traditional shrimp farm of almost 2500 acres. It is located on the coast next to mangrove forests, produces 5 million pounds of shrimp per year and has a huge environmental footprint.

The Project

The shrimp farm to be constructed is a Solar Biosecure Super Intensive Shrimp Farm utilizing the latest innovations in solar power, aquaculture and technology. This state-of-the-art facility to be located in the Dominican Republic, built with American technology and hardware will grow a Specific Pathogen Free (SPF) Pacific White Shrimp (Penaeus Vannamei). This high-density, indoor biosecure facility will have the capacity to produce approximately 5 million pounds of Jumbo to Extra Jumbo weight shrimp per year exported to the United States.

This system allows for stocking densities that are many times higher than traditional shrimp farming and allows for land and water use that is a fraction of what is used in traditional shrimp farming. The farm will provide a reliable and environmentally sustainable production technology package which will allow for the production of healthy, good-tasting seafood at competitive prices that will be both Organic Certified and certified by the Aquatic Stewardship Council.

Below is an architect's rendering of our Solar Biosecure Shrimp Farm on just 16 acres, taking water from the sea through just a 3 inch pipe, which will produce 5 million pounds of shrimp per year with almost zero environmental footprint.

Design by Aquaculture Farming Technology

Our shrimp farm will save a mangrove forest like the one in this picture.

Countries are going to enter the aquaculture business or look to grow their existing market share; this project has the Dominican Republic doing it in an environmentally friendly way.

The Government of the Dominican Republic has contributed to the farm 16 acres of land including the environmental permits and full support of the government for the project including job training, infrastructure and Free Zone status. The granting of Free Zone status means no corporate income taxes for 25 years, zero VAT and no import or export duties. This will allow us to put those savings back into the project to build more modules and even additional farms saving more coastal ecosystems.


About 80% of the seafood consumed in the United States comes from somewhere else and only 2% of that is inspected and 1% is tested in a lab. The FDA continues to report in an alert issued in April 2014 “the use of unapproved antibiotics or chemicals in aquaculture raises significant public health concerns,” including cancer producing effects. The FDA reports that it continues to find residues of some banned animal drugs in shipments of farm raised seafood products from China. Plus in the past two years, a disease known as Shrimp Early Mortality Syndrome (EMS), caused by a strain of bacteria commonly found in brackish coastal waters, has caused die-offs of cultivated shrimp in several Asian countries.

For shrimp to survive and grow well, pond water temperatures need to be maintained within a narrow range, and large outdoor ponds cannot accommodate this requirement. In light of the disadvantages and constraints of traditional shrimp farming, alternative approaches need to be implemented in order to grow shrimp in an environmentally sustainable and profitable way. In addition, shrimp farming has become competitive and as such the technology utilized needs to be efficient in all aspects – productivity, quality, sustainability, biosecurity and to be in line with market demand.

The Super Intensive Production System (SIPS) technology provides such an alternative. Water in the PS is recirculated and remediated by bioreactors specially designed for the system rather than via water exchange. Water requirements are reduced significantly, thereby mitigating the opportunity for pathogen introduction onto the farm and through the use of various scientific methodologies reducing the amount of organic matter discharged into the surrounding environment.

Also, the enclosed environment of SIPS allows for temperature control and therefore year-round production. In addition, shrimp can be produced at temperate latitudes and closer to major markets, thereby reducing transport costs and the number of “food miles” which is a measure of environmental impact. These benefits, coupled with super-intensive stocking densities, result in a farm footprint that is much smaller than traditional shrimp farms for the same production output.

In addition to the advantages of the technology, is the use of domesticated, Specific Pathogen Free (SPF) shrimp which represents a significant advantage over wild-caught shrimp. Shrimp farmers who stock their ponds with wild, postlarvae (baby shrimp) experience poor shrimp growth and survival, low farm production, and reduced profits. SPF shrimp are developed from domesticated populations and are certifiably free of specific pathogens which pose a significant health threat to the shrimp. We have an integrated approach to super intensive production which integrates major advances used in successful terrestrial meat production industries with novel approaches to aquatic animal husbandry provided by our experts.

What the Funds Will Used For

Since we have the land and infrastructure improvements, the next step is to begin construction on the first module. The first module will produce 1 million pounds of shrimp per year. The first crop can be available in USA supermarkets 6 months after the completion of the first module. Below is an architect's rendering of one raceway in the module. Each module consists of 10 production raceways. Of course, the more funds we raise the more modules that can be constructed.

Design by Aquaculture Farming Technology

Overview of the Shrimp Farm

The shrimp farm will cover 16 acres of land which would allow for expansion and include a 15 KW solar power plant, a small maturation/hatchery facility to produce post larval (baby) shrimp and a modularized growout facility to grow shrimp from post larvae (.003 of an ounce) to market size (over one ounce).

In addition to these primary facilities, the farm will include support facilities such as offices, a water quality laboratory, feed storage space, and maintenance shop. We will use only certified shrimp feed that meets aquaculture industry guidance and production standards. 

In addition to achieving a production goal of over 5,000,000 pounds of shrimp per year with five modules completed, the Management Team will be able to achieve important key success factors including:

1.  Reliability: By using the latest aquaculture technologies, production goals can be achieved and more reliably because the shrimp production environment is biosecure (free of pathogens) and temperature controlled. This is very different from traditional shrimp farming where outdoor ponds are exposed to significant environmental fluctuations and virulent pathogens which compromise system stability and reliability.

2.  Environmental Sustainability: Because water in the production units will be re-circulated and remediated, no waste water effluent will be discharged from the farm and no coastal pollution will occur. Also, solid wastes produced during production will be collected for proper disposal. These wastes can also be used as fertilizer to grow salt-tolerant plants for biofuels or human consumption, processed into aquatic animal feeds, or used to grow other seafood products such as sea cucumbers or saltwater tilapia. In addition, shrimp shells can be converted to chitin, a polysaccharide that has numerous uses such as purifying waste water, thickening and stabilizing foods and pharmaceuticals. Thus, solid wastes generated from the farm can generate additional revenue.

3.  Healthy/Good Tasting Shrimp: Because shrimp will be grown indoors, the potential for off-flavors to develop is eliminated. Off-flavors can develop in shrimp grown on coastal farms due to the presence of a compound called Geosmin which is produced by blue-green algae. In addition, shrimp grown on the farm can receive a “finishing diet” which will improve the fatty acid profile of shrimp tissue just prior to harvesting. This will allow us to market a “heart healthy” shrimp product which is organic certified.

4.  Organic Shrimp: Again, because shrimp will be grown indoors, the opportunity for pathogen introduction onto the farm is mitigated and there will be no need for antibiotics or other chemicals to treat disease. Plus the shrimp will be certified organic and the facility will meet all of the requirements of the Aquaculture Stewardship Council.

Photo provided by Aquaculture Farming Technology

Project Benefits

The Shrimp Farm Project will provide a significant number of new, sustainable, fair wage and in many cases, highly technical jobs and offer a new skill set for many of the local residents.

With direct job creation this project will quickly help to revitalize the immediate community in which it is being placed and an equally significant number of indirect employment opportunities in the USA.

The quality of shrimp produced via the technology will quickly establish the farm as a quality supplier of an increasingly sought after commodity. Our Management Team wants to provide a total solution for ecological (and economic) production of shrimp with the goal of becoming a leader in sustainable and environment friendly shrimp farm technology to expand into other locations. This project is being monitored by several countries in Latin America and Africa.

Description of the Biofloc Biosecure System

Biofloc technology (BFT) is a relatively new biotechnology which means to control water quality in shrimp and fish aquaculture to minimize water exchange and environmental pollution, to recycle feed and reduce production cost. This system can be used to develop a sustainable and environmentally friendly aquaculture.

The biofloc system allows production of shrimp without exchange of water. Its phase production maximizes the utilization of water volume by using a two- phase split growing system and partial harvesting. It allows harvesting of daily fresh shrimp through partial harvesting without stressing the remaining shrimp in the tank.

The interaction with the bioreactors reduces the excess sludge production and nitrate buildup. Excess bioflocs can be removed without special equipment. Intensive aeration allows high biomass densities and keeps the flocs in suspension. Utilization of substrates increases the surface of shrimp tanks and provides extra hiding and resting places for molting shrimp as well as an increased area for nitrification and production of micro-organisms.

Thanks to zero exchange of water with no effluents, the environmental impact is reduced. The application of such a system meets the growing aquaculture concept of a responsible, sustainable and environmentally friendly shrimp farming method.

The system also reduces the risk of introduction and spread of diseases. When covered with a building, this system provides the only good option for a biosecure shrimp farm. Because the module is equipped with an advanced bioreactor, this increases the flexibility of water quality management. The addition of chemicals for pH adjustment is not necessary and nitrate levels are controlled.

Excess bioflocs can be removed without special equipment. The advanced utilization and control of bioflocs not only reduces the environmental impact but also enables nutrient recycling into new protein biomass as additional nutrition for the shrimp, resulting in faster growth and reducing the amount of feed needed to grow a pound of shrimp. Thanks to the re-use of water, the system can be built anywhere in the world, in the tropics, in temperate climates, in the desert, close to towns, and in buildings. The system is easy to handle and manage and has low operational costs.

This bioreactor is customized to the farm production strategy. Its design incorporates bioreactors, pond aeration systems, tanks for production and waste water treatment.

Cutting Edge Water Recycling System

The water recycling system is one of the newest unique technologies which is being employed in this project; its water recycling process enhances biosecurity. Since the iso-osmotic concentration for the shrimp is in the 20- to 25- ppt range, medium-salinity seawater is physiologically advantageous for shrimp growth, while still providing adequate levels to offset possible nitrite toxicities.

Water recycling from run to run also facilitates faster turn-around between harvest and restocking, eliminating the need to condition new water before each restocking. Juvenile shrimp are acclimated to the growout race-way water by slowly running existing raceway water through the adjacent nursery tank starting about two weeks prior to stocking.

Conclusion

The farm will be solar powered, environmentally protected, biosecure, have minimal water exchange, a minimal footprint per ton of production, fast growth, and ever more efficient food conversion ratios utilizing the latest biofloc technology. This facility will be a model for shrimp farmers to follow. It will be the first solar shrimp farm in the world utilizing and developing breakthrough technologies in the aquaculture industry; and be a transparent showcase of the latest innovations in shrimp farming, while being certified by the leading international bodies responsible for global and aquaculture standards and practices.

Even with strong interest to purchase the shrimp from major supermarkets and restaurants nothing is better than their customers and our supporters asking for the product by name. We need our supporters asking their local retailers for the product. It would be great if BluAqua could partner with retailers. Some great chefs have asked for the shrimp even wanting us to raise shrimp to just 8 shrimp per pound for their restaurants. Follow us on Twitter, like us on Facebook and we will update you on the project's progress, product availability, fantastic seafood recipes (on our Twitter page now Bucatini with Pesto and Shrimp) and send you coupons.

Our Perks

We have thoughtfully chosen perks to thank you for supporting the effort to make the shrimp farm a reality such as our special logo T-shirt just for our crowdfunding supporters and art pieces made by the Taino Indians. The Taino greeted Columbus when he landed in the Americas. We applaud you and thank all of you for not just supporting this project but also for supporting the Taino.

                                               BluAqua Farm Logo T-Shirt 
                  100% Cotton T-Shirt  Made in the USA by American Apparel
                         

                                       Mama Juana Herbs and Bottle

Mama Juana is concocted by allowing rum, red wine, and honey to soak in a bottle with tree bark and wild herbs. The taste is similar to port wine and the color is deep red.

The specific herbs that make up Mama Juana were originally prepared as a herbal tea by the native Taino Indians; post-Columbus alcohol was added to the recipe. 

We have never seen Mama Juana available in the USA. Our favorite concoction is to use dark rum (Dominican or Puerto Rican) or cachaca, a Rioja (your choice) and Black Mangrove honey.

Our special T shirt logo is on the back of the 750 ml bottle with a thank-you note. Recipe included, just refill when empty, it is good for several refills.

Taino Amulets

The Taino Amulets are replicas of Taino Pre-Colombian artifacts that are hand made of red clay, carved with sticks and fired in sand kilns the same way the Taino's ancestors made them.

                                                       Taino Batea

Taino hand carved wood bowls (Batea in Spanish) that are hand painted with different scenes and signed by the artists.

The Bowls are 12-14 inches long, 7-9 inches wide and 2 inches deep.

                            Hand Painted Tin Mugs By Taino Artists

On our Facebook page is a recipe for Watermelon Gazpacho. Served in these mugs, it's a beautiful way to kick off a dinner party.

The Taino greeted Columbus when he landed in the Americas. We applaud you and thank all of you for not just supporting this project but also for supporting the Taino.                                                BluAqua Farm Logo T-Shirt                    100% Cotton T-Shirt  Made in the USA by American Apparel                                                                 Mama Juana Herbs and BottleMama Juana is concocted by allowing rum, red wine, and honey to soak in a bottle with tree bark and wild herbs. The taste is similar to port wine and the color is deep red.The specific herbs that make up Mama Juana were originally prepared as a herbal tea by the native Taino Indians; post-Columbus alcohol was added to the recipe. We have never seen Mama Juana available in the USA. Our favorite concoction is to use dark rum (Dominican or Puerto Rican) or cachaca, a Rioja (your choice) and Black Mangrove honey.Our special T shirt logo is on the back of the 750 ml bottle with a thank-you note. Recipe included, just refill when empty, it is good for several refills.Taino AmuletsThe Taino Amulets are replicas of Taino Pre-Colombian artifacts that are hand made of red clay, carved with sticks and fired in sand kilns the same way the Taino's ancestors made them.                                                       Taino Batea Taino hand carved wood bowls (Batea in Spanish) that are hand painted with different scenes and signed by the artists. The Bowls are 12-14 inches long, 7-9 inches wide and 2 inches deep.                             Hand Painted Tin Mugs By Taino ArtistsOn our Facebook page is a recipe for Watermelon Gazpacho. Served in these mugs, it's a beautiful way to kick off a dinner party.

story:
Hello!

My name is Melanie Wheeler.  I'm a sophomore studying music education at the tiny school of Earlham College in the only slightly larger town of Richmond, Indiana.  The reason you're here reading this campaign is because from October to December of this year, I will be interning in southeast Madagascar with Azafady, a registered UK charity whose mission is to alleviate poverty and conserve the endangered forest environments in southeast Madagascar.  As part of the pre-travel preparations, I've begun campaigning to fundraise for this awesome organization

Madagascar is simultaneously one of the most ecologically diverse and poverty stricken countries in the world.  The country hosts a diverse range of flora and fauna, 80% of which are found exclusively on the island.  Yet, due to growing industrialization and demand, the country has experienced 90% deforestation.  The environmental crisis is compounded with the fact that 77% of the population live under the international poverty line ($1.25 USD/day) and more than 65% of the population are living without access to clean water.

To keep it brief, Azafday is paired with a Malagasy NGO (ONG Azafady) that builds its projects sensitively around the directly expressed needs of the rural communities outside of Ft. Dauphin (a coastal city near the bottom of Madagascar).  Within the mission of alleviating poverty and conserving environment, Azafady works to meet those needs in a sustainable fashion.  The specific program I'm involved with, the Pioneer Program, works in three interrelated areas:

-Sustainable livelihood development

-health based infrastructure and education

-habitat conservation

Therefore the work that I will be doing could range from reforestation to helping communities start small, income generating business to building, wells, latrines, and schools.

But why?  Why would some random college student want to travel halfway across the world to work in a tiny country?  And more importantly, why should you care?

Well, on a personal level, I'm at point in my education where I'm ready to grow in ways that a classroom can't offer me.  I'm ready for the world to be my classroom and for experience to be my teacher (don't worry, I'll be returning to college in the spring).  On what I guess you could call a more altruistic level, I believe we all have a calling to ease to suffering in the world.  I suppose you could say this is mine.

I can't promise much.  There's no flashy end product, no tangible way of knowing you've done good.  All I can promise is that the money you help me fundraise will go to a purpose that I am a 110% invested in.  I can promise a peace of mind that your money will not just go to cause, but it will go to people and to valuable experience.  Your donations will go directly to Azafady , of which 90% of it will go directly to funding on-the-ground projects.

There's also some pretty cool incentives to donate :)

You can't donate?  No problem!  Help me spread the word!  Post this page on your facebook wall, your twitter account, or whatever social media you're involved with.  Talk to your friends about.  I can't do this fundraising on my own; I need your help  The beauty of this campaign is that it's not just about it money, it's also about raising awareness.  

Help me make some noise about this incredible organization and the work they do.

Whether or not you choose to donate, I invite you to follow my blog (starting this summer) which will track my movement from my summer work as a naturalist to working on an organic farm in Ashville, NC and finally to Madagascar.  I also encourage you to educate yourself.  Below are links to website to learn more about Madagascar and Azafday:

http://azafady.org/index.htm

https://www.facebook.com/AzafadyMadagascar

Here's a link to my blog:

http://travelsofastudent.blogspot.com/

If you donate through this website, the money goes to me and then I send it to Azafady.  However, if you feel compelled to donate and want to donate without me as a middle man (and you can do without the lovely incentives listed to your right), you can donate through bmycharity.  The money donated there will go directly to Azafady. The link for that website is here:

http://www.bmycharity.com/azafadywheeler1

In closing, I'd like to share what I believe is a relevant quote from Thich Nhat Hahn, author of Peace is Every Step:

“Hope is important because it can make the present moment less difficult to bear. If we believe that tomorrow will be better, we can bear a hardship today.”

Walk softly upon the earth, 

Melanie Wheeler

story:
La réalité des changements climatiques est maintenant reconnue par la majorité. Toutefois, renverser la vapeur n’est pas un but accessible si la cause n’est soutenue qu’au niveau individuel.

La raison d’être de Greenplease est de prendre le pouls (vert) des communautés et de permettre la mise en œuvre de moyens de pression efficaces et constructifs sur les entreprises ainsi que sur les conseils municipaux afin qu’ils relèvent le défi de maintenir leurs activités tout en usant de pratiques et de mentalités durables et responsables, sans compromis !

  • L’influence des Entreprises sur nos habitudes de consommation, et par conséquent sur notre planète, est colossale. Elles doivent donc devenir LES LEADERS en terme de développement durable et responsable, ainsi qu’être à la hauteur de la confiance que nous leur vouons en achetant leurs biens.
  • Les Conseils Municipaux représentent sans doute le seul palier de gouvernement à toujours pouvoir interagir à un niveau humain; ils sont néanmoins assez puissants pour que leurs actions aient de réels impacts au niveau global. C’est sur eux qu’il faut pouvoir compter pour initier, supporter et sommer les actions de changement.

Si l’architecture et les fonctionnalités de Greenplease empruntent à Facebook et à Twitter pour l’aspect interactif, ses outils uniques (en particulier les BOYCOTTS) en font une plateforme de pression qui n’a pas son pareil sur le Web. Les TURFS & TOOLS de Greenplease offrent aux individus et aux communautés l’opportunité de prendre part à de simples actions qui, lorsque mises en commun, peuvent atteindre un niveau de persuasion impossible à ignorer. Avec le défi que représente les changements climatiques, l’arrivée de Greenplease est tout à fait à propos.

 

GREENPLEASE EN FRANÇAIS

Jusqu'à présent, le développement s'est fait uniquement en anglais. Nous débuterons la traduction en français dès que la programmation sera entamée, et Greenplease sera simultanément lancé en anglais et en français.

 

LES TURFS

Les TURFS sont des profils interactifs conçus pour développer la communication ouverte et bi-directionnelle entre les administrations municipales et leurs citoyens ainsi qu’entre les entreprises et leurs clients. Les TURFS sont pour les individus, les BIG TURFS pour les entreprises, et les CITY TURFS pour les conseils municipaux.

 

LES TOOLS (Outils)

Les OUTILS de Greenplease sont simples à utiliser et rapides à mettre à exécution. Leurs buts sont de mettre à l’avant-plan :

  • La Responsabilité (BOYCOTTS)
  • Le Support (BUYCOTTS)
  • L’Engagement (BANS) Bannissements
  • La Solidarité (GATHERINGS) Rassemblements

L'exécution

L'architecture, les maquettes et les fonctionalités sont prêtes. Nous prévoyons débuter la programmation au mois d'août prochain et lancer Greenplease avant Noël.

Avec votre appui nous pourrons:

  • Nous installer temporairement un bureau commun - Nous sommes présentement tous des bénévoles. Afin d'être efficaces, nous devons poursuivre en tant qu'équipe travaillant à temps complet, sous le même toit. Et ce, pour une période de 3 à 4 mois.
  • Défrayer les coûts d'hébergement et d'entretien web pour la première année d'opération.
  • Assumer les frais d'éventuelles sous-straitance techniques dont notre équipe ne pourra s'occuper
  • Compléter nos démarches d'enregistrement en tant qu'organisme sans but lucratif.

 

Puis, si nous dépassons notre objectif de 10 000$, nous utiliserons ces fonds pour:

  • Lancer des campagnes-chocs de publicité afin de rassembler un maximum de membres.
  • Débuter les traductions en espagnol et en allemand, toujours afin de rejoindre un maximum de personnes.
  • Développer la Phase 2 : Le Fond Innovation-Hub de Greenplease et le volet des enfants et de leurs écoles: Les GREENKIDSPLEASE.

Rappel sur nos statuts de bénévoles

Aucun des membres de l’équipe de Greenplease n’est rémunéré; tous nos programmeurs, marketers, graphistes et administrateurs oeuvrent en tant que bénévoles. Lors de l’étape de la programmation, ceux-ci devront quitter leurs activités quotidiennes respectives et venir s’installer et s’investir avec nous. Une partie des sommes recueillies par la présente campagne de financement servira donc à leur offrir un milieu de travail intéressant et agréable. Notez toutefois que ces espaces de travail nous seront prêtés gracieusement par différents partenaires. Nous n’aurons qu’à défrayer les coûts d’opération.

Suite au lancement, nous mettrons en branle notre stratégie de "sponsorship" pour assurer la suite de nos opérations. Nous tenons par ailleurs à préciser que nous ne ferons jamais appel à la publicité pour recueillir des fonds.

 

LES "GOODIES" !

La plus grande contrepartie dont vous pouvez vous prévaloir est la satisfaction personnelle de participer à cet effort, qui veut donner un nouvel élan au Mouvement Vert.

Ceci dit, nous voulons bien sûr souligner votre participation avec quelques « Goodies » ! 

  • Les mini-badges - Nous avons fait graver sur le rebord de nos premiers 1000 badges l'inscription suivante " I'M ONE OF THE FIRST 1000 GREENPLEASERS". Il nous en reste environ 400. Le prochain lot sera identifié par "I'M GREENPLEASER #1000-2000", et ainsi de suite. Ne tardez pas !
  • Votre Greenplease T-Shirt - Les T-Shirts que nous nous procurons proviennent de fournisseurs utilisant des matières biologiques et recyclées. Si la présente campagne réussi à générer une commande importante de T-Shirts nous pourrons opter pour du chanvre biologique ! Commandez donc en grand nombre !
  • L'entête de votre TURF à votre image - Projetez-vous 3 ans dans le futur et imaginez que Greenplease soit "LA" plateforme verte par excellence que tout le monde utilise. Ne souhaiteriez-vous pas faire partie de la poignée de Visionnaires dont l'entête de TURF arbore un vert distinctif ?

 

L'Équipe de Greenplease

Xavier Bonacorsi   (Fondateur - basé au Canada)

Des années de voyages, d’études hétéroclites (sur & hors campus), ainsi qu’au front d’une multitude de projets, m’ont fait développer un très grand respect pour la vie, sous toutes ses formes. Greenplease est issu de ce mode vie, et est alimenté par le désir de briser ce sentiment d’impuissance qui nous tient en échec quant aux enjeux importants.

 

Friedhelm Filler   (Co-fondateur - basé en Allemagne)

Une facilité pour les maths et plusieurs startups internationales m’ont permis de voyager à travers le monde dès mon jeune âge. Ces expériences m’ont fait voir que nous nous servions de la Terre comme s’il n’y avait pas de lendemain. De réaliser à quel point nous exagérons les excès me pousse aujourd'hui à diriger mes efforts afin que la trace de mon passage sur Terre soit... « Verte » !

 

Peter Myers   (Co-fondateur - basé en Nouvelle-Zélande)

Après avoir exploré la majorité des systèmes sociétaux qui se sont développés au cours du dernier siècle, je réalise que de continuer sur ces chemins ne peut que nous conduire vers des conséquences irréparables. Depuis dix ans, je m’applique donc à développer localement des initiatives vertes. Ma règle d’or est de vivre selon, et utiliser des « systèmes » durables et responsables.

 

Hélène Breton   (Co-fondatrice - basée au Canada)

Gestionnaire de ressources humaines; voyageuse fascinée par la nature humaine et ses différentes cultures; mère de deux adolescents de plus en plus préoccupés par leur avenir. C’est à travers cette réalité que s’inspire ma détermination pour Greenplease. Nous arrivons à une croisée des chemins cruciale pour notre futur, mais surtout pour celui de nos enfants. Il est maintenant impératif de se rappeller que tout ce que nous faisons aujourd’hui affectera LEUR demain…

 

Une plateforme intransigeante, mais constructive et respectueuse

Greenplease est une plateforme gérée par ses communautés. Ses administrateurs n’émettront jamais d’opinions ou de commentaires personnels; et, si Greenplease est un lieu pour les critiques, les réprimandes et les désaccords, une attitude constructive et respectueuse est néanmoins de rigueur.

 

Participez à l'effet d'entraînement : Passez le mot !

Afin qu'un mouvement lève et prenne de l'envergure, il doit être diffusé largement: passez le mot ! Parlez-en à vos amis, sur Twitter, Facebook, sur vos blogs, etc.

Vous avez des idées et désirez contribuer davantage à l'essor de Greenplease, n'hésitez pas à communiquer avec nous à info(a)greenplease.fr

 

*** Programmeurs-web et infographistes recherchés ***

Si vous êtes programmeur-web ou graphiste, disposant de quelques semaines de temps libre en août, septembre, ou octobre prochains, et êtes intéressé à participer à l'exécution de Greenplease, contactez-nous. Nous sommes présentement à compléter notre équipe "internationale"; il nous fera plaisir de vous communiquer les détails (particuliers) d'une telle participation !

Si vous êtes programmeur-web ou graphiste, disposant de quelques semaines de temps libre en août, septembre, ou octobre prochains, et êtes intéressé à participer à l'exécution de Greenplease, contactez-nous. Nous sommes présentement à compléter notre équipe "internationale"; il nous fera plaisir de vous communiquer les détails (particuliers) d'une telle participation !

story:
Maasai Weaving Project

What is the Maasai Weaving Project?

This project aims to use the strength of the Maasai community's creative energy to spark a change in the way that discarded materials are used. By providing looms, weaving supplies, and upcycling know-how to local artisans, we aim to draw attention to the problem of overabundant plastic waste. Cows and wildlife are dying as they ingest the plastic bags that litter Kenya's Maasai Mara Reserve. This brings great hardship to the livestock-dependent Maasai. This project will focus on teaching Maasai women how to turn plastic waste into woven mats, bags, and other marketable products. We hope to transform communities by empowering women with new skills. The products created through the weaving of plastic bags will provide a source of income for families, reduce the amount of plastic ingested by Maasai cattle and wildlife, and give visitors and tourists a tangible way to share the story of the Maasai with their friends and family back home. 

Who is involved?

This idea originated with James Nampushi, a Maasai leader now working towards his doctorate in Parks and Wildlife Management at Clemson University. As a member of the Maasai community, he saw firsthand the effects of plastic waste on the Masaai way of life, and sought a solution. He contacted Chris Gustin of Homestead Weaving in Indiana. Gustin has been making beautiful scarves and rugs out of recycled materials for over 20 years. She generously gave her time and knowledge to teach James and me how to turn plastic bags into colorful, washable rugs. My name is Linda Whelihan and I am an artist and teacher in Brattleboro, Vermont, particularly interested in working with recycled materials. For the past 10 years, I have been collaborating with William Sirkobei ole Osono, James' cousin and a Maasai safari guide, in efforts to share Maasai culture with communities and school groups along the east coast. 

What is the timeframe of this project?

Our fundraising campaign will begin in early April, and end after Earth Day on April, 30th. We will be traveling to Kenya in July and spending two weeks with the women in a community center on the Maasai Mara Reserve. We will focus on providing the women with enough hands-on experience and information to continue growing the project and educating others after we are gone. 

What will the funds be used for specifically? 

The money raised through this campaign will be used to fund the purchase of a loom, knitting supplies and my transportation to Kenya. Any extra funding will go towards additional looms and a pedal powered sewing machine.

story:
Save the Barn!

We incorporated a historic 59.25 family farm as a L3C in 2011 with big goals of honoring the legacy of the community and building a community center that helps others live more sustainably through workshops, classes, job training, organic gardens, composting and more.

Our goal is to use our farm to strengthen our community and build resiliency.

One of our projects is to save the farm's centerpiece barn and use it:

  • as a place to house animals - dairy and grass fed beef
  • as a model of sustainability with solar panels on its southern roof
  • as a place to house a new vermiculture/job training, skill building program
  • as the site of community gatherings -weddings, musical events

This beautiful old barn was built in 1871. For nearly a century it housed draft horses and dairy cattle, including our father's dairy business. It is a lovely old structure made with all hand hewn lumber using mortise and tenon construction.

Our needs - simple yet important - raising money for renovation of the barn.

We have some great farm related perks including:

A shout out on our website - as a funder of our barn rising work!

  • Cards showcasing beautiful old barns and farm trees
  • t-shirts with our honor heal nurture logo
  • an honor a farm hero quilt square on an oudoor barn quilt
  • an engraved brick with your family's, business' name
  • And a party invite - on the farm - all organic food, music, great food!

The difference you will make -

We are already making a difference in the community, supporting environmental activism that protects land and water, offering fresh organic food to local markets, putting at risk and disadvantaged youth and adults to work, creating jobs and building programs. We have more to do. This barn will make a big difference. You will make a big difference.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute financially, you can help get the word out about our programs and our save the barn campaign. Please friend us on Facebook or follow us on Twitter. We love you and care about your future. That's what saving this barn is all about.

story:
More than a year after the triple meltdown at Fukushima, Japan and the rest of the world continue to grapple with the short- and long-term consequences. The myth that nuclear power can deliver us from the long-term hazards of fossil fuels has been shattered. Renewable energy, long dismissed as impractical, is being given serious reconsideration. Japan can and must take advantage of this opportunity to rethink and refocus its energy strategies.

  

In Kyoto, birthplace of the Kyoto Protocol, a dedicated group of reporters, writers, artists, editors, and photographers associated with Kyoto Journal (www.kyotojournal.org) is taking a fresh look at proven and innovative alternative technologies such as solar, wind, geothermal, mini-hydro, and biomass as well as the even greater number that are being actively researched, but are insufficiently recognized and under-funded.

 

With your help, our goal is to produce an investigative publication,“Fresh Currents: Japan’s Flow from a Nuclear Past to a Renewable Future,” first in English, with the possibility of having it subsequently published in Japanese, which we will do our best to get into the hands of key policymakers, local government officials, community leaders, educators, and media outlets. Print and PDF versions will also be made available to the general public.

 

 

Why is this so important? Japan’s entrenched pro-nuclear lobby is desperate to reinstitute “business as usual,” as it has after far too many previous accidents. The nuclear industry’s dismal safety record, reflecting both amazing arrogance and catastrophic negligence, shows that safer, sustainable alternatives must be found and developed.

 

This is a critical moment, with a strong citizens’ movement underway demanding a national referendum on nuclear power. Even Japan’s current Minister for the Economy, Trade and Industry admits that it’s time to phase out nuclear generation of electricity. Our “Fresh Currents” project has vital potential to identify viable renewable energy mix options. We believe that it can make a significant contribution to the debate on the future of energy production – not only in Japan, but worldwide.

 

*A previous KJ special issue, Biodiversity, presenting compelling perspectives on biological diversity, contributed constructively to debate at the COP10 Conference in Nagoya in 2010. We handed out 1,000 complimentary copies to delegates and media, in person. KJ also established a presence at the original Kyoto Protocol negotiations in 1997.

 

What will your contribution do?

Our team is already hard at work on this project, but we need help. Kyoto Journal editors and contributors are all working on “Fresh Currents” as volunteers, but we urgently need funds to enable:

• Research and documentation, including travel expenses

• Translation of vital source materials

• Printing of complimentary copies

• Website management

 

Long experience has taught us how to operate on a shoestring, so our budget is modest. All donations will be gratefully received, and applied to maximum effect.

We need to raise $9,500 by July 10th, 2012. Please help us to make a real difference, with multiple benefits for tomorrow’s world and future generations!

People who pledge $300 will receive a "Millennial Tree," a hand-drawn gravure etching similar to the one pictured here by KJ contributing editor and renowned Japan-based artist Brian Williams.



Some of our content contributors:

• Interview with Tetsunari Iida: “Mr. Renewable Energies Japan,” the country's leading expert on renewable energy. Iida has served on numerous local and national government committees, and was a key figure behind last year's passage by the Diet of a new “feed-in tariff” that obligates power companies to use more renewable energy.

 

• Aileen Smith: in recent decades, one of the most persistent critics of the nuclear establishment. Co-founder of NPOs Stop the Monju and Kyoto-based Green Action. Lived and worked in Minamata in the 1960s to publicize the methyl mercury poisoning disaster there with Eugene W. Smith.

 

• Interview with Mycle Schneider: founder of WISE Paris and an energy consultant and nuclear analyst. An adviser to members of the European Parliament on energy issues for more than 20 years, as well as advising the International Atomic Energy Agency. A co-recipient, along with Jinzaburo Takagi, of the Right Livelihood Award, for work in alerting the world to the dangers of plutonium.

 

 

• Martin Frid: Japan-based organic food expert, writing on the effects of radiation on Japan's food.

 

• Winifred Bird: Kyoto Journal contributing editor, correspondent for The Japan Times, The Christian Science Monitor, and numerous other publications.

 

• Christian Dimmer: Japan-based expert on urban design, writing on more energy-efficient city design.

 

 

• Richard Dasher: professor, Stanford University, head of the U.S.-Asia Technology Management Center, consultant to Japanese universities and Silicon Valley firms, writing on the current state of “smart grids” in the U.S. and their lessons for Japan.

 

• Eriko Arita: staff writer at The Japan Times with a decade and a half of experience covering nuclear power and renewable energy issues.

 

• Jonathan Watts: author of  When a Billion Chinese Jump, the story of China's environmental degradation, and former environmental correspondent for The Guardian's Beijing bureau.

 

• Jane Singer, professor at the Graduate School of Global Environmental Studies, Kyoto University, Kyoto Journal contributing editor.

 

• Eric Johnston:  “Fresh Currents'' Editor, staff reporter for The Japan Times in Osaka and a 24-year resident of Japan, including nine years in Kyoto. He has written about Japan's nuclear power industry for The Japan Times and numerous publications since 1995, and covered the 1997 Kyoto Protocol and 2009 Copenhagen Accord climate change conferences for The Japan Times.

 

• Brian Williams: Landscape artist and environmental devotee, long-term resident of Shiga prefecture, Kyoto Journal contributing editor.

 

• Transcript of press conference with freelance journalist Tomihiko Suzuki: One of Japan's leading writers on Japan's yakuza gangsters, Suzuki went under cover as a day laborer at the Fukushima nuclear power plant last July and August. His book “Nuclear Power and the Yakuza,” published in Japanese last December, became a bestseller.

 

• A thought-provoking profile by Jonathan S. Watts of activist priest Rev. Hidehito Okoshi, who applies essential Buddhist principles to deal with CFCs and global warming, militarization, economic inequality, nuclear power, and oil dependency, aiming for a sustainable future and ultimately, social transformation.

 

• Also featured: extraordinary work by many concerned photographers and artists.

 And more…

 

Contact: submissions@kyotojournal.org

Hidehito Okoshi, who applies essential Buddhist principles to deal with CFCs and global warming, militarization, economic inequality, nuclear power, and oil dependency, aiming for a sustainable future and ultimately, social transformation.

 And more…
 
Contact: submissions@kyotojournal.org

story:
UQAM NORD 2015 : MONTRÉAL-KUUJJUARAPIK

Hello! Nous sommes huit étudiants à la maîtrise en Sciences de l'Environnement et en Géographie. Cet été, nous prenons un cours intensif de deux semaines en région boréale québécoise.


1. Au programme:

Comprendre les enjeux sociaux et environnementaux du Nord Québec.

Assistés de deux professeurs, nous rencontrerons des acteurs locaux sur le terrain : forêts, mines, barrages hydroélectriques, village Cri et Inuit.

Grâce à vous, nous allons pouvoir :

- explorer la mine de Malartic

- nous entretenir avec un professeur de foresterie autochtone

- en apprendre plus sur les modes de gouvernance Cri et Inuit

- visiter le complexe hydroélectrique La Grande

- comprendre les enjeux autour de la limite nordique des forêts

- découvrir un ancien poste de traite de fourrure 

- étudier le pergélisol et les aménagements que cela implique

- voir l'impact des changements climatiques sur le terrain

- voir l'Arctique!


2. Parcours:

Abitibi, Baie James, Kuujjuarapik : 3000 kilomètres aller-retour


3. Pourquoi nous avons besoin de VOUS:

Ce cours est une opportunité extraordinaire d'apprentissage en contexte! Pour parcourir les 1500km jusqu'à Kuujjuarapik, nous devons collecter 12000 dollars. Ils couvrirons les frais de déplacement, d'hébergement et les repas. 

Comme vous pouvez le voir sur la vidéo, tous les moyens sont bons pour arriver à destination. Cependant, certains sont plus efficaces que d'autres. 

En donnant  un montant de votre choix, vous contribuez grandement à notre campagne. Les différentes catégories sont affichés à droite de votre écran. 

En échange, vous recevrez une pensée, une photo, un souvenir ou un défi. Si vous souhaitez nous voir grimper aux arbres ou plonger dans le fleuve, c'est maintenant!

Pour plus d'information, n'hésitez pas à nous contacter à uqamnord@gmail.com

VOTRE CONTRIBUTION NOUS RAPPROCHE DE NOTRE OBJECTIF

MERCI!

story:
Short Summary

We are a small Colombian university (UPTC) in the provincial capital of Tunja.  For a year and a half now we have been researching ten Andean crops that were used by the ancient Muisca people of our region, and continue to be grown and consumed by the traditional peasantry. 

An important component of our project is an agronomic experiment on one of these crops, achira (Canna indica), carried out together with local farmers from the towns of Somondoco and Guayatá.  This plant is mainly used in Colombia for the starch that can be extracted from its root-like rhizomes and used in various traditional baked goods, though the root can also be cooked and eaten whole, like a potato.  Aside from its links to local traditional culture, achira is attractive because it is an undemanding crop, requiring few chemical inputs and very compatible with the small-scale mixed cropping system practiced by most peasants in our region of Boyacá.

Our work is important because we are doing grassroots, applied research on achira, asking the sort of basic agronomic questions that have already been largely answered for major crops like corn or wheat, but which are virtual unknowns for a minor, local crop like achira.  In particular, we are evaluating four varieties of achira to learn about yield and nutritional quality of fresh rhizomes (for eating cooked), of extracted starch (for baked goods), and of the leaves, which can be used for animal feed. 

By contributing to our project you will allow us to obtain valuable data that will comprise a reference point for farmers and researchers interested in expanding cultivation of this unique, ecologically responsible, and peasant-friendly crop.  A future of sustainable food and agriculture for all of us depends precisely on small-scale, applied research of the type we are performing, carried out by farmers and academics in different local contexts around the world.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Harvest time is approaching, and we are making all the logistical arrangements after a year of caring for our crop and taking scientific measurements.  But due to rising prices and some miscalculations in our initial budget, we are short $1500US.  This is the amount necessary for us to send 50 samples of rhizomes and extracted starch to a laboratory for a chemical analysis that will tell us what nutritional benefits achira in general has to offer small farmers and food processors, as well as the relative strengths of each variety of achira.

We are offering some perks for big donors: all donors of $20US or more will receive a shout-out on our lead researcher's blog, agrarianideas.blogspot.com.  Donors at the $50 level will get the shout-out and a pdf copy of the first article we successfully get published in a respected academic journal as a result of our research.  For those who give $100US or more to the achira cause, we will thank you in the acknowledgments section of this article.  And for any special achira godmothers (or godfathers) who give $500US, our lead researcher will offer his services as a personal tour guide if you come to visit Colombia.

All money we receive up to our goal amount will go to fund these laboratory analyses.  If we don't receive the full amount, our team of researchers will have to pitch in out of pocket to cover the difference, which represents more than a month's wages for our lead researcher, and even more for our other team members.  If we are lucky enough to exceed the $1500US we need, any surplus will go to form a fund with local farmers to finance future achira-related projects (a semi-mechanized processing plant, for instance).

 

The Impact

As noted above, your donation will fund research that is increasingly necessary in an uncertain food future.  Such grassroots, farmer-level research is too rarely financed by big public organizations, and almost never by large agricultural companies (who don't stand to earn anything from small farmers growing an undemanding crop using few purchased inputs).  Achira is versatile not only ecologically, but because it can serve the farmer as a home-grown food, a small-scale industrial/commercial product, or an animal feed.  As for many locally-adapted crops, achira cultivation is increasingly being abandoned as farmers plant other species that receive more research attention and marketing support, or as young people leave the countryside for jobs in the city.  Our research is laying the knowledge groundwork (and creating an excitement and social validation around the crop) that will encourage farmers to plant more achira.  This will lower pesticide use as compared to most other crops, as well as offering a new, viable economic option to attract and keep young farmers in the area.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, or if you're able to donate less than you would have liked to, we would appreciate it if you share our project with your friends and family, via facebook, indiegogo, or good old-fashioned word of mouth or email.

An important component of our project is an agronomic experiment on one of these crops, achira (Canna indica), carried out together with local farmers from the towns of Somondoco and Guayatá.  This plant is mainly used in Colombia for the starch that can be extracted from its root-like rhizomes and used in various traditional baked goods, though the root can also be cooked and eaten whole, like a potato.  Aside from its links to local traditional culture, achira is attractive because it is an undemanding crop, requiring few chemical inputs and very compatible with the small-scale mixed cropping system practiced by most peasants in our region of Boyacá.
Our work is important because we are doing grassroots, applied research on achira, asking the sort of basic agronomic questions that have already been largely answered for major crops like corn or wheat, but which are virtual unknowns for a minor, local crop like achira.  In particular, we are evaluating four varieties of achira to learn about yield and nutritional quality of fresh rhizomes (for eating cooked), of extracted starch (for baked goods), and of the leaves, which can be used for animal feed. 
By contributing to our project you will allow us to obtain valuable data that will comprise a reference point for farmers and researchers interested in expanding cultivation of this unique, ecologically responsible, and peasant-friendly crop.  A future of sustainable food and agriculture for all of us depends precisely on small-scale, applied research of the type we are performing, carried out by farmers and academics in different local contexts around the world.
 


What We Need & What You Get
Harvest time is approaching, and we are making all the logistical arrangements after a year of caring for our crop and taking scientific measurements.  But due to rising prices and some miscalculations in our initial budget, we are short $1500US.  This is the amount necessary for us to send 50 samples of rhizomes and extracted starch to a laboratory for a chemical analysis that will tell us what nutritional benefits achira in general has to offer small farmers and food processors, as well as the relative strengths of each variety of achira.
We are offering some perks for big donors: all donors of $20US or more will receive a shout-out on our lead researcher's blog, agrarianideas.blogspot.com.  Donors at the $50 level will get the shout-out and a pdf copy of the first article we successfully get published in a respected academic journal as a result of our research.  For those who give $100US or more to the achira cause, we will thank you in the acknowledgments section of this article.  And for any special achira godmothers (or godfathers) who give $500US, our lead researcher will offer his services as a personal tour guide if you come to visit Colombia.
All money we receive up to our goal amount will go to fund these laboratory analyses.  If we don't receive the full amount, our team of researchers will have to pitch in out of pocket to cover the difference, which represents more than a month's wages for our lead researcher, and even more for our other team members.  If we are lucky enough to exceed the $1500US we need, any surplus will go to form a fund with local farmers to finance future achira-related projects (a semi-mechanized processing plant, for instance).
 


The Impact
As noted above, your donation will fund research that is increasingly necessary in an uncertain food future.  Such grassroots, farmer-level research is too rarely financed by big public organizations, and almost never by large agricultural companies (who don't stand to earn anything from small farmers growing an undemanding crop using few purchased inputs).  Achira is versatile not only ecologically, but because it can serve the farmer as a home-grown food, a small-scale industrial/commercial product, or an animal feed.  As for many locally-adapted crops, achira cultivation is increasingly being abandoned as farmers plant other species that receive more research attention and marketing support, or as young people leave the countryside for jobs in the city.  Our research is laying the knowledge groundwork (and creating an excitement and social validation around the crop) that will encourage farmers to plant more achira.  This will lower pesticide use as compared to most other crops, as well as offering a new, viable economic option to attract and keep young farmers in the area.
 


Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't donate, or if you're able to donate less than you would have liked to, we would appreciate it if you share our project with your friends and family, via facebook, indiegogo, or good old-fashioned word of mouth or email.

story:
URGENT CROWD FUND FOR HISTORIC BENTLEY BLOCKADE POLICE DAY MAY 20.
HELP US CREATE  AN EPIC VISUAL DISPLAY OF NON-VIOLENT DIRECT ACTION - SPONSOR A PROTECTORS T-SHIRT AND BE PART OF THE STORY! 

IF you can, Please come to Bentley Blockade this week and be part of history in the making!   AND/OR  Sponsor a PEACEKEEPER T-shirt for Protectors at Bentley.

  • Collect your PEACEKEEPERS t-shirt when you come
  • or Sponsor a Protector to wear it if you cant make it
  • Sign the International Avaaz Campaign
  • A unified and visual PEACEKEEPING presence will help keep everyone SAFE ON THE DAY and we need your HELP and your LOVE. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • WE WANT A STRONG VISUAL PRESENCE OF PEACEKEEPERS on the day the police come.
  •  500+ PEACEKEEPER T-shirts on Protectors when Police come
    will create a strong visual presence of PEACE and UNITY. 
  • If you come to BENTLEY you can collect your T-shirt for yourself to wear
  • IF you can't come please sponsor one or more T-shirts for Protectors to wear.
  • T-shirts will be printed locally on organic cotton. 

The Impact

Your small contribution will have a huge impact as the WORLD IS WATCHING BENTLEY THIS WEEK. 

  • A Blockade of this kind has never happened before - we are pushing all boundaries on Non-violent Direct Action
  • Protesting Efforts in the Northern Rivers have inspired the world with unique and creative campaigns proving hugely successful
  • We need your presence here even if you cant make it, this is how you can  be here with us, on our very backs.   

Other Ways You Can Help

  • PLEASE Sign our Avaaz Campaign and Share with your friends: 
    • https://secure.avaaz.org/en/petition/UNITED_NATIONS_SECURITY_COUNCIL_and_the_INTERNATIONAL_COMMUNITY_STOP_Martial_Law_against_CIVILIANS_by_the_Australian_and/ 
  • please share this to your friends and family ASAP as we need this T-shirts in the next few days. 

THANK YOU FOR YOUR LOVE  FROM BENTLEY  "For the Earth"

story:
Our Mission

Health & Beauty Product Exchange (H&B ProdEx) is an environmental pilot program, established in Los Angeles, California to provide a database for registered users to exchange or donate their unwanted and/or minimally used Health & Beauty products.
H&B ProdEx program is operated free-of-cost for residents of Los Angeles and surrounding cities, by our pending status non-profit organization: H&B ProdEx Inc.
Our Mission is to help reduce chemical contamination in Southern California's landfills and bodies of water, by sustaining as many unused and/or minimally used H&B products as we possibly can.

How Your Contributions Will Help Us 

Your contributions will help us cover the cost of all legal paperwork, including non-profit 501(c)(3) status application with Internal Revenue Service, and the cost for our IT team to develop and launch our website, which will serve as the main database of available products: www.hbprodex.org

Here are the details of our expenses:

  • All legal paperwork prepared by professional legal services: $950
  • Non-profit 501(c)(3) status application: $850
  • Website developing: $3,800
  • Operation expenses (office rent, transportation, office supplies and equipment, campaign perks, etc.): $2,400
