story:
'Be Constructive, Build the Movement!'

 

What is thePOOSH.org?

At thePOOSH, we are shooting for the stars! We truly believe that sustainable building techniques are a serious, rational and innovative response to some of the environmental challenges that face human kind in the 21st Century.

For thousands of years humans have built houses together and conrtibuted to community structures. For many years people have created and driven the sustainable self-build movement. There are countless people involved in this already, to which we give thanks!

Using volunteers at sustainable build-sites is not a new concept, but a single webplatform is!

'ThePOOSH.org is not creating the movement, rather facilitating a new method of communication to help further develop it through profile creation.

In addition to environmental concerns, sustainable self-builds are a viable, safe and practical option to combat economic difficulties facing mankind today. Commonly constructed using natural, ecological and/or recycled materials, sustainable self-builds are both a desired and essential option worldwide.

Our Vision: Community-driven sustainable construction will simply be known as construction

Our Mission: To inspire and empower people to build economical, sustainable, and community created structures through an active international network of skilled and unskilled volunteers that exchange knowledge, labour, and experiences at sustainable self-build projects. 'Help one another, house one another, sustain life on our planet!'

How does thePOOSH work?

1. There are two types of membership: volunteers (POOSHers) and sustainable self-build projects.

2. Sustainable and natural builders unite around the world by using thePOOSH.org to self-build more sustainable structures.

3. Volunteers and sustainable self-build projects connect with one another as part of our global social networking system, creating a community that exchanges knowledge, experiences and labor.

4. ThePOOSH.org serves as a reference source for sustainable self-build case studies, which can be used for research and educational purposes.

5. ThePOOSH involves as many people as possible. Sustainable self-build construction is achievable by virtually anybody, anywhere in the world, regardless of your previous building experience!

Why we need your help:

For thePOOSH to be successful we require action and capital.

ThePOOSH.org is currently registered as a non-profit in Estonia (reg. number: 80344535). Our team is made up of four Americans, one Estonian, and one Englishman. Our focus from the start has been the internationalization of this idea.  We are currently seeking both private foundation and government support to finance our growth.

ThePOOSH.org intends to provide an inspirational product and service, appreciated by its members who, in return, will donate to support the building revolution!

Our past UK Tour - http://thepoosh.org/veggie-promo-tour

Our upcoming Southern European Bamboo Bike Tour - http://thepoosh.org/southern-european-bamboo-bicycle-tour-2013

Your donations will:

• Help us undertake a serious marketing campaign, publicizing thePOOSH.org worldwide!

• Cover production and administrative costs (such as acquiring U.S. 501(c)(3) status).

• Launch new and exciting projects to help make it more legal and easier
to build sustainable structures anywhere in this planet.

• Provide for living expenses for the POOSH team (we have been working fulltime as volunteers for the last 8 months!) thepoosh.org/meettheteam

• Keep membership to thePOOSH.org free!

 

Other ways to help:

• Visit thePOOSH.org and become a member and part of the sustainable self-build revolution

• 'Like' us on Facebook

• Keep up to date by visiting our blog at thePOOSH.org/blog

• Be active and spread the word

An increasing number of people are becoming concerned with the unsustainable nature of society’s common approach to building and construction.

ThePOOSH  (People's Organization on Sustainable Housing) provides a web platform (thepoosh.org) where people who want to get active in the sustainable self-build movement can meet, connect, network and communicate with the objective to assist one another in self-building sustainable structures.


Thank you for giving us the opportunity to share our vision for this project with you. Together, we can make our society and our environment healthier! We look forward to hearing from you soon!

ThePOOSH Team
Michael, Eric, Loren, James, Leah and Maarja

 



*Perks: Our perks are geared towards sustainable thinking. Therefore, we are more interested in giving away non-material perks, e.g. inspiration, experiences, knowledge, smiles, etc!
story_txt:
'Be Constructive, Build the Movement!'
 

What is thePOOSH.org?
At thePOOSH, we are shooting for the stars! We truly believe that sustainable building techniques are a serious, rational and innovative response to some of the environmental challenges that face human kind in the 21st Century.
For thousands of years humans have built houses together and conrtibuted to community structures. For many years people have created and driven the sustainable self-build movement. There are countless people involved in this already, to which we give thanks!
Using volunteers at sustainable build-sites is not a new concept, but a single webplatform is!
'ThePOOSH.org is not creating the movement, rather facilitating a new method of communication to help further develop it through profile creation.
In addition to environmental concerns, sustainable self-builds are a viable, safe and practical option to combat economic difficulties facing mankind today. Commonly constructed using natural, ecological and/or recycled materials, sustainable self-builds are both a desired and essential option worldwide.
Our Vision: Community-driven sustainable construction will simply be known as construction
Our Mission: To inspire and empower people to build economical, sustainable, and community created structures through an active international network of skilled and unskilled volunteers that exchange knowledge, labour, and experiences at sustainable self-build projects. 'Help one another, house one another, sustain life on our planet!'
How does thePOOSH work?
1. There are two types of membership: volunteers (POOSHers) and sustainable self-build projects.
2. Sustainable and natural builders unite around the world by using thePOOSH.org to self-build more sustainable structures.
3. Volunteers and sustainable self-build projects connect with one another as part of our global social networking system, creating a community that exchanges knowledge, experiences and labor.
4. ThePOOSH.org serves as a reference source for sustainable self-build case studies, which can be used for research and educational purposes.
5. ThePOOSH involves as many people as possible. Sustainable self-build construction is achievable by virtually anybody, anywhere in the world, regardless of your previous building experience!
Why we need your help:
For thePOOSH to be successful we require action and capital.ThePOOSH.org is currently registered as a non-profit in Estonia (reg. number: 80344535). Our team is made up of four Americans, one Estonian, and one Englishman. Our focus from the start has been the internationalization of this idea.  We are currently seeking both private foundation and government support to finance our growth.ThePOOSH.org intends to provide an inspirational product and service, appreciated by its members who, in return, will donate to support the building revolution!
Our past UK Tour - http://thepoosh.org/veggie-promo-tour
Our upcoming Southern European Bamboo Bike Tour - http://thepoosh.org/southern-european-bamboo-bicycle-tour-2013
Your donations will:
• Help us undertake a serious marketing campaign, publicizing thePOOSH.org worldwide!
• Cover production and administrative costs (such as acquiring U.S. 501(c)(3) status).
• Launch new and exciting projects to help make it more legal and easierto build sustainable structures anywhere in this planet.
• Provide for living expenses for the POOSH team (we have been working fulltime as volunteers for the last 8 months!) thepoosh.org/meettheteam
• Keep membership to thePOOSH.org free!
 
Other ways to help:
• Visit thePOOSH.org and become a member and part of the sustainable self-build revolution
• 'Like' us on Facebook
• Keep up to date by visiting our blog at thePOOSH.org/blog
• Be active and spread the word
An increasing number of people are becoming concerned with the unsustainable nature of society’s common approach to building and construction. 
ThePOOSH  (People's Organization on Sustainable Housing) provides a web platform (thepoosh.org) where people who want to get active in the sustainable self-build movement can meet, connect, network and communicate with the objective to assist one another in self-building sustainable structures.
Thank you for giving us the opportunity to share our vision for this project with you. Together, we can make our society and our environment healthier! We look forward to hearing from you soon!
ThePOOSH TeamMichael, Eric, Loren, James, Leah and Maarja
 
*Perks: Our perks are geared towards sustainable thinking. Therefore, we are more interested in giving away non-material perks, e.g. inspiration, experiences, knowledge, smiles, etc!

story:
HELP US SAVE SHARKS! 
(Be sure to click on the gallery above to view the images and be sure to watch the BLOOPERS REEL at the end of the video)

Dr. Glenn R. Parsons,  CFO Parsons Consulting and Professor of Biology.

First, let me thank you for visiting our campaign web-site. Did you know that millions of sharks die each year as a result of commercial and recreational fishing? In many cases, the sharks are not wanted and are taken incidentally by swordfish and tuna fishers. Commercial and recreational fishers would love to have a method for preventing the capture of sharks. They are dangerous to handle, they damage fishing gear, and they slow down fishing operations thus reducing fishing efficiency. This capture of unwanted species is referred to as "bycatch". Bycatch is a global problem that plagues many fisheries, and scientists, partnered with commercial and recreational fishers, are working hard to develop methods to reduce bycatch.

I am Dr. Glenn R. Parsons,  CFO of Parsons Consulting LLC (a very small environmental consulting firm) and Professor of Biology. I hold degrees from The University of Alabama (Birmingham), The University of South Alabama, and The University of South Florida (St. Pete, School of Marine Science). I have researched the basic biology of sharks for the past 40 years along the coasts of Alabama, Florida, and Mississippi. Over the past approximately 15 years, I have focused on the problem of bycatch and recently turned my attention on shark bycatch in the tuna and swordfish fisheries. I feel that the work I am doing on bycatch is perhaps the most important research of my entire career.

As a professor an important part of my job is to train graduate students so they might conduct original research. My role as a mentor to students is without question the most gratifying (and, on occasion, the most frustrating) part of my responsibilities. I am very serious about that role and I have been very fortunate to have excellent undergraduate volunteers and superb graduate students. Training undergraduate and graduate students and conducting research is an expensive undertaking and, lately, funds for research have been difficult to obtain.

WHAT WE NEED AND WHAT YOU GET

Our campaign is simple. At present we are using a boat to conduct bycatch research that is close to the end of its useful life. While our Carolina Skiff is still a good boat, it is 15 years old and starting to show its age in a number of ways. I am mounting this campaign to raise funds to purchase a boat that will allow us to expand our shark research projects and to accommodate a larger number of undergraduate and graduate students.

We will likely purchase another Carolina Skiff but the boat will be 24 feet long and will be better outfitted for the kind of research in which we are presently engaged. The boat will cost approximately $25,000.

We desperately need a new boat and your contribution will be a great help to us and may result in saving the lives of many thousands of sharks.

All of those that donate will receive regular updates about the progress of the shark project. We have some exciting prizes for those that are able to donate at the following levels:

BULL SHARK CONTRIBUTOR $25:  At this level you will receive an autographed personalized copy of Dr. Parsons' book "Sharks, Skates and Rays of the Gulf of Mexico". This book is perfect for identifying the shark you encounter.

    MAKO SHARK CONTRIBUTOR $50:  You will receive the book mentioned above as well as a ceramic coffee mug that identifies you as a Mako Shark Contributor. You will be the envy of your  friends as you sip a hot beverage from your mako cup.

    ADOPT-A-SHARK CONTRIBUTOR $200: This one is really exciting. At this level you will receive a copy of the book mentioned above plus you will adopt a shark. This means that your shark will be tagged with a specially made tag that identifies the shark as adopted. We will send you all of the pertinent information concerning your shark, species, size, where captured, etc. When the animal is recaptured, the tag will inform the fisher that it is your shark and they are encouraged to report the location where captured and release the animal unharmed. We feel that a fisher that captures an adopted shark will be more inclined to let the animal go without harming it.

    GREAT WHITE SHARK CONTRIBUTOR $2,000: At this level we will take you on a shark research trip in the Gulf of Mexico. The waters of the northern Gulf of Mexico are teeming with sharks and we will include you in our research project.  You will have to pay for your travel to Ocean Springs, MS but when you arrive we will put you up in a cottage for two nights and will provide all that you need on the boat. The trip will last approximately 8 hours and you will see dolphins, sharks, many varieties of fish, etc. We obviously have to schedule these trips around weather but we can be very flexible during the summer months.

    WHALE SHARK CONTRIBUTOR $25,000:  This is the big one. You and a companion will spend two nights in a cottage on the coast of Mississippi and will embark on a shark research trip with the shark team as described above. We will video document the trip and will provide you with a copy of the video. In addition, you will be given the privilege of naming the new research vessel. You can name it after your mother or father or wife or husband. You can name it whatever you want as long as it is not inappropriate or offensive. Obviously, the name will be emblazoned on the side of the vessel for all to see. We will actually purchase a boat wrap with your company name and logo  covering the hull .

    If we do not raise the entire amount, the money will be used to either purchase a smaller boat or to renovate our existing boat. If we raise more than our goal, we will use the extra funds for graduate student research projects. These projects have involved everything from shark biology, to paddlefish research, to radio-tracking crappie in local reservoirs.

    THE IMPACT AND OUR APPROACH TO THE PROBLEM

    Please visit the following web site for information on our bycatch research projects:  www.bycatch.net
    OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP
    Maybe you can't contribute money at this point, I know times are hard. However, we still need your help. Send this out to your  friends, family and colleagues. Put it on your facebook page. Help us get the word out. Use the Indiegogo share tools if you are so inclined.
     

    HELP US SAVE SHARKS FROM EXTINCTION!

story:
The Story

At many of the South African nature reserves, the tourist receive a more or less legible A4 paper map which can be quite a challenge to make sense of even for people who are quite used to reading maps.  We want to bring the maps in digital form to your smartphone, tablet or GPS.


What We Need & What You Get

After a very successful pilot study (the video contains data of it) we endeavour to generate mobile maps for as many nature reserves and game parks as possible.  At first the focus will be on South Africa but we are hoping to expand this to other southern African countries. 

The funds will be used to capture all the roads and buildings and process the data.  There are quite a number of parks and reserves to be captured - US$ 3000 will not be nearly enough to capture all of them but will be a great help to get the project started.

The processed data will then be made available online for the public, free of charge.  One of the advantages is that a trip to one of our nature reserves can be properly planned before actually arriving at the nature reserve. 

As the reserves are captured we will post updates on the campaign site as well as on other social media platforms.


Social spin-off

We believe that with proper mobiles maps we can draw more tourist to our nature reserves, especially the not-so-well-known ones.  As reserves and game parks generally employ people from the surrounding communities while an increase in tourists will generate more job opportunities and local revenue.


Conservation spin-off

While the developed world struggles to obtain additional land for conservation, the developing world has land under conservation, which is not necessarily utilised optimally. It is expected that access to the route information in these less well known reserves, will result in more visitors which will contribute to more effective management of these reserves, which often has limited resources compared to more well-known reserves such as the Kruger National Park, Chobe or Serengeti.

These less well known reserves often conserve localised populations of threatened biodiversity or very dramatic landscapes which provide stepping stones and/or corridors for the general movement of biodiversity. In South Africa for instance, there are over 160 provincial and local nature reserves compared to the 22 national parks, therefore there are eight times more provincial and local reserves than national parks, with on average 17 provincial and local reserves per province.

story:
As most of my friends and family know, I have taken an enormous interest in the environmental issues we are faced with. Especially the ocean is suffering from the pollution we - as humans - have created. Since I wanted to do something to help and protect our planet I have come up with the idea to create 'Turtlee Green'. With Turtlee Green I'll provide green alternatives for disposable plastic, organize events to raise money for charities, basically anything that will help going towards a greener future. 

http://turtleegreen.com

To raise some money to launch all this I have decided to sell t-shirts. Since one of the main values of Turtlee Green is sustainability and eco-friendly, we have pledge to make sure that the circumstances of the production is fair. Thanks to the danish company Neutral we can be sure that their products are manufactured according to the highest social, ethical and environmental international standards.

https://www.neutral.com/certified-responsibility/

Also the printing of the shirts is environmental friendly since they use water-ink and recycle it after the process. 

There will be 2 shirts available: 

- 'Turtlee Green' shirt

This is the t-shirt with the entire logo printed on the t-shirt

- 'Just a turtle' shirt

This is the turtle of turtlee green printed on the left chest

Unfortunately for all my international friends. Due to high shipping fees, the t-shirts will only be available in Belgium. Feel free to contact me to find a way to make it work to get you this awesome shirt as well.

My first project will focus on banning the plastic straws, providing stainless steel & paper straws as a substitute. 

Straws are harming turtles and other beautiful creatures that live in the sea. Please, 

"Don't trash where they splash" 

Love,

Axelle

story:
We are raising money to buy 20 new Yamaha motorcycles for National Park Rangers of  Ulaan Taiga. Last year's campaign was very successful and made a big difference in the preservation of a treasured place. Help us reach our goal by contributing. You can give to the cause through the Blue Waves Campaign. 

We thank each and every one of our donors for their support.


Hi I'm Hilary Davis.

I have always enjoyed the beautiful wilderness spaces available to us all in and around California, and am passionate about preserving undeveloped space for wildlife habitat and the health of humans. I have fantasized about exploring other parts of the world, and have always thought that the best way to get to know a place is to go there with a purpose!

Since hearing of this cause I have been moved by the beauty of Mongolia and one of the last, ancient largest freshwater lakes in the world, Lake Hovsgol. The Mongolians call this body of water "The Mother Sea". The Lake and the National Parks around it are unique on this planet, and under threat from poachers and illegal developers tooling around in jeeps and 4x4's.

These parks are patrolled by rangers, mostly on horseback or decrepit old motorcycles. The rangers need better transportation to do their job catching poachers and illegal developers, and the motorcycles they have are old, tired and inadequate. The horses are even less effective.

I am raising funds to buy a motorcycle and gear. On my own dime, I am going to go to Mongolia and deliver them to the rangers in person and show them off road riding techniques.

Ulaan Taiga in Hovsgol Province is a special place that needs preserving and protecting! 

The National Park bigger than Yellowstone at 3,784,130 acres and is strictly protected as a transition zone between Central Asian Steppe and the Siberian Taiga. 5 rivers originate from Ulaan Taiga Mountain Rainge and create the headwaters to Yenisei and Selenge rivers. There are 300 small pristine ancient lakes that are more than 2 million years old, and the water is so clean you can drink it without any treatment.  There are a number of indigenous people that depend on these for their water supply. This park is a water shed for Lake Hovsgol. 

So what's threatening it?

Illegal poaching and over fishing:  The rivers and lakes have fish, including two endemic species, those fish can easily become over fished as every other fish population in the world has become.  The surrounding park lands are home to a number of rare and endangered species, including ibex, argali, elk, wolf, wolverine, musk deer, brown bear, Siberian moose, and sable.

Mongolia has done a good job designating this area as a wildlife preserve to protect the survival of these animals, but enforcement is challenging.  Rangers have been stabbed and injured trying to enforce the law against poachers, who stand to make a great deal of money in the short term.

Illegal Mining: Mongolia is mineral rich and artisanal miners move in destroying and polluting the land and waters. They exploit the region with no regard for preservation of the pristine wildlife. 

Illegal development and tourism: It shouldn't be news to Americans that people in and from outside Mongolia are eager to develop properties in the region.

Rangers have caught individuals simply building around it without permits. Run off and pollution from illegal development and road building is certain to pollute the rivers and lake, as well as impact wildlife habitat.  Additionally outsiders have come in and started developing  tourism projects without regard for the environment and without obtaining permits.

But they have rangers to enforce the laws, right?

Yes, the whole park is about 5,900 square miles (1.5 m hectares) and there are 20 permanent rangers and a few seasonal ones.  Each ranger patrols over 300 square miles of park, which is about the same size as all the boroughs in New York City.  And they do it mostly on horseback.    Imagine if there was only one policeman in a space as big as the five boroughs of New York City, and he was on horseback chasing bad guys in jeeps.

The poachers and illegal users in the park tool around in jeeps, 4x4's, and other vehicles.  Did I also mention the poachers are armed?

The rangers have asked for help by in the form of offroad motorcycles, gear, and training.  With modern offroad motorcycles, they could patrol more effectively and discourage lawbreakers.

This is my Park Ranger and with your help I will be delivering a motorcycle to him.

Bayarkhuu Huuhen

 I started my career as a Cinema Mechanic. I traveled around showing and promoting international and national films, history, culture, religions, traditions and legends of people. It helped me to develop a deep passion for nature and connection to people. When Mongolia transitioned to market economy in 1990s, people started exploiting the nature and environment. I witnessed illegal logging, depletion of rivers and lakes, poaching and greediness of artisanal miners in our Taiga region. As the condition worsened, I wanted to strengthen my devotion to nature by becoming a ranger and promised to make a difference. I patrol 100 thousand acres.


So why do I care, and how can I help?

It's true, Mongolia is halfway around the world, but I care, and here's why:

  • We don't have that many wild places left in the world.  
  • We don't have that much wildlife left in the world.
  • I love motorcycles, and it's not often that my love of motorcycles could have such a huge impact for a good cause.

Even if you aren't moved by this situation, I ask that you support me in my effort to keep this wild area as pristine as possible.   You can help by donating to help cover the cost of  motorcycles and equipment.

Where does the money go?

100% of the money you donate is tax-deductible, and goes to buy and ship the motorcycles and equipment. I am paying my own ticket over, and the Mongol Ecology Center is not taking any of it for administration, it all goes directly to equipment for the rangers! 

I am trying to fund  motorcycles and equipment.  Each motorcycle and equipment, along with shipping, costs $6,500. Indigegogo fees on the total amount are $475 ($6,500+$475 = $6,975.00)   I am trying to raise enough to outfit two rangers.  Any additional money goes to buying a third and eventually fourth motorcycle if I exceed my fundraising goal.  

If I raise additional funds, but not enough for an entire motorcycle and gear, the Mongol Ecology Center has agreed to pool it with the funds raised by other riders to fund another complete motorcycle.
story_txt:
We are raising money to buy 20 new Yamaha motorcycles for National Park Rangers of  Ulaan Taiga. Last year's campaign was very successful and made a big difference in the preservation of a treasured place. Help us reach our goal by contributing. You can give to the cause through the Blue Waves Campaign. We thank each and every one of our donors for their support.Hi I'm Hilary Davis.I have always enjoyed the beautiful wilderness spaces available to us all in and around California, and am passionate about preserving undeveloped space for wildlife habitat and the health of humans. I have fantasized about exploring other parts of the world, and have always thought that the best way to get to know a place is to go there with a purpose!Since hearing of this cause I have been moved by the beauty of Mongolia and one of the last, ancient largest freshwater lakes in the world, Lake Hovsgol. The Mongolians call this body of water "The Mother Sea". The Lake and the National Parks around it are unique on this planet, and under threat from poachers and illegal developers tooling around in jeeps and 4x4's.These parks are patrolled by rangers, mostly on horseback or decrepit old motorcycles. The rangers need better transportation to do their job catching poachers and illegal developers, and the motorcycles they have are old, tired and inadequate. The horses are even less effective.I am raising funds to buy a motorcycle and gear. On my own dime, I am going to go to Mongolia and deliver them to the rangers in person and show them off road riding techniques.Ulaan Taiga in Hovsgol Province is a special place that needs preserving and protecting! The National Park bigger than Yellowstone at 3,784,130 acres and is strictly protected as a transition zone between Central Asian Steppe and the Siberian Taiga. 5 rivers originate from Ulaan Taiga Mountain Rainge and create the headwaters to Yenisei and Selenge rivers. There are 300 small pristine ancient lakes that are more than 2 million years old, and the water is so clean you can drink it without any treatment.  There are a number of indigenous people that depend on these for their water supply. This park is a water shed for Lake Hovsgol. So what's threatening it?Illegal poaching and over fishing:  The rivers and lakes have fish, including two endemic species, those fish can easily become over fished as every other fish population in the world has become.  The surrounding park lands are home to a number of rare and endangered species, including ibex, argali, elk, wolf, wolverine, musk deer, brown bear, Siberian moose, and sable.Mongolia has done a good job designating this area as a wildlife preserve to protect the survival of these animals, but enforcement is challenging.  Rangers have been stabbed and injured trying to enforce the law against poachers, who stand to make a great deal of money in the short term.Illegal Mining: Mongolia is mineral rich and artisanal miners move in destroying and polluting the land and waters. They exploit the region with no regard for preservation of the pristine wildlife. Illegal development and tourism: It shouldn't be news to Americans that people in and from outside Mongolia are eager to develop properties in the region.Rangers have caught individuals simply building around it without permits. Run off and pollution from illegal development and road building is certain to pollute the rivers and lake, as well as impact wildlife habitat.  Additionally outsiders have come in and started developing  tourism projects without regard for the environment and without obtaining permits.But they have rangers to enforce the laws, right?Yes, the whole park is about 5,900 square miles (1.5 m hectares) and there are 20 permanent rangers and a few seasonal ones.  Each ranger patrols over 300 square miles of park, which is about the same size as all the boroughs in New York City.  And they do it mostly on horseback.    Imagine if there was only one policeman in a space as big as the five boroughs of New York City, and he was on horseback chasing bad guys in jeeps.The poachers and illegal users in the park tool around in jeeps, 4x4's, and other vehicles.  Did I also mention the poachers are armed?The rangers have asked for help by in the form of offroad motorcycles, gear, and training.  With modern offroad motorcycles, they could patrol more effectively and discourage lawbreakers.This is my Park Ranger and with your help I will be delivering a motorcycle to him.Bayarkhuu Huuhen I started my career as a Cinema Mechanic. I traveled around showing and promoting international and national films, history, culture, religions, traditions and legends of people. It helped me to develop a deep passion for nature and connection to people. When Mongolia transitioned to market economy in 1990s, people started exploiting the nature and environment. I witnessed illegal logging, depletion of rivers and lakes, poaching and greediness of artisanal miners in our Taiga region. As the condition worsened, I wanted to strengthen my devotion to nature by becoming a ranger and promised to make a difference. I patrol 100 thousand acres.So why do I care, and how can I help?It's true, Mongolia is halfway around the world, but I care, and here's why:
We don't have that many wild places left in the world.  
We don't have that much wildlife left in the world.
I love motorcycles, and it's not often that my love of motorcycles could have such a huge impact for a good cause.
Even if you aren't moved by this situation, I ask that you support me in my effort to keep this wild area as pristine as possible.   You can help by donating to help cover the cost of  motorcycles and equipment.Where does the money go?100% of the money you donate is tax-deductible, and goes to buy and ship the motorcycles and equipment. I am paying my own ticket over, and the Mongol Ecology Center is not taking any of it for administration, it all goes directly to equipment for the rangers! I am trying to fund  motorcycles and equipment.  Each motorcycle and equipment, along with shipping, costs $6,500. Indigegogo fees on the total amount are $475 ($6,500+$475 = $6,975.00)   I am trying to raise enough to outfit two rangers.  Any additional money goes to buying a third and eventually fourth motorcycle if I exceed my fundraising goal.  If I raise additional funds, but not enough for an entire motorcycle and gear, the Mongol Ecology Center has agreed to pool it with the funds raised by other riders to fund another complete motorcycle.

story:
People often look to others to fix environmental problems, blaming only the large corporations and government for the state of the Earth. But each of our daily actions- where we go, what we purchase, our attitudes towards the things we want in our lives and how we get them- all contribute to the state of the Earth. Each of us owns some of the responsibility.

Too many people are completely disconnected from the natural world...

* Did you know there are many children and adults who believe food just comes from the grocery store? Some literally do not realize meat is animals or that vegetables grow in the soil.

* Did you know there are many, especially those who live in cities, who have never touched the ground; who do not know the feel of grass on their fingers or the smell of good, rich dirt?

* Do you realize how many people never consider where the materials for all of the things they own come from; let alone where it all goes when they throw it away?

* Did you realize that far too many people do not understand that water is finite and can be destroyed beyond human use or that we can overuse the land to a point it cannot sustain us anymore?

And knowing these things, is it surprising that too many people on this planet are living in ways that contribute to our unsustainable use of what the Earth provides for us?

Ways of the Earth Living Museum is a unique opportunity to help shift this by immersing people in nature, by helping them better understand where our food comes from and what contributes to healthy land and water, and by bringing the necessities of life- shelter, water, fire and food- into perspective. The Living Museum consists of a community of people living as humanity did for countless generations, living in "primitive" shelters constructed using available materials from the land and using ancient skills such as flint knapping, hide tanning, fire by friction, basketry, pottery and so much more to make what is needed for day to day living. There is no electricity, running water or other comforts of modern living. It is a simple, wholesome lifestyle where what we need comes from the land and we use only what we can create ourselves. The village will have its own gardens with foods grown organically and sustainably as well as extensive use of wild edible and medicinal plants. An underlying theme of the entire community is "caretaking", an approach in which we use the things we need from the land in a way that helps the natural world instead of just taking what we want without regard for its impact. We also accept these gifts from the land with gratitude which helps us focus on our needs and not our wants. Through living this way we can actually make the land healthier by our presence and those who visit the village will see and feel this approach in action.

We attract people through the fun of the Living Museum experience, where people can come and visit for a day, seeing natural history come to life. They'll experience the pace and activities of daily life including food gathering, preparation and storage and the making of things such as tools, buckskins, baskets and pottery. They'll interact with the Residents, asking questions and seeing how things are actually made and used and even try out some of the skills themselves; so much better than viewing artifacts in glass enclosed displays. No item purchased from a store can create a connection with the Earth like making with your own hands the things you need from raw materials harvested in a caretaking manner from the land. It touches a primal place within each of us that bonds us with the natural world, creating a respect and appreciation for what the Earth provides. Visitors can walk our gardens, learning about how foods can be grown to make the soils healthier. They can learn the incredible nutrition and uses of plants most would consider "weeds". They will also see very happy, contented people who live a simple life without modern conveniences but without a sense of hardship. People can also delve deeper, coming for our weekend, week-long and even month long primitive living experiences where they'll experience the lifestyle first hand and learn and put these ancient skills into use.

By sharing this experience we hope to bring people closer to the Earth and to understanding their real needs. We don't expect everyone to run to the woods to live and give up all the modern conveniences, but our hope is they can take home a lesson or two from their experience with us and begin to look at their own lifestyle. Perhaps they might simplify and use less, recognizing the interconnection between the natural world and all the things that make their lives comfortable. Perhaps they'll explore options to grow some of their own food, support organically grown plant foods and humanely raised animal foods or look for local wild edibles. Perhaps they'll explore many other sustainable practices that can support their daily living and benefit the Earth at the same time. We hope to inspire people to get outdoors and appreciate the beauty of the natural world, benefiting in mind, body and spirit from a stronger relationship with nature and taking from that a respect for the Earth and a desire to take action to protect her. We work also to pass on these amazing ancient skills which connect people so wonderfully with the Earth, helping keep them alive into future generations. We hope to help people understand each human's role as a caretaker and subsequently become stronger advocates for the environment in their own communities.

   

THIS CAMPAIGN

We are a non-profit organization and arrived on our land in Indiana in September 2014. Our 240 acre property is in the heart of an area visited by millions of tourists each year for its local outdoor activities and covered bridges. We have the potential to touch the lives of thousands of children, families and adults each year.

We are now working toward our opening in May of 2015. We've been living on the land through the winter constructing primitive shelters and all the tools and other things needed to live off the land. We are working on the designs and will be building community areas including a long house, gardens and areas to work on specific 

skills such as flint knapping and hide tanning, a primitive archery range, bow making workshop and tracking areas. All of these things we can do without cost, but there are other projects on the land that are necessary for us to open to the public which do require funding. Currently our entry road is only dirt which makes it inaccessible during wet weather- something we have plenty of around here! We've applied for a donation of the gravel needed but need donations to complete the road; paying for hauling the gravel and the bulldozer work that needs to be done for its completion. In addition we need to install a well and restroom facilities. We have the skills to create the village, but without your help, we cannot complete the projects needed to begin to share this experience with the public. We have a large local event planned for April and your donation will also help demonstrate that others find this project of value and help us leverage donations from the local community.

story:
Over 1040 Rhinos have been poached in South Africa this year, but we have been able keep our Rhino's safe, having not lost any to poaching in the last 7 months. We need your help to keep our teams feed, so that we can continue to protect them.

The Black Mamba APU was founded by Transfrontier Africa (NPO) and was create to protect Olifants West Nature Reserve in Balule starting off with a team of 6, now a year later the Black Mamba APU has grown to cover the entire Balule area. The Black Mamba APU is the first of its kind, being that the majority of our teams are women. 

We operate in an open system and our directly connected to the Kruger National Park. We are therefore custodians of the wild animals that roam freely throughout Balule Private Nature Reserve and the Greater Kruger National Park.

Anti-Poaching is a major need in the area. We are constantly plagued by rhino poachers and bush-meat poachers. Apart from Antelopes other endangered species such as wild dogs and cheetah are also often the victims to snaring. Our dedicated teams are constantly deployed and managed to search and destroy poacher’s camps, wire-snares and bush-meat kitchens every day and this is where you come in. 

Ration packs cost $65 per person per month, any donation that you can afford will enable us to continue to supply food to all our teams whilst they are on duty. Keeping them strong, fit and able to continue protecting the reserve and its wildlife.

story:
Who We Are:

We are Amanda and Andy Bramble. We have been restoring our 38 acre property in Cerrillos, NM, for the last ten years. In 2008, we began Ampersand Sustainable Learning Center, where we offer internships, classes and events, and retreats. We also share our experience through blogging and our website. We focus on Passive Solar Design, Greywater Recycling, Rain Catchment, Permaculture, Natural Building, Appropriate Technologies, and Land Restoration.

We are dedicated to the land, to self-sufficiency, and to community. We do this because it brings us joy. 

"Ampersand is a gem. Lots of practical, low-cost, high-positive-impact examples of sustainable strategies that work. The proof–the wonderful folks that implemented these strategies, live with, use and evolve them regularly. You won’t find glossy projects here, much is made with salvaged and on-site materials. Thus it is accessible to everyone, full of heart, and real. A big reason why I stop by regularly to get re-juiced and inspired."

Brad Lancaster, Author of Harvesting Rainwater for Drylands, Vol 1 and 2

"I can't imagine a more deserving project. These folks not only do great work, but they live it and use every opportunity to teach it. If we are going to love and heal the land and our communities Ampersand is a living example of how to go."

Joel Glanzberg, International Permaculture Instructor

This Project

A railroad bed that was built in the 1890's runs through our property. It unnaturally channelized floodwater and created a big erosion problem. A crucial element in our recent restoration work was to provide a new flood way to cut through this old railroad bed. In 2011, we installed water harvesting and erosion control measures in an area where the water historically and naturally flowed before the railroad bed was constructed.

For a while, the newly constructed rock and brush structures did their job, collecting sediment, encouraging the establishment of vegetation, and creating a stable location for the side channel to meet up with the main floodwater drainage. The restoration was working well for normal rain events for our area, but  no one knew the extent of the flooding that was still to come. On September 17, 2013 a record flood blasted through the town of Madrid, just upstream from us, and damaged the work done here too.


Now we have the challenge and opportunity to upgrade the design of these flood structures. We are blessed with the support of Bill Zeedyk, author of Let the Water Do the Work. He's basically a genius, a wizard of the land and waterways. He has toured the damage and contributed his design experience to help us come up with a good plan to repair and improve upon the project. 

Now we will install new combinations of storm water harvesting and grade control structures, and once again, gather dozens of volunteers to help implement this project while learning how to restore their own lands. It’s all about getting water into the soil and regrowing our native wild lands!

Since the September flood, we have been looking for grants and government funding.  We are not finding anything. We have been honored in the past to receive generous grants from both the Partners for Fish and Wildlife and the New Mexico Environment Department. A lot of work and funds have gone into creating the restoration aspect of Ampersand, and in particular the water mitigation project focused on the railroad bed. We won't let this all this past work go to waste because of this abnormal flood damage! We will learn from it as a community and continue to move forward -- and that's why we are asking you to help us now.

Our goal of $5000 for this campaign will help us hire the backhoe we need to contour the land and transport rock from the main arroyo to the places where we need to build these structures. It will also allow us to get all the tools we need to supply our volunteers and feed them well for our work days. It will take at least 6 work days for a crew of 8 to 10 volunteer workers to finish this project, beyond the backhoe work.

Now is the time! We need to take care of this land before another flood makes the damage worse. And we want to keep our learning center up to date so that others can see watershed restoration in process. People come to us for learning about this. We have all the expertise we need, all the project management skills, even all the rocks! Please help us with the funds. You can trust us to put them to good use. And we will do it right away.

It's a Short Campaign!

We are just doing this for the short month of February- only 28 days! This is to reduce impact on ourselves, and you. Let's just get this done. Please donate what you can now, and forward this to your friends so that we can reach our goal and get started on the work. No more wringing our hands about getting ready for flood season. Let's get started already.

About the Perks

Check out the complete perks list on the right-side column!

We will be spending our evenings crafting away to make you wonderful hand made gifts (see pics below and below again) as thank you's for your contributions.

All donors will receive their names listed on our website and email updates on our project's progress including when it sees its first flood.


This is a great opportunity to visit our site as you can attend a class for free this summer with $100 donation or more. And bring a friend!

Those of you who give $500 or more will receive special sponsorship recognition on our website.

For even higher level donations we will treat you very, very well - check out the list of perks on the right.

No matter how much we raise, we are dedicated to repairing this land. When we bought this land in 2004 we knew there would be much work to do. We have been working steadily to restore the land and make a model of sustainability for us to live within. The amount of work we have done on our acreage, and the amount of people we have educated here speaks for our commitment to the health of the lands of our region.


Other Ways You Can Help

To raise this amount of money, we need to reach more people. Please help us spread the word by forwarding this campaign with a personal note to your friends and colleagues. Share on Facebook. Or use the share buttons below.

And, send us an email if you want to lend some hands on support. We will be sure to invite you to our work parties, and feed you very well. Our email is ampersandproject@yahoo.com.

your contributions. All donors will receive their names listed on our website and email updates on our project's progress including when it sees its first flood. This is a great opportunity to visit our site as you can attend a class 
for free this summer with $100 donation or more. And bring a friend!Those of you who give $500 or more will receive special sponsorship recognition on our website. For even higher level donations we will treat you very, very well - check out the list of perks on the right.No
 matter how much we raise, we are dedicated to repairing this land. 
When we bought this land in 2004 we knew there would be much work to 
do. We have been working steadily to restore the land and make a model of sustainability for us to live within. The 
amount of work we have done on our acreage, and the amount of people we 
have educated here speaks for our commitment to the health of the lands 
of our region.Other Ways You Can HelpTo raise this amount of money, we need to reach more people. Please help us spread the word by forwarding this campaign with a personal note to your friends and colleagues. Share on Facebook. Or use the share buttons below.And, send us an email if you want to lend some hands on support. We will be sure to invite you to our work parties, and feed you very well. Our email is ampersandproject@yahoo.com.

story:
Who We Are and Why We're Doing This?

Our goal is to transform agriculture and mitigate climate change. We believe we can do this while providing food and other products through the creation of agroecosystems that function at the highest level of biodiversity and ecosystem services - the “epitome of sustainability.”

The Apios Institute, the organization running this campaign, exists to share experience and information about perennial crop polyculture systems in all climates of the world. The Apios Institute works through a collaborative network of farmers, gardeners, and researchers, sharing inspiration and filling critical knowledge gaps regarding the design and management of these systems.

Our current Wiki has worked for thousands of people in cold climates -- but it is incomplete. Many people around the world have asked us to expand to include other climates. 

Our all-volunteer team has been hard at work since 2007. We are all practitioners and “plant geeks”. None of our board have ever been paid, nor do we have paid staff. Apios revenues come through memberships and sponsorships, and 100% of these funds go to pay for web hosting and design. 

For a taste of the amazing wiki our members have already created, check out these top pages:

Perennial Crops

• Asimina triloba - pawpaw - Banana-custard flavored cold-hardy fruit!

• Castanea pumila - Chinquapin chestnut. A sweet and productive bush nut.

• Dioscorea polystachya - Chinese yam. A hardy relative of the tropical yams. An excellent perennial vine root crop.

• Chenopodium bonus-henricus - Good King Henry. A perennial lead anf shoot vegetable for partial shade.

Food Forest Sites

• Central Rocky Mountain Permaculture. A high-desert, cold-climate perennial polyculture market garden and demonstration center.

Polycultures

• Butternut-Concord Grape. A living trellis polyculture producing nuts and fruit.

• Turkish rocket broccoli production polyculture. A productive perennial vegetable system!


Why Does the Wiki Focus On Agroforestry?

Multistrata agroforestry systems go by many names - food forests, edible forest gardens, tropical homegardens, and more. What they have in common is their structure - multiple layers of vegetation, typically one or more layers of trees, with further layers of shrubs, vines, herbaceous species, and often fungi and/or livestock.

These “agroforests” can be at a tiny backyard scale or big enough to cover 50-70% of entire islands. Contemporary commercial examples include coffee and cacao under nitrogen-fixing shade trees. Multistrata systems go back 13,000 years in Java, and today are practiced on an estimated 100 million hectares globally (247 million acres), mostly in the humid tropics. Home-scale systems appear quite viable in cold climates, but models of commercial cold-climate hard to find - in deed development of such systems is one of our goals.

Scientists have called tropical homegardens “the epitome of sustainability” and have identified many benefits of these systems:

  • Multistrata agroforestry systems sequester outstanding amounts of carbon - some as high as 40 tons per hectare per year (t/ha/yr). This compares extremely favorably with often-recommended carbon farming strategies like no-till (0.3 t/ha), “regenerative organic” annual crops (2.3), and managed grazing (0.3). Some even sequester carbon at faster rates than adjacent natural forest!
  • Tropical homegardens have the highest levels of biodiversity of any human land management technique. For example, Mesoamerican homegardens average 348 species per hectares (149/acre).
  • In some cases these systems produce more food than monocultures - sometimes much more! For example, in Brazilian oil palm monocultures, oil yields average 5 t/ha. Polycultures of oil palm, with the addition of fruiting vines, nitrogen-fixing trees, and other elements, produce 8.7 t/ha of oil, plus the additional products!

The very complexity that makes these systems so fantastic makes them hard to study, and greatly slows their spread. Outside of the tropics models are few and far between.

How Does the Wiki Address Crops and Polycultures?

Polycultures (“guilds” to permaculture practitioners) are cultivated plant systems which include at least two species. They are generally designed for minimum competition and maximum cooperation between the component species. They also need to be optimized for easy harvest and management.

Polycultures are the building block of multistrata agroforestry systems. Large farm- and landscape-scale systems may repeat one polyculture across the landscape, while smaller home-scale systems are a patchwork mosaic of polycultures. However, resources to help design perennial polycultures are few and far between, regardless of climate.

We founded the Apios Institute to address the challenges we’ve heard over and over from practitioners and aspiring practitioners. These seem to be the case across climates, at least where intact tropical homegardening traditions are not widespread.

  • It is hard to find information on perennial crops and support species, the great majority of which are rare in cultivation.
  • It is sometimes very challenging to combine species into polycultures.
  • Few case studies of gardens, farms, and productive wild “reference ecosystems” are available for use as models or inspiration.

Apios is a place for growers and enthusiasts to share personal experience, observation, and research. How do these crops perform for you? What polycultures have you planted, and how are they working out? What’s the design of your site, and what have you learned from it about establishment and ongoing maintenance? Apios contributors, as “roving reporters”, also share observations of gardens, farms, and wild ecosystems of interest that they visit (even if they themselves have no garden or farm at the moment). 

Why collect sample polycultures? First, it is challenging to design new ones, and borrowing open-source designs from others is a great place to start. Members will be able to search for polycultures suited to their site (climate, soils) and their goals (fruit production, nitrogen-fixation, etc). Searching for fruiting shrub polycultures for cold and dry or humid tropical climates will greatly stimulate adoption of these practices.

How Is the Wiki Organizing Polyculture Data?

There is another even more compelling argument for collecting sample polycultures. It is becoming clear to us that, while there may be an infinite number of possible polycultures, they seem to cluster under a few basic patterns.  The redesign of the wiki will include these basic clusters, and enable tagging so that together we can develop an international user-generated pattern language of polycultures.

What are some examples? Well, around the world we see the pattern of nitrogen-fixing trees being used as living trellises for edible vines. Wherever you live, this could work for you. So even if there is not yet an example of this polyculture in your climate, you can generate one more quickly once you understand the pattern. Don’t worry - you’ll also be able to filter out results from other climates if you just want to see things that work where you live.

What We Need & What You Get

The overall estimated cost of this wiki transformation is $15,000.

  • We have spent $5000 so far, almost completely funded by membership signups and one time donations. A big thanks to all of you who continue to support, use and improve the wiki each day!

  • We are aiming to raise $10,000 from this campaign. Every dollar counts! If we exceed our goal we can make more, and more rapid, changes.

  • We’re confident this campaign will be successful, and the plan is to also seek any remainder of the funding for the wiki from membership revenue, loans, and advertising.

  • Your contribution is going towards building a powerful tool for regenerating the world and solving global climate change. 

  • AND you also get fantastic rewards for your support, like: a Two Year Membership to the wiki for $50; or how about a Care-Package of Organic Forest Garden Fruits for $250; and what could be more exciting than a Full Permaculture Site Design for your property (in continental US) for $10,000 ($20,000 value)... and many more rewards to choose from!

  • Whatever contribution we receive from supporters like you will go towards:

    • Enhanced and modernized website that works on any computer and any mobile device;

    • Improved user-friendliness like easy image uploading;

    • Expanded reach globally instead of just cold temperate regions;

    • A new release of 600 useful global plant species profiles for 100% free public access;

    • Expanding the database uses and functions for wiki members.

Why Does it Matter?

The Apios Institute online wiki exists to accelerate the dissemination of information about the use of perennial crops and agroforestry systems, which will increase the adoption of these systems across the globe AND support their ongoing research and development. 
This community and user-driven research platform will make it possible to share information globally, across similar climates around the world, and uncover crowd-sourced global meta-patterns. 
There is no other platform like Apios in the world—where else can you learn about a thriving home agroforestry system in Ninilchik, Alaska?


What We've Been Working On

The Apios Institute has an 8 year track record of leading the way for online user-generated perennial agriculture databases. 
Along the way we have generated and shared content for 741 species, over 181 polycultures, and over 55 global sites. 
Not to mention, The Apios Institute’s board members and wiki contributors are actively working across all climates and demographics to establish and further the ongoing study and use of perennial crops and agroforestry systems.

We Are Ready to Turn Challenges Into Opportunity

Two years ago during a strategic planning meeting, we realized that the wiki in its current form would not achieve our goals of affecting global climate change. It was only focused on one region, and the design was outdated.

That inspired us to see an opportunity to expand globally. We hired a web design team that rocks, who do cutting-edge work for the global agriculture community. 

Raising the money of course is a big challenge, and yet at the same time, this campaign also allows us to get the word out about this amazing wiki resource, and to share the power of agroforestry and perennial crops with more people.

Even if we don't meet our campaign goals, we will seek loans and continue at the slower pace that revenue from memberships allows. 

Other Ways You Can Help This Apios Campaign

We understand some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Please help us get the word out through your networks by using the Indiegogo share tools on this page.
  • Become a "Wiki Work Trader". Post your garden and farm information on the Apios wiki and get a free membership in exchange for agreeing to post once a month.

  • We love volunteers with a clear idea of what they can offer. Contact us and we will plug you into the project!

story:
WHO ARE WE?

The Rural Renewable Energy Alliance (or RREAL for short!) is a 501(c)3 solar energy nonprofit based in northern Minnesota. With the mission of making solar energy accessible to people of all income levels, RREAL is pioneering the use of solar technologies to address energy poverty throughout Minnesota and the greater Midwest.

WHAT IS "PLUG INTO ARRAY OF SUN"?

"Plug into Array of Sun" is RREAL’s newest Adopt-a-Module project. We are making 148 solar photovoltaic (PV) modules available for sponsorship. A new twist on the Buy-a-Brick model, Plug into Array of Sun offers the opportunity to adopt (or sponsor) a panel on one of two solar arrays installed in northern Minnesota. By sponsoring a module, you can help our short and long-term efforts to deliver solar energy to under-resourced families and individuals across the region.

Proceeds from Plug into Array of Sun will go toward connecting the installed solar arrays to the grid to power our workplace and reduce our carbon footprint. Once installed, we estimate the systems to produce over 8,400 kilowatt hours annually, and the long-term energy saving will help support our Solar Assistance program which equips low-income households with solar energy systems as a solution to energy poverty.

Since its founding in 2000, RREAL has installed hundreds of solar energy systems for under-resourced communities and households living in energy poverty. In 2014 alone, RREAL equipped 60 residences with solar energy systems, empowering 34 households with solar electricity and 26 households with solar heating. As we continue to grow this impact across the Midwest and beyond, we are looking to you for your help! By joining this effort, you can help us create positive change for families, communities, and the environment.

From our grassroots beginnings refurbishing solar collectors in a garage, to a full-fledged 501(c)3 nonprofit, we have demonstrated a commitment to clean energy and social equity. 

Though still small, we dream big. This spring, we are trying out our first campaign with IndieGogo and need your help to make it a success!

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Not able to adopt a module? There are a number of levels at which you can contribute. Also, by simply sharing this effort with others, you create awareness for solar energy and help foster a new, sustainable way of thinking about social and environmental challenges.

Please share Plug into Array of Sun on your Facebook, Twitter, or whatever other social media you like to use, and follow our journey on RREAL’s Facebook and Twitter.

story:
Keep scrolling down to find out….

  • How one MAGIC partition equals up to 6 competitive inventory items.
  • What makes MAGIC’s shipping product similar to the Golden Gate Bridge.
  • How MAGIC can save up to 80% of storage space.
  • How easy it is to become a MAGIC Stakeholder.

Section 1 - The Campaign for MAGIC Packaging Reducing EPS Foam in Landfills

Millions of cubic feet of foam end up in US landfills yearly discarded from consumer direct Wine and Beer shipments. Magic Packaging (MAGIC) has a preliminary patent for an environmentally friendly, 100% recyclable packaging product. Our die cut shipping partition is made with materials that contain recycled materials that will be marketed to companies interested in opportunities to save natural resources with “Green” sustainable solutions. The initial products are for wineries, breweries and third party fulfillment companies that ship wine and beer direct to consumers using parcel delivery services. The MAGIC Partition will save the business 50%-80% in storage space and cost no more than existing shipping systems. MAGIC and its distributor have invested over $20,000.00 (materials, tools, testing) and devoted almost 2,000 hours to develop the patentable design that will be used for many packaging and shipping needs in the future. In addition to the provisional patent for the design, MAGIC has registered the trademark “GOT MAGIC?” and completed the necessary ISTA* tests for wine and beer package shipping.

*ISTA – International Safe Transit Association

Section 2 - MAGIC vs. Other Shippers/Materials

MAGIC has designed a bottle partition to be used inside a corrugated outer shipping box that incorporates similar physics to a suspension bridge where forces acting on the bottles contained in the shipping system are redirected into the shipping box, as the bridge would redirect force into the earth. This design protects the bottle(s) from each other and outside impacts. The “patent pending” technology eliminates the need for bulkier space consuming products like non-recyclable foam, molded pulp/fiber or other void fill materials. A more in-depth description follows (in Sec. 5).

Section 3 - Use of Donor Funds 

The majority of the money will be for product production - die cut corrugated and sized recyclable plastic for initial inventory – the partitions will need to be purchased in truckload volumes (60,000+ units) and each size of boxes in volumes of 10,000 to be price competitive. Some funds will be used to purchase dies for the partitions, specially designed heat sealers and environmentally friendly strapping equipment.

MAGIC has a relationship with an existing packaging distributor that has invested a lot of money and time in the development of our partition. This distributor has many years of experience with the food and hospitality industries, big box and internet retailers, and the beverage industry and will have the responsibility of channel sales, marketing, and logistics for MAGIC brand products. 

Section 4 – MAGIC   vs.        Existing Wine/Beer shipper partitions

    

 

Section 5 – The MAGIC Design

Plastic oriented on die cut corrugated acts similar to the roadway on this bridge diagram with force arrows in red.

Die cut corrugated acts like the bridge towers and transfers forces acting on the wine/beer bottles (from the attached plastic) to the corrugated shipping container represented below by a plexiglass box (so you can see inside the shipper).

 

Surface of die cut restricts bottle movements like a “take out” drink carrier (pictured above).

One partition works for most bottle sizes: wine/tall beer, small beer/dessert wine, and standard size magnums.

(shipping box size changes with size and quantity of bottles)

Partition has perforation in center so for odd number of bottles you tear the partition in half to ship odd number quantities - 1 bottle, 3 bottle  (even 9 bottle shipments).

 

The beverages pictured above were purchased retail and do not reflect an endorsement from the producer, its affiliates, distributors or third party relationships. However we would appreciate it if you ask your favorite winery or brewery if they "GOT MAGIC?" and thanks for your support!

"The MAGIC Guys"

 

Section 6 – Miscellaneous

MAGIC will initially market wine and beer shippers (partitions and shipping boxes) for 1,2,3,6,12 bottle shipments of wine and “tall” beers. In addition, depending on market needs, shippers with the same partition can be made available for 4, 9 bottles of wine and tall beers, 6 and 12 bottles of regular size beer or desert wine and 3 bottles of standard size magnums. MAGIC also has a shipper (possibly the World’s only), that will ship a full case of wine or tall beer in their retail box* or 24 bottles of standard size beer in their retail box via UPS, GSO and most other shipping companies that use the ISTA 3A standard. The full case shippers require a different partition, also covered by the MAGIC preliminary patent.

*Retail box must have partitions

Section 7 - Perks

Cinch Bag with 'Got Magic?' screen print logo

Wine/Beer Stopper with 'Got Magic?' printed logo

Neoprene 2 Bottle Wine Carrier with 'Got Magic?' screen print logo

Corkscrew and bottle opener with 'Got Magic?' Logo

Stakeholder Perks

$25.00 - 1 year MAGIC updates with discounts on Magic branded “GOT MAGIC?” gift items or products including special offers from beer/wine $1,000.00 Stakeholders and Associates

$50.00 - 2 years MAGIC updates with discounts on Magic branded “GOT MAGIC?” gift items or products including special offers from beer/wine $1,000.00 Stakeholders and Associates

$100.00 - 4 years MAGIC updates with discounts on Magic branded “GOT MAGIC?” gift items or products including special offers from beer/wine $1,000.00 Stakeholders and Associates

$1000.00 - “Forever” discounts 

-       3-5% off the (then) current price level on all Magic brand products ordered and priority (front of the line) scheduled shipping at no additional cost. 

-       $50.00 off the (then) current price of 100ea custom printed cinch bags (restrictions apply) As many orders of a 100ea or in multiples of a 100ea. (eg. 200, 300, etc.). Yes, as many as you want!

How MAGIC can save up to 80% of storage space.
How easy it is to become a MAGIC Stakeholder.
Section 1 - The Campaign for MAGIC Packaging Reducing EPS Foam in LandfillsMillions of cubic feet of foam end up in US landfills yearly discarded from consumer direct Wine and Beer shipments. Magic Packaging (MAGIC) has a preliminary patent for an environmentally friendly, 100% recyclable packaging product. Our die cut shipping partition is made with materials that contain recycled materials that will be marketed to companies interested in opportunities to save natural resources with “Green” sustainable solutions. The initial products are for wineries, breweries and third party fulfillment companies that ship wine and beer direct to consumers using parcel delivery services. The MAGIC Partition will save the business 50%-80% in storage space and cost no more than existing shipping systems. MAGIC and its distributor have invested over $20,000.00 (materials, tools, testing) and devoted almost 2,000 hours to develop the patentable design that will be used for many packaging and shipping needs in the future. In addition to the provisional patent for the design, MAGIC has registered the trademark “GOT MAGIC?” and completed the necessary ISTA* tests for wine and beer package shipping.*ISTA – International Safe Transit AssociationSection 2 - MAGIC vs. Other Shippers/MaterialsMAGIC has designed a bottle partition to be used inside a corrugated outer shipping box that incorporates similar physics to a suspension bridge where forces acting on the bottles contained in the shipping system are redirected into the shipping box, as the bridge would redirect force into the earth. This design protects the bottle(s) from each other and outside impacts. The “patent pending” technology eliminates the need for bulkier space consuming products like non-recyclable foam, molded pulp/fiber or other void fill materials. A more in-depth description follows (in Sec. 5).Section 3 - Use of Donor Funds The majority of the money will be for product production - die cut corrugated and sized recyclable plastic for initial inventory – the partitions will need to be purchased in truckload volumes (60,000+ units) and each size of boxes in volumes of 10,000 to be price competitive. Some funds will be used to purchase dies for the partitions, specially designed heat sealers and environmentally friendly strapping equipment.MAGIC has a relationship with an existing packaging distributor that has invested a lot of money and time in the development of our partition. This distributor has many years of experience with the food and hospitality industries, big box and internet retailers, and the beverage industry and will have the responsibility of channel sales, marketing, and logistics for MAGIC brand products. Section 4 – MAGIC   vs.        Existing Wine/Beer shipper partitions    

 
Section 5 – The MAGIC DesignPlastic oriented on die cut corrugated acts similar to the roadway on this bridge diagram with force arrows in red.Die cut corrugated acts like the bridge towers and transfers forces acting on the wine/beer bottles (from the attached plastic) to the corrugated shipping container represented below by a plexiglass box (so you can see inside the shipper). Surface of die cut restricts bottle movements like a “take out” drink carrier (pictured above).One partition works for most bottle sizes: wine/tall beer, small beer/dessert wine, and standard size magnums.(shipping box size changes with size and quantity of bottles)Partition has perforation in center so for odd number of bottles you tear the partition in half to ship odd number quantities - 1 bottle, 3 bottle  (even 9 bottle shipments). The beverages pictured above were purchased retail and do not reflect an endorsement from the producer, its affiliates, distributors or third party relationships. However we would appreciate it if you ask your favorite winery or brewery if they "GOT MAGIC?" and thanks for your support!"The MAGIC Guys" Section 6 – MiscellaneousMAGIC will initially market wine and beer shippers (partitions and shipping boxes) for 1,2,3,6,12 bottle shipments of wine and “tall” beers. In addition, depending on market needs, shippers with the same partition can be made available for 4, 9 bottles of wine and tall beers, 6 and 12 bottles of regular size beer or desert wine and 3 bottles of standard size magnums. MAGIC also has a shipper (possibly the World’s only), that will ship a full case of wine or tall beer in their retail box* or 24 bottles of standard size beer in their retail box via UPS, GSO and most other shipping companies that use the ISTA 3A standard. The full case shippers require a different partition, also covered by the MAGIC preliminary patent.*Retail box must have partitionsSection 7 - PerksCinch Bag with 'Got Magic?' screen print logoWine/Beer Stopper with 'Got Magic?' printed logoNeoprene 2 Bottle Wine Carrier with 'Got Magic?' screen print logoCorkscrew and bottle opener with 'Got Magic?' LogoStakeholder Perks$25.00 - 1 year MAGIC updates with discounts on Magic branded “GOT MAGIC?” gift items or products including special offers from beer/wine $1,000.00 Stakeholders and Associates$50.00 - 2 years MAGIC updates with discounts on Magic branded “GOT MAGIC?” gift items or products including special offers from beer/wine $1,000.00 Stakeholders and Associates$100.00 - 4 years MAGIC updates with discounts on Magic branded “GOT MAGIC?” gift items or products including special offers from beer/wine $1,000.00 Stakeholders and Associates$1000.00 - “Forever” discounts -       3-5% off the (then) current price level on all Magic brand products ordered and priority (front of the line) scheduled shipping at no additional cost. -       $50.00 off the (then) current price of 100ea custom printed cinch bags (restrictions apply) As many orders of a 100ea or in multiples of a 100ea. (eg. 200, 300, etc.). Yes, as many as you want!

story:
Short Summary

Bats are often put into the category of creepy crawly species, and associated with fear and mystery. But did you know that bats help keep the ecosystem healthy, and help us by keeping our agricultural lands pest-free?

According to the Canadian Wildlife Federation, a typical colony of 150 Big Brown Bats consumes 38,000 cucumber beetles, 16,000 June bugs, 19,000 stinkbugs and 50,000 leafhoppers in just one summer. By keeping bug populations in check, bats help keep the natural balance of the ecosystem, and act as a natural pesticide.

However, bats all over North America are in grave danger. A fungus called White Nose Syndrome has killed approximately 6 million bats since it was first discovered in 2006. The Canadian Wildlife Federation is one of many organizations working tirelessly to slow and stop the fungus's devastation.

What We Need & What You Get

Bats need our help now more than ever! This Halloween, the Canadian Wildlife Federation (CWF) is inviting people to throw bat-tastic fundraisers to raise money to help save Canadian bats. Instead of a party, I started this Indigogo campaign with the hopes of reaching a wider audience and spreading the message of the bat. All funds raised will go to the CWF to support their bat research and public outreach initiatives.

**PLEASE NOTE that I am not directly affiliated with the CWF, but am merely a supporter of their work and initiatives.**

I am a student studying wildlife conservation, and my first internship was working to build bat houses and educate the public on living in harmony with bats. Since then, bats have stolen my heart!

As well as studying conservation, I am a wildlife photographer. As a thank you for donating to this cause, I am offering the following:

~ Donation of $15 or more: A high-quality digital copy of an image of your choice that you can print and hang at home
~ Donation of $50 or more: A high quality 8x10 print of an image of your choice, sent to your home

See my photography here: facebook.com/alenasphotography

If you have any personal questions for me, please do not hesitate to contact me through my facebook photography page!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please visit HelpTheBats.ca to find out more about this issue and how you can help Canadian bats!

Please share this cause with your friends on Facebook, Twitter, and other social media. Thank you so much for your support!

story:
Without the pollinators, a vibrant, diverse, and beautiful environment is impossible!  For our sake and the health of the future of Planet Earth, we (all of humanity) must immediately deal with the issues that threaten the honey bees, butterflies, and all beneficial insects, as well as the health of the air, the soil and the water.  


We are seeking donations to enable the creation of a state-of-the-art music video which will be a fun and inspiring sing-along, filmed on the Garden Island of Kaua`i.  The soundtrack being featured is called “Owed To The Honey Bees” and is a happy love song to the honey bees and to all of nature. 

So, with this in mind The Honey Bees Project, through the media of song, video, and storytelling, offers the opportunity to experience the power of expressing gratitude as a path toward positive change.

To hear “Owed To The Honey Bees”, and for more information about our cause, please visit our website at:  www.beebuzzz.org 

Our website has payment options for your donation, including how to donate by check or money order. 

Mahalo Nui Loa for your love and support of the pollinators!
