story:
Kampanya ile ilgili Türkçe bilgi için: http://yelkouanshearwater.org/tr/yelkovan-yuva-... 

Campaign Summary

A mysterious seabird, trying to survive and raise its fluffy chicks against many human-related threats…Yelkouan shearwater is one of the most secretive and yet a threatened seabird species in the Mediterranean Basin. Turkey has high potential in terms of breeding Yelkouan pairs yet any discovered colony mainly due to the difficulty of the fieldwork.

I am planning to undertake an intensive fieldwork with comprehensive techniques in Turkish Aegean coast with the aim of locating breeding grounds of these vulnerable species.

I am a biologist and a seabird lover, passionate about Yelkouan shearwaters. I am studying this species in the Bosporus since 2010. Currently I am a PhD student in Bogazici University.

The Bird (Yelkouan Shearwater)

These remarkable birds are close relatives of albatrosses and endemic to the Mediterranean Basin. There are many unknowns about this species such as its precise distribution and breeding locations. 

Yelkouans are breeding on remote and rocky coastal and offshore islets, and on the mainland. These birds often chose well-hidden burrows and crevices in mostly inaccessible parts of the islands and visit breeding colonies only at night in order to protect their eggs from predators. For this reasons, locating breeding sites is very though job.

Turkey has high potential in terms of breeding Yelkouan shearwater colonies thanks to relatively abundant pelagic fish species in its unique marine environment and its long coastline. Yelkouans are plentiful in Turkey; we broke a record last year and counted 90000 birds flying towards the Aegean in 4 hours. Yelkouans are migrating to Black Sea after raised their chicks and then spreading back to their breeding colonies in winter. It is commonplace to encounter Yelkouans in Turkish waters during the year yet the breeding grounds remain mystery.

Like many seabird species, Yelkouan shearwaters face with rapid global population decline, because we are over-exploiting their food resources (fish) and breeding grounds (coastal habitats) and because we are introducing predators (rats), which are steeling the one and only egg of these seabirds in breeding colonies.

The Work (Discovery)

Despite the increasing number of ornithologists and bird watchers in Turkey, to date, just a small number of researchers had intended to discover Yelkouan colonies. They all failed because of the difficulty of this work and limited techniques they used. In this project I am planning to use wide range of techniques in order to locate these birds’ breeding sites.

The planned work contains rope access and night work at cliffs on remote islands. I will be inspecting all vertical cliff faces in order to find suitable burrows and crevices by abseiling from the top of the islands during the day. As many islands that I will work have high sea-facing cliffs, it is impossible to access some parts without rope work.

As Yelkouans are active at night, in order to increase the efficiency of this work I will be spending a whole week on each island without any access to basic living conditions. I will listen out for prospecting birds visiting their nests during the night and also locate sound recorders in order to increase the effort.

The Needs

I only need good equipment to conduct this project. Shearwater colony fieldwork requires rope access and night work on remote islands. Thus I will spend a whole week in each small and remote island during winter months and probably face with strong weather and living conditions. I need good climbing and camping equipment in order to secure myself during the fieldwork. 

A detailed list of these equipments can be found here.

The Impact

First of all your contribution will encourage young researchers -especially female ones- to implement even such difficult and extreme work in Turkey.

With this campaign, you will not only contribute to the discovery of breeding colonies which is a long-lasting plea from European conservationists but also you will lead a long-term conservation project on Yelkouan shearwaters in Turkey -in the case I succeed.

Risks and Challenges

If I fail to reach my goal, I will still go for this discovery by paying as much as possible on my own for necessary equipment but apparently it will be ill equipped thus carrying high risks.

You can follow the news on the discovery from project website and Facebook page. 

Other Ways You Can Help

You don't have to pay money for this campaign. If you prefer, you can buy or donate climbing or camping equipment. If you prefer to donate, please contact me. 

You can also contribute largely by sharing campaign's page with related people or organizations.

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
The Project

The Earth is currently experiencing a mass extinction, fueled by alterations in the earth’s atmosphere, rapid land development, and resource mismanagement. In the process, we are losing crucial systems which will need to be recovered by the restoration ecologists of tomorrow. But those scientists will require an identifiable historical standard to work from.

RARE Tomorrow is a non-profit organization creating a virtual reality archive of critically endangered ecosystems. Put simply, we design fully immersive references to guide future scientists tasked with restoring ecological systems, as well as to educate people today.  

In 2018 we completed the field work for the Washington State feasibility project and in 2019 began engineering the online VR platform. The field team will continue their work in 2020 with the filming of all critically endangered ecosystems found in the contiguous United States. RARE Tomorrow will debut the Washington State pilot project in the fall of 2020, with the rest of the contiguous US to follow in the winter of 2021.

We’ve already raised half of the field budget. All we need now is 30,000 dollars to ensure we can successfully capture each of the critically endangered systems. We hope to have the funding in place to be able to start fieldwork in time for summer.

 

Rewards

We are keeping this simple. First, we have two ways to show your support to the world around you, a sticker and a badge. We're pretty excited about both, but to be honest that badge really does something to all of us here at RARE. Might be all those merit badges we didn't earn. Then at the founding member level and above, you’ll receive a gorgeous, one-of-a-kind landscape photo of one of the endangered sites you’re helping to preserve, plus a badge to stitch onto your backpack. Just a little something to remind you of the important work you’re helping to fund. 

At all levels of support, your names will be added to the list of people who helped create this crucial archive, but let’s be honest; the real reward is to be part of an international effort to save this visual information for the next generation. 

If you don’t have the money to pitch in, share the link and spread the word. The more of your friends, family, and co-workers who know about this campaign, the better.

 

Risks & Challenges

Honestly, the risks are low. We have the information and are building the relationships we need to make sure we have access to these landscapes. Our big hurdle is funding.

story:
Story
 This fall, House Alive, one of North america's most experienced earthen construction teaching organizations, will travel to a remote, ethnically Tibetan region of India, deep in the Himalayas. With a small group of apprentices, we will build a small cob (earthen) house to be used as a sanctuary at a children's community called Jhamtse Gatsal. Jhamtse Gatsal, which means, "Garden of Love and Compassion" is a community of 85 orphaned and/or disadvantaged children, plus teaching, cooking and caring staff, and volunteers from around the world. 

My Goal 
 I am going to be one of the volunteers and my intention is to learn how to build a beautiful earthen sanctuary and use the knowledge to practice and then teach appropriate, affordable, environmentally friendly construction methods that helps to save the Earth and brings new, healthy, more happy and natural ways of living.
My vision is to use Sacred Geometry in my building plans to increase peoples awareness and spirituality, to bring peace and into each and every bodies hearts. 
What I need 
I would love to ask for your support which is received with deep gratitude. You are supporting the spread of environmental sustainability, education, community, love and happiness. 
If you cannot help financially, please pass my campaign on to your friends, families and associates through email and social networks.

story:
The Story

Between 1990 and 1994, Rwanda was undone by violence on an unimaginable scale. This led to the flight of nearly two million refugees, most of whom ended up in refugee and transit camps in nearby countries. As millions of people return to Rwanda they are forced to live in impermanent communities with inadequate building materials, electricity, food and water. Because of Rwandaâ€™s high population density, all land was cleared for agriculture and pasture, leaving the only remaining natural resources within national parks and reserves. With the lack of building materials and electricity, the need for massive amounts of wood for fuel and timber has resulted in communities resettling in protected areas, rapidly depleting Rwandaâ€™s already scarce natural resources and further contributing to the lack of clean water as erosion from deforestation worsens. Conservation and development organizations, as well as the Government of Rwanda, are aware of these problems but have struggled to address them. Little research has attempted to understand the extent of impact the conflict had on Rwandaâ€™s environment.

Where I Come In

After having spent a year conducting conservation field research in Madagascar, the Comoros and Equatorial Guinea, I recognized that successful conservation requires understanding regionally-specific political and cultural dynamics (a coup in Madagascar, longstanding political instability in the Comoros and a sovereign dictator in Equatorial Guinea). For example, marine conservation in the Comoros requires acknowledgement of the fact that  nearly everyone living on each of the Comorian Islands relies on marine resources as their primary source of protein. Few supply ships pass by these islands, and ecotourism remains an unviable option due to the continued political instability. From these experiences, it became clear that working in international conservation in central and southeastern Africa at the community level is, without a doubt, what I want spend the rest of my life doing. To work more effectively in these regions I decided to return to graduate school to improve my research skills and acquire useful conservation tools like remote sensing and GIS, all of which will enable me to put ideas into action.

Through a Masters Program in Conservation Biology at Columbia University, I am researching the impacts of the Rwandan civil war and genocide on deforestation. Using satellite images I am able to quantify the extent of deforestation and answer questions like â€˜how extensive has the resettlement of refugees in, or near, protected areas been?â€™, â€˜how severe is the loss of forest resources as a result?â€™ and â€˜what is the capacity for these forests to recover?â€™. The results of this research will directly impact local conservation and development organizations, as well as the Rwandan government, to be used in planning and rebuilding. Due to natural disasters, climate change and warfare, human movement and resettlement continues to increase. Understanding the consequences of this movement and how it may burden the environment can help us better mitigate the impact and manage natural resources upon which we depend.

Why Your Support Is Needed

By analyzing satellite images of Rwanda from the present day and the past I can quantify the extent of forest area prior to the conflict, and determine where and how much has changed. However, this satellite image-based analysis cannot be done entirely remotely. To ensure the accuracy of my work, and provide publishable and usable results, my research requires traveling to the sites in Rwanda that I am analyzing. By doing what is called ground truthing I can validate what is represented in current images, enabling me to also better infer what is presented in earlier images. Without on-the-ground field work, it is impossible to validate my research. Additionally, working with conservation organizations while in Rwanda will ensure that my research is useful and relevant to their work. Several local and international conservation organizations, along with the new government, are already working hard to protect Rwandaâ€™s forests and their biodiversity. My research findings and recommendations will be made available to each of these groups so as to directly improve future on-the-ground conservation within protected areas and manage forest resources.  

As a graduate student in a two-year Masters program, traditional sources of research funding (government funded grants, private scholarships, etc.), particularly for international field work, are scarce and extremely difficult to obtain given the limited time constraints. Your support will make it possible to complete my work and connect it directly to on-going efforts in Rwanda.

Your donations go directly to funding research travel and field work costs. With a goal of raising $5000, I am budgeting for the cost of a $2000 plane ticket, $800 for travel while in the country (since my research will require traveling to three different sites throughout western Rwanda), $200 for research permits and $2000 to pay for living expenses. The Great Ape Trust in Gishwati Forest Reserve, an area I will be working in, has kindly made their office and field station available for my research needs for a small fee. Additional funds will be used to pay for travel to two additional research sites: Nyungwe National Park and Volcanoes National Park. Every penny raised will go directly towards covering these costs.
story_txt:
The Story

Between 1990 and 1994, Rwanda was undone by violence on an unimaginable scale. This led to the
flight of nearly two million refugees, most of whom ended up in refugee and
transit camps in nearby countries. As millions of people return to Rwanda they
are forced to live in impermanent communities with inadequate building
materials, electricity, food and water. Because of Rwandaâ€™s high population
density, all land was cleared for agriculture and pasture, leaving the only
remaining natural resources within national parks and reserves. With the lack
of building materials and electricity, the need for massive amounts of wood for
fuel and timber has resulted in communities resettling in protected areas,
rapidly depleting Rwandaâ€™s already scarce natural resources and further contributing
to the lack of clean water as erosion from deforestation worsens. Conservation and
development organizations, as well as the Government of Rwanda, are aware of
these problems but have struggled to address them. Little research has
attempted to understand the extent of impact the conflict had on Rwandaâ€™s
environment. 


Where I Come In

story:
Please scroll down for English!!..

Sürdürülebilir Kırsal Yaşam Projesi Nedir? Neye hizmet eder? Nereden ilham alır?

Sürdürülebilir Kırsal Yaşam Projesi Tangala Keçi Çiftliği'nin ev sahipliği yaptığı bağımsız bir projedir. Kırsal yaşam ve üretim biçimlerini destekleyen bir grup gönüllü insanın iradesi, desteği ve arzusu ile başlatılmıştır. 

Hayvancılık, sürdürülebilir sebzecilik ve kültürler arası etkileşim, bu projenin hizmet ettiği ve esinlendiği başlıca alanlar. Yöresel hayvancılık, özellikle keçicilik ve üretim biçimleri özel ilgi alanımız. Bu bağlamda peynir sevdalısıyız:)

Bu proje için farklı ülkelerden birçok insan gönüllü olarak çalıştı. Projenin bir amacı da, sürdürülebilir kırsal yaşam deneyimlerimizi daha çok gönüllüyle paylaşmak. Burada ağırlayacağımız misafirler, sadece gözlemci değil aynı zamanda gönüllü katılımcılar olacaklar.

Hep birlikte atölye çalışmaları ve festivaller düzenlemek, hayvancılık ve süt ürünleri alanlarında araştırmalar yapmak, doğal malzemelerle barınak yapımı için projeler oluşturmak, gönüllülük prensiplerinin kültürler arası etkileşimini araştırmak ve arttırmak istiyoruz.

Doğal malzemelerle barınak yapımı Sürdürülebilir Kırsal Yaşam Projesinin bir parçasıdır. 

Proje dahilinde bir kerpiç ev tamamladık. Çalışma alanımızda, evin hemen yanından çıkartılan toprak, dereden akan su ve komşu tarlalarda üretilen buğdayların samanı kullanıldı. 

Taş ve kerpiçten yapılan bir diğer doğal yapı ise gönüllü eviydi. Bu evin içerisine yöresel ve geleneksel bir barınma biçimi olan keçi kılından yapılma çadırlar koymaya karar verdik. Köyde sayıları azalmış olsa da hala kıldan çul dokuyan nineler var. Yerel ve doğal malzemelerle hazırlanacak kıl çadırlarda gönüllü ziyaretçilerimizi ağırlayabileceğiz.

2013 Ağustos ayında başlayan çalışmalar sonunda projenin %90'ını, Tangala Keçi Çiftliği'nde gönülden gayretle çalışan bir kaç hayalperest olarak tamamladık.

Kerpiç Ev: Keçilerin serbest yaşadıkları 2,5 dönüm alan içerisinde 35 m2 bir kerpiç ev(tamamlandı)

Peynir Atölyesi: Gönüllü evinin altında 60 m2 peynir atölyesi ve mahzen (tamamlandı)

Gönüllü Evi: 220 m2 gönüllü evinin içinde bir ortak tuvalet/banyo ve iki kıl çadır,mutfak ve toplantı alanı (İnşaat tamamlandı, iç bölümlerde eksikler var)

Şimdi kalan eksiklerimiz için destek olmak isteyebileceklere bir çağrıda bulunmak istiyoruz. Desteğiniz ile gönüllü evinin aşağıdaki eksikleri tamamlanacak;

* Zemin ve çadırlar için kıl çulların ördürülmesi.

* Kıl çadırların dikilmesi.

* Ortak mutfak ve tuvalet / banyo kaba inşaatı tamamlandı. Mekan içi eksiklerin tamamlanması.

* Toplantılar ve atölye çalışmaları için kullanılacak olan ortak salonun ısıtma ve mutfak alt yapı ihtiyaçları.

Göstereceğiniz en ufak destek bile bizim için çok önemli. Şartlarınız elverdiği kadar maddi katkı sağlayabilir, projemizi FB ve Twitter'da duyurabilir, bize mesaj yazıp yüzümüzü güldürebilirsiniz!

Projemize belli miktarlarda destek olmak isteyenler için birkaç armağan da hazırladık, bunları proje sayfasının sağında görebilirsiniz.

Sesimizin duyulmasına lütfen destek olun. Çok teşekkürler.

Kırsal Yaşam Gönüllüleri

<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<

What is the Rural Life Project? What does it serve to? Where does it take its inspiration?

Sustainable Rural LifeProject is an independent project which is hosted by Tangala Goat Farm. This project is initialized by the will, support and desire of a couple of volunteer people. 

Because we love animals they are at the heart of our project. Regional animal breeding, specifically goat breeding and dairy farming is our special interest. Simply we are cheese lovers:)

Many volunteers all around the world worked in this project. One of the aims of this project is to share our sustainable rural living experiences with more volunteers. In this project the guests will not only be observers but in the mean time will be voluntary participants.

We want to organize workshops and festivals, make research on animal breeding and dairy products, organize and support sheltering projects with natural materials, make contribution to the cross-cultural interaction of voluntary principles. 

Making shelter with natural materials is a part of Sustainable Rural Life Project.

We constructed a cob house during this project. In our work area we used the soil from the land, the water from the trench and the straw bales from the neighborhood.

Another construction made with natural materials is a guesthouse. We decided to put goat hair tents into a stone/mud house that we build. The old women of the village knit these tents with traditional methods from goat hair. We will be able to host our volunteer guests in these tents. 

This project started running in August 2013 and we –a couple of dreamers- completed 90% of the project by “heart working” in Tangala Goat Farm.

Cob House: 35m2 cob house located in the 2,5 hectares of land where the goats live freely (completed)

Cheese make room:Under the guest house there is another unit with a cheese make room and cellar inside (completed)

Guesthouse: 220m2 stone building with 2 tents, a kitchen, a bathroom and a meeting area (Construction completed, still working on the interior construction and set up.)  

Now for the parts that are incomplete we would like to make a call for those who would like to contribute. With your contribution the guesthouse will be completed;

• Women will thread yarn from goat hair and knit the haircloths

• The tents will be produced

• Common kitchen and toilet construction is complete; the interior construction will be finished.

• The groundwork for heating and kitchen of common area, which will function as a meeting, festival, presentation and workshop unit, will be finalized.

Even a little contribution will be much appreciated. You can contribute by financial support, by broadcasting our project on FB and Twitter or you can send us a message just to make us smile!

We also prepared some gifts for some amounts of support. You can find more information on the right side of the project page.

Share our project and let our voice be heard. Thank you so much.

Rural Life Volunteers

story:
Hello, I'm Kenzi Burnett and I live in Charleston WV with my Fiance. We are living in 1 of the 9 counties affected by the chemical spill into the Elk River from a plant by the name of Freedom Industries. The chemical which is a cleaning agent used in the coal industry spilled into the river directly above our water company and main source of water in the community. We are now on week 4 and the water is still not safe for drinking, showering, cooking, etc. Both my Fiance and I work at Olive Garden as servers and were forced to be out of work for over 9 days due to all of the restaurants in town being closed. We are now back to work but not getting much business due to the fact that people still dont trust the local water that the restaurants are using. We are running out of water, money, and patience. Our health is at risk and we have no one trust. We have decided to move closer to family that can help us in our time of need and get us back on our feet. We need to live in a place where we can use our water without the fear of getting sick! We are looking for donations to help us finish out our bills here and afford a moving truck to get us across country to Utah. This is the first time we have ever done something like this and we understand that not all of our friends and family will be able to make a donation but If you could please SHARE this for us we would greatly appreciate it! We need all the help we can get. Moving is not a cheap thing and we need to be out of this state as soon as possible so that we can have access to a healthy lifestyle again! Thank you for taking the time out of your day to read this and if you choose to donate THANK YOU ahead of time!    

   Kenzi Burnett

story:
Tragedy at Schoharie Creek, Esperance NY 12066
 
 
I am honored for the opportunity to write to you of my concerns:
 
There were 19 homes on the Schoharie Creek at Priddle Road in Esperance NY on August 28th, 2011.  With the advent of Hurricane Irene and the subsequent flooding two remained, one was abandoned.  So it is just that one.  It's been almost a year and things are getting worse.  Much worst than anything which you may  have heard.
 
"Would you care to be involved in kind charitable contribution:  A donation itself to help re-establish someone in a life they formerly had?"
 
My home on the creek and in my family for 43 years:  Gone; it was 21 feet high and the "wave" that came through the valley seemed to be 24 foot (as evidenced by "burnishing and scouring marks" left up on the larger trees that survived).  The NYS Water Authority said the water was travelling at 50 miles per hour!
 
Nothing was left:  About two or three weeks later while raking glass debris, asbestos, asphalt, fiberglass insulation, and other flood debris I realize it was "my rake" that was in the mud-room prior to the hurricane that I was using.  The house completely gone - and somehow the rake remained; how did that survive?
 
Otherwise a total loss:  No one else is re-building on the creek. The rebuild is estimated at $90,000.
 
Difficulties abound:  Even if I could afford to rebuild - It is a real concern for the increased tax burden.  I had "grievance" year after year to get the taxes (upon my retirement) down to about $100 per month.  So in every respect I cannot afford to rebuild anything too costly.  I am now in my 60's on a Social Security pension of $869/month.  That is a real difficulty.
 
When my home was first built it was only $5,500 and my father and I would improve it basically any way we wanted when we had the money to do so.  Now with all of the additional regulations everything is so costly it is prohibitive, (in every sense of the word).  My father since passed.
 
My elder sister is an administrator for health care:  She presupposes that everyone there has a PTSD [Post Traumatic Syndrome Disorder].  She's probably right - as I feel "crushed," actually "frozen," and greatly troubled by the times.  I need some assistance and the more people I ask the less help I get.
 
Your involvement in this endeavor would not only be a Godsend, and greatly appreciated, yet it would also serve as an example of what can be done:  A good example.
 
It would encourage an entire community to rebuild.  This would endear an entire community to you.
 
Can you, would you help?
Kind regards, sincerely
Raymond Lucas
 
P.S.  It has been reported that over 30 houses in that community have been destroyed.  And over 300 homes in the county (Schoharie).  I believe "hand in hand" it would be a great bit of charity:  Showing care and giving hope.
 
All of this devastation and destruction has not been reported well in the newspapers and media.  The houses being basically "completely" gone, makes for nothing to take (‘good’) photographs of:  No tilted houses, no ‘water-marks.’  As a result it has been largely over-looked, ignored, and that is a shame; and a pity.  Please make a presence of yourself.  I hope Mr. Sean Penn or Mr. Robert DeNiro will read this.  God will never forget.  And I for one will be grateful forever.
* * *
 I come from the building trade in roofing, siding, and framing.  But at my age "I can’t wrap my head around all that needs to be done."  (I can still pound nails.)  Pardon, I don't like to admit that but I feel lost.  I am living with my daughter, in New Jersey and really want to get back Upstate New York.  I believe you may be able to empathize with my feelings.  In the community, I was the one that would help anyone and freely repair their leaking roofs.  While I have helped so many others - now, it is I who need help.
 
The new restrictions in “over”-building the foundation have my hands tied on the expenses of the home.  If you could provide any funds, I could do the roof, pay for the foundation, and be able to get in by the autumn sometime late.  Being benevolent and kind would only be seen as glorious in the eyes of The Lord.  Will you help, please?
 
 
 
Monday, August 29, 2011 9:49 PM
 
Valuation:

228 Priddle Rd, Esperance, NY 12066
$95,200 est. value
story_txt:
Tragedy at Schoharie Creek, Esperance NY 12066
 
 
I am honored for the opportunity to write to you of my concerns:
 
There were 19 homes on the Schoharie Creek at Priddle Road in Esperance NY on August 28th, 2011.  With the advent of Hurricane Irene and the subsequent flooding two remained, one was abandoned.  So it is just that one.  It's been almost a year and things are getting worse.  Much worst than anything which you may  have heard.
 
"Would you care to be involved in kind charitable contribution:  A donation itself to help re-establish someone in a life they formerly had?"
 
My home on the creek and in my family for 43 years:  Gone; it was 21 feet high and the "wave" that came through the valley seemed to be 24 foot (as evidenced by "burnishing and scouring marks" left up on the larger trees that survived).  The NYS Water Authority said the water was travelling at 50 miles per hour!
 
Nothing was left:  About two or three weeks later while raking glass debris, asbestos, asphalt, fiberglass insulation, and other flood debris I realize it was "my rake" that was in the mud-room prior to the hurricane that I was using.  The house completely gone - and somehow the rake remained; how did that survive?
 
Otherwise a total loss:  No one else is re-building on the creek. The rebuild is estimated at $90,000.
 
Difficulties abound:  Even if I could afford to rebuild - It is a real concern for the increased tax burden.  I had "grievance" year after year to get the taxes (upon my retirement) down to about $100 per month.  So in every respect I cannot afford to rebuild anything too costly.  I am now in my 60's on a Social Security pension of $869/month.  That is a real difficulty.
 
When my home was first built it was only $5,500 and my father and I would improve it basically any way we wanted when we had the money to do so.  Now with all of the additional regulations everything is so costly it is prohibitive, (in every sense of the word).  My father since passed.
 
My elder sister is an administrator for health care:  She presupposes that everyone there has a PTSD [Post Traumatic Syndrome Disorder].  She's probably right - as I feel "crushed," actually "frozen," and greatly troubled by the times.  I need some assistance and the more people I ask the less help I get.
 
Your involvement in this endeavor would not only be a Godsend, and greatly appreciated, yet it would also serve as an example of what can be done:  A good example.
 
It would encourage an entire community to rebuild.  This would endear an entire community to you.
 
Can you, would you help?
Kind regards, sincerely
Raymond Lucas
 
P.S.  It has been reported that over 30 houses in that community have been destroyed.  And over 300 homes in the county (Schoharie).  I believe "hand in hand" it would be a great bit of charity:  Showing care and giving hope.
 
All of this devastation and destruction has not been reported well in the newspapers and media.  The houses being basically "completely" gone, makes for nothing to take (‘good’) photographs of:  No tilted houses, no ‘water-marks.’  As a result it has been largely over-looked, ignored, and that is a shame; and a pity.  Please make a presence of yourself.  I hope Mr. Sean Penn or Mr. Robert DeNiro will read this.  God will never forget.  And I for one will be grateful forever.
* * *
 I come from the building trade in roofing, siding, and framing.  But at my age "I can’t wrap my head around all that needs to be done."  (I can still pound nails.)  Pardon, I don't like to admit that but I feel lost.  I am living with my daughter, in New Jersey and really want to get back Upstate New York.  I believe you may be able to empathize with my feelings.  In the community, I was the one that would help anyone and freely repair their leaking roofs.  While I have helped so many others - now, it is I who need help.
 
The new restrictions in “over”-building the foundation have my hands tied on the expenses of the home.  If you could provide any funds, I could do the roof, pay for the foundation, and be able to get in by the autumn sometime late.  Being benevolent and kind would only be seen as glorious in the eyes of The Lord.  Will you help, please?

story:
Toronto Youth Environmental Council (TYEC) is a youth-led, non-profit organization in Toronto, Canada, focusing on promoting environmental sustainability among youths and connecting a variety of schools in the GTA together. TYEC is made up of a group of passionate youth who hope for a greener city. To achieve this, we run events throughout the year and connect with environmental councils across high school; we hold monthly meetings for school representatives, who are a part of their respective school environmental advocacy group, in order to create an environmental connection throughout the city. Not only do we provide a space for students to come up with innovative solutions to current environmental problems and to network with like-minded peers, we also provide support for students  to create new environmental groups within their school by organizing fun and effective events in the city to engage students in environmental issues, allowing youths to gain knowledge about the issues facing our generation.

We are currently fundraising for the 2015 new year. Any funding will go directly to support our upcoming Toronto Sustainability Business Competition in March and our the Amazing Race in June, as well as the bi-monthly Eco-leadership conferences throughout the year. Please support us with your kindness, and every dollar received will be greatly appreciated and utilized.

story:
A swim to raise awareness and funds to save sharks by supporting the shark sanctuary campaign and promote marine protection in the San Francisco Bay and Pacific Ocean. (see write up in Bay Nature)

Short Summary

Shark populations are threatened globally from over fishing and the shark fin trade. Sharks are critical for ocean health, and ultimately human health and that health is in decline.  We fight for sharks and the health of critical habitat in the San Francisco Bay and Pacific Ocean.

Creating marine protected areas- Shark Sanctuaries- in regions critical for feeding, reproduction and nurseries will help maintain populations that are impacted elsewhere. The San Francisco Bay is one such critical region where several species of sharks are feeding, breeding and giving birth in the Bay.  These sharks are fished outside the gate, but also face impacts in the nursery from fishing, pollution and habitat loss. We need to work abroad to protect sharks but we can start at home.

Supporting our swimmers will help us gain press, but also fund a student intern to help research into how best to protect local species of shark and habitat. These funds will support a science intern's work compiling fisheries records and shark population data into a comprehensive report to the California Department of Fish and Wildlife to support shark and marine protected areas.

Trophic cascade art by Lily Williams http://lilywilliamsart.com/

What We Need & What You Get

  • We are seeking $3000 to pay a student intern to research shark fisheries records in the Bay region, evaluate historical population and catch and help us make recommendations to fisheries managers on how best to protect local shark populations through a shark sanctuary
  • We have several perks including a Sharktober Wildlife Expedition to the Farallon Islands- seeking sharks, whales, sea birds and learning more about our Sanctuary. 
  • All donations are entered into a drawing for a free trip to the Farallon islands lead by Shark Stewards director David McGuire and other experts.
  • Your gift will support a student, help advance them into master's candidacy, and the research will justify marine protection in the Bay
  • The report will help us to protect sharks and critical habitat in the Bay and help create the first shark sanctuary in North America.
  • If we do not reach our goal the campaign will continue and we will use these funds to help find a match to support our intern.  As a project of part of the Earth Island Institute all funds are tax deductible to the extent  provided by the law. 

The Impact

Protecting sharks protects the health and balance of fish populations and marine ecosystems. Our short video and social media push during the swim will help the world recognize that sharks are in trouble world wide and need our help. Our Indiegogo last year helped us produce a short documentary Swim For Sharks (excerpted in last years trailer) screened in the San Francisco International Film Festival and elsewhere. We will be adding material from the swim to our high definition conservation adventure film to reach a broader market across the Pacific to raise global awareness for sharks.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Make some some noise about the Swim for Sharks campaign through twitter, Facbook, instagram and other social media.
  • Invite your friends and come to our shark benefit party  or other sharktober events this year, or join us for our swim next year!
  • Watch for our other events and campaigns to protect sharks
Consider donating to support our other work here and in Asia.
  • You can also use the Indiegogo share tools!
This campaign is raising funds on behalf of Earth Island Institute, a verified US nonprofit. The campaign does not necessarily reflect the views of the nonprofit or have any formal association with it. All contributions are considered unrestricted gifts and can't be specified for any particular purpose.

story:
Mill Creek Restoration Project

The sandstone cliffs, ravines, rock outcroppings, and streams at Mill Creek illustrate the diversity and grandeur of natural resources right here in Southwestern Illinois.

Mill Creek, a high quality natural area, was purchased at auction in 2012 to prevent development or over-harvest of the timber resources associated with the site. The property sits immediately adjacent to Swayne Hollow Nature Preserve and is in close proximity to Piney Creek Ravine Nature Preserve. 

In addition to hosting a high quality dry-mesic upland forest, the site boasts a Grade A Category 1 sandstone cliff /canyon community which has sheltered plants such as club moss, cinnamon fern, and bishop’s cap for eons. These plants are more typically located in northern Illinois and southern Wisconsin.

A restoration plan has been developed but we need your help to finish the project!

How you can help

We are in need of local funds to finish the restoration project so everyone in our region gets the opportunity to experience the area’s richness. 

Raising these funds will leverage $34,000 in state and federal habitat restoration funds.

OUR FUNDRAISING GOAL: 10,000

Three things you can do today to help us reach our goal:
1) Donate to the Mill Creek Restoration Project
2) Tell all your friends, family, neighbors, co-workers about the project.
3) Continue to share with others the story of Mill Creek.

Mill Creek Stewards

Everyone has their own definition of what stewardship means to them. Stewardship often evokes a sense of personal responsibility for ensuring that natural resources are managed not only for our own quality of life, but for future generations as well. 

As a Mill Creek Steward, you join our efforts in investing in the nature of Southwestern Illinois through charitable contributions. Your support matters and your investment stays where you live, work and play.

Recognition of Stewards

For any donation amount, you will receive:

1) Personal, hand-written thank you letter from the leadership at HeartLands Conservancy.

2) Certificate of recognition from HeartLands Conservancy that celebrates your stewardship.

3) Be recognized on HeartLands Conservancy’s website and newsletters.

For donations of $250 or more, we’ll also send you a high-quality, 8x10 photo print of Mill Creek Nature Preserve.

    Project Goals - What needs to be done to restore Mill Creek?

    Streambank Restoration - Mill Creek, a biologically significant stream, runs through the property and is experiencing streambank degradation near it’s confluence with Piney Creek. 

    · Restoration efforts will stabilize 375’ of streambank, improving water quality within Mill Creek, as well as the greater Mary’s River watershed.

    Forest Stand Improvement - A forest management plan has been developed for Mill Creek Natural Area, indicating needs in the following two areas: 

    · An overabundance of less desirable tree species, including sugar maple, elm and boxelder, exists throughout the site. Efforts will include removal of less desirable species on 100 acres to encourage regeneration of native oaks and hickories.

    · While invasive plant species are not overrunning Mill Creek Natural Area, their presence is certainly well documented. Invasive plant species management will be conducted on 100 acres.

    Habitat Restoration - Fifteen acres of the site have been cropped for several decades. Much of this acreage is within the floodplain and would benefit by being converted to native habitat.

    • 15 acres will be enrolled in the Conservation Reserve Program and will be planted to native trees.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Working together to help make some noise about this campaign will lead to its success. Please join us in our efforts to restore Mill Creek by getting the word out, donating and using the Indiegogo share tools to ensure our message is shared.

story:
Because so many of you were asking to continue to purchase the incredible, organically sourced tanks, crops and hoodies for our EcoKarma campaign, we have started a new campaign for the next month. Every dime goes towards planting more coral and taking care of the ocean. All products are ethically sourced by Tagulan and features original artwork by Eoin Finn.

Please note: When it comes to the apparel, you can now either receive your perk by post in which case you will be asked about your shipping address + the shipping costs will be added to the total or you can pick up your perk in person in Vancouver (more details to follow) and you will not be charged for shipping costs. Keep an eye out for the description of the perk to see which is which. 

~

I spend a lot of time in oceans around our planet.  I've waded through plastic bags to get to waves. I've watched entire eco systems disappear when our coral reefs bleach. I've shed tears when I've seen ocean animals emerge with plastic in their guts. Years ago, I realized that I could no longer revel in my ocean time, without doing something actionable to give back.  

Let’s leave a legacy of positive change for the oceans of past and future generations.  Let’s deepen our connection to each other and restore our bodies and hearts while restoring the ocean. Join me at an Eco Karma event or support us with a donation or purchase of any of our incredible, ethically made Eco Karma products!!!  I've created the hand drawn Ganesha surfing the waves of life, specially for this occasion and I am so stoked to share it with you. From the bottom of my heart, THANK YOU! 

What is Eco Karma?

I've always been inspired by Karma Yoga, which is about finding your higher self in service to others. These teachings helped me develop Eco Karma Yoga: devoting our selves in service of nature.  Since 2014, I have been bringing yogis to ocean shores in Florida, Bali, Australia and Hawaii. We've cleaned beaches, transplanted coral and restored native plant habitats.  In the process, we have realized that our yoga is so much more than giving back to our bodies. 

In 2019 we have eco karma projects lined up in Hawaii and Bali. We will remove plastic from the ocean, restore fish stocks and transplant coral. We will do it as a collective community, and commit to living our life with more awareness and kindness every day so we can reduce our impact on our planet.  

Why the Coral Reefs?

We are so intimately connected to the ocean. Every tear and every drop of sweat comes and goes from the ocean. Every second breath we take is produced by  plankton. Our oceans are the source of countless life forms. And within then, coral reefs are like the rain forests of the ocean.  They cover a mere 1% of the ocean floor yet are home to approximately 25% of all marine life!

Today coral reefs around the world are in danger.  Some estimates show how approximately 10% of the world's coral reefs are dead, and about 60% of the world's reefs are at risk due to human-related activities. By the 2030s, 90% of reefs are expected to be at risk from both human activities and climate change.

Connect to your Higher Porpoise!

The main work of my life is to make sure that Nature remains the deepest source of our mental, physical and spiritual health. I see the ocean as my temple and my playground.  Perhaps for you it's the mountains, or the rivers, or the lakes.  No matter what feeds your soul, I want us to connect our LOVE for ecology with both the physical yoga practice and selfless service of Karma yoga.  Thank you once again for fueling my birthday with LOVE.  

We so APPRECIATE YOU and are committed to living a life of mindful awareness so we can continue to leave our children and their children a sustainable home on which to dwell.  

With peace + aloha,

Eoin Finn.

Love is the Ultimate Renewable Resource!

And if you were wondering... what is BLISSOLOGY? 

Blissology is about tuning into the the wisdom of our innermost heart so we can stay connected to not just our bodies but to our personal relationships, to our communities, and to Nature.  There is a still place within, a source of infinite joy, love and bliss. When we are in touch with this place life ceases to be merely about us and we feel deeply connected to the well -being of our body/mind, our personal relationships, our community and nature.  Blissology is about deepening our awareness of this place so we can be a positive force in the world.

story:
Our Story

We are starting a non-profit company called GreenSpark EVs to convert gas-powered cars into electric vehicles (EVs). While we are waiting for our non-profit and tax-exampt status to be conferred, and while we start applying for grants, we will be doing a conversion to demonstrate that the company has the required knowledge and experience, and to provide technical and cost data on our conversions. We are trying to raise $5000 to $10,000 to help offset the cost of the initial conversions.

The GreenSpark EVs team (so far) is
Dr. Gerald Good - Idea guy, engineer, mechanic-in-training, "CEO"
Pete Kurtz - Chief mechanic, BMW guru, educator, owner/operator of Organic Mechanix (www.organic-mechanix.com)
Chris Luckett - Fundraising, networking and outreach, HR and benefits dude, mechanic-in-training
Will Hildebrandt - Fundraising and incorporation consultant, owner/operator of Hildebrandt Analytics (hildebrandtanalytics.com)

The Impact

Here is our mission statement:

- Recycle "clunkers" or non-working automobiles and convert them to environmentally-friendly Electric Vehicles.
- Make EVs available to individuals who can not afford the high price of currently produced gas-electric hybrid and all-electric vehicles.
- Reduce the amount of gasoline that needs to be purchased by lower income individuals, since gasoline price increases affect them more than those with higher incomes.
- Create rewarding and high-paying jobs for the St. Louis community.
- Provide internship opportunities for high school, trade school and college students.
- Raise awareness of alternatives to gasoline powered vehicles and ways to reduce emission of pollutants and greenhouse gases.


By contributing to our startup venture, you will be helping us get on the road to success! Without your help, we'll be stuck using Gerald's savings account and credit cards for funding.

What We Need & What You Get

We have purchased a 1986 BMW 528e for our initial conversion ($800). An EV conversion kit will cost about $7500 and batteries will cost about $2500. We are also renting shop space for $150/month. So our initial out-of-pocket cost to do the conversion will be about $11,000.


Here is what you will receive for contributing to our campaign:

For contributions of $1 - $29, you will receive a GreenSpark EVs bumper sticker.
For contributions of $30 - $99, you will receive a bumper sticker and a hand-printed GreenSpark EVs T-shirt.
For contributions of $100 - $499, you will receive a bumper sticker, T-shirt, and preferential placement on our list for future EV conversions.
For contributions of $500 - $5000, you will receive a bumper sticker, T-shirt, preferential placement for future EV conversion, and a credit towards a future EV conversion equal to the 110% of the amount of your contribution.


Other Ways You Can Help

- Spread the word about GreenSparkEVS: share this campaign site and our website, blog, Facebook and Twitter info with your friends.

- Contribute time and/or knowledge: some of our "donor" vehicles will need other repairs, if you're a gearhead then we can use your help!

- Contribute to help set up our shop; we can use shelving, lights, white boards, tools, and lots of other stuff.

- Come to the Gateway Electric Vehicle Association (GEVA) meetings to learn more about EVs and ongoing efforts in the St. Louis area. The GEVA meets on the second Sunday of each month at 2 PM at the Schlafly Tap Room, 2100 Locust Street in St. Louis.


Thanks from everyone on the GreenSpark EVs team!
story_txt:
Our StoryWe are starting a non-profit company called GreenSpark EVs to convert gas-powered cars into electric vehicles (EVs). While we are waiting for our non-profit and tax-exampt status to be conferred, and while we start applying for grants, we will be doing a conversion to demonstrate that the company has the required knowledge and experience, and to provide technical and cost data on our conversions. We are trying to raise $5000 to $10,000 to help offset the cost of the initial conversions.The GreenSpark EVs team (so far) isDr. Gerald Good - Idea guy, engineer, mechanic-in-training, "CEO"Pete Kurtz - Chief mechanic, BMW guru, educator, owner/operator of Organic Mechanix (www.organic-mechanix.com)Chris Luckett - Fundraising, networking and outreach, HR and benefits dude, mechanic-in-trainingWill Hildebrandt - Fundraising and incorporation consultant, owner/operator of Hildebrandt Analytics (hildebrandtanalytics.com) 

The Impact
Here is our mission statement:
- Recycle "clunkers" or non-working automobiles and convert them to environmentally-friendly Electric Vehicles.- Make EVs available to individuals who can not afford the high price of 
currently produced gas-electric hybrid and all-electric vehicles.- Reduce the amount of gasoline that needs to be purchased by lower income
 individuals, since gasoline price increases affect them more than those
 with higher incomes.- Create rewarding and high-paying jobs for the St. Louis community.- Provide internship opportunities for high school, trade school and college students.- Raise awareness of alternatives to gasoline powered vehicles and ways to reduce emission of pollutants and greenhouse gases.

By contributing to our startup venture, you will be helping us get on the road to success! Without your help, we'll be stuck using Gerald's savings account and credit cards for funding.

What We Need & What You Get
We have purchased a 1986 BMW 528e for our initial conversion ($800). An EV 
conversion kit will cost about $7500 and batteries will cost about 
$2500. We are also renting shop space for $150/month. So our initial out-of-pocket cost to do the conversion will be about $11,000.

Here is what you will receive for contributing to our campaign:
For contributions of $1 - $29, you will receive a GreenSpark EVs bumper sticker.For contributions of $30 - $99, you will receive a bumper sticker and a hand-printed GreenSpark EVs T-shirt.For contributions of $100 - $499, you will receive a bumper sticker, T-shirt, and preferential placement on our list for future EV conversions.For contributions of $500 - $5000, you will receive a bumper sticker, T-shirt, preferential placement for future EV conversion, and a credit towards a future EV conversion equal to the 110% of the amount of your contribution.


Other Ways You Can Help
- Spread the word about GreenSparkEVS: share this campaign site and our website, blog, Facebook and Twitter info with your friends.
- Contribute time and/or knowledge: some of our "donor" vehicles will need other repairs, if you're a gearhead then we can use your help!
- Contribute to help set up our shop; we can use shelving, lights, white boards, tools, and lots of other stuff.
- Come to the Gateway Electric Vehicle Association (GEVA) meetings to learn more about EVs and ongoing efforts in the St. Louis area. The GEVA meets on the second Sunday of each month at 2 PM at the Schlafly Tap Room, 2100 Locust Street in St. Louis.

Thanks from everyone on the GreenSpark EVs team!

story:
Meet TraX...

an Action Hero app that rewards you everywhere for your reusables!


TraX acknowledges your eco-action efforts by rewarding you 25¢ per action, up to $1 per day for bringing your reusables to your favorite retail stores. TraX offers you the flexibility to redeem for cash, retail gift cards, and donations to pay it forward. 

Many TraX users have been asking exactly how to tag and use our current rewards.  Watch this video and tag items to get rewards! 

YOU CAN GET 25¢ REWARDS NOW WITH TRAX SOCIAL CAMPAIGNS:

#TAGMYBAG to share reuse bag photos to Facebook with this tag and store name.

#TAGMYCUP to share reuse cup photos to Facebook with this tag and store name.

#TAGMYSTRAW share reuse straw photos to Instagram with this tag and store name. 

TraX is raising funds to develop a mobile app to THANK YOU everywhere you use reusables when you shop. Take actions that make a positive difference and get credit everywhere credit is due!

LATEST UPDATES:

We are excited to announce our latest rewards campaign with Simply Straws! They make durable glass reusable straws to help remove the more than 500 million single-use disposable straws used in the US each day, yikes!

In addition, to the live #TagMyBag campaign with ChicoBags, #TagMyCup with Clean Water Fund.  Simply Straws supports our mission to reduce single-use disposables (SUD) from ending up in our environment. 

Watch the "how-to" video here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_3JEQL-fge8 

TraX will comment on your Instagram photos, so you know we got them, please also send an email to hello@traxactions.com to receive your rewards.  At the end of each week we will send you a credit on Tango Card, redeemable for cash, retail gift cards or donations to pay it forward. 

So get out there Action Heroes... you are being called upon to bring your own reUSE straws, cups and bags everywhere you shop!

Please share this campaign with others in your networks & communities, thank you for all that you do every day. 

Onwards.

JULY 18th********TRAX WINS 1ST PLACE @PITCH CLUB SF***********

We are honored to announce that the #TraXapp has just received 1ST PLACE at the PitchClubSF competition in SF.  TraX competed against other great tech based startups.  

 @CitizenSpace in SF

Prize details:

TraX 1st Place - $25,000 in cloud services from @Softlayer, a team desk at @CitizenSpace in SF ($3,000 value), team desk at Fueled Collective in NYC ($2,000 value), and Grasshopper phone service ($300 value). Plus membership into the Softlayer Catalyst Startup program! 

We would like to thank all the sponsors! 

Our favorite audience feedback of the night was from an excited audience member who stated, "not only is it (TraX) a great business idea, but you are doing good with mobile... finally!" 

Please share this announcement to Twitter and your online communities.  

#TraXapp WON first prize @PitchClubSF for $25,000 from #Softlayer and #CitizenSpace. Support today at #IndieGoGo   igg.me/at/trax Join!

Onwards.

*******#TagMyCup reUSE Photo Rewards ******

We are excited to share that in addition, to our running #TagMyBag campaign with ChicoBags we are proud to announce our latest partnership with the community organization, Clean Water Fund.  CWF fully supports our mission to reduce single-use disposables (SUD) from ending up in our water sources.

You can now earn 25¢ per trip, rewards for simply using your cups at stores!

Here are the simple steps:

1. Bring your reUSE cup to any US store. 

2. After a beverage purchase, simply take a photo of your cup with your phone. 

3. Post it to Facebook, from your phone or computer. 

4. Locate the exact store name (needed step) with the FB app. 

5. Type in #tagmycup , so that we can track it!

It's that Easy!!!

Watch the video here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CS2mmrfLLKU 

 

******* #TAGMYBAG ~ ReUSE Photo Rewards *********

Watch the video here: http://youtu.be/FjlqCdt1AS4

TraX is proud to host a new real rewards campaign with our sponsor + partner ChicoBag!

Get real rewards TODAY by sharing photos of your reusable bags to Facebook. 

***Get 25¢ per store trip, up to $1 per day... that's $31 per month!***

 

Each week, participants will receive a digital Tango Card for your rewards credits to be redeemed as cash, retail gift card or donations. We will need your email address on Facebook to email the rewards to, or email us at hello@traxactions.com. 

∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆∆

Our Collective Problem:

So... let’s put this waste not in the trash, but in the past!

As you know, there are intense environmental problems like climate change, plastics in our oceans, methane gas release, and other real issues that are difficult to measure on a daily basis. However, retail consumer waste from single-use disposables (aka SUD) is very easy to see, feel and touch each day of our lives.

Did you know that on average each American uses 500 disposable cups and 500 disposable bags per year... that’s over 300 BILLION cups and bags per year!

The Massive Opportunity:

Bringing reUSE Bags and reUSE Cups to every store we shop at!

We have the opportunity to make a massive impact and eventually help make single use disposable usage obsolete from the shopping experience. We can remove this waste from the shopping within this decade, if we decide to take actions now. Our kids could grow up in a world knowing that we stopped this habit of SUD waste and rid our planet of this pollution system all together.

There are hundreds of thousands of cafes, markets, pharmacies, convenience, and retail stores for us to take action at. Millions already “check-in” to stores on mobile devices, share photos and their experiences.

Simply adding a positive action to that check-in, can make a real difference.

When we choose reusables, we are saving a disposable cup or plastic bag, and making a powerful consumer statement. We are also helping to save stores costs in shipping, inventory, waste management, and negative public image.

If you already bring reusables to the stores, great work... and now TraX can help you quantify how much you’re helping us all. Plus, we can now reward you with cash, gift cards or donations for something you already do.  Find out just how many SUDs you have saved from the trash. The is energy, waste, and natural resources you have saved, are now visualized. 

There are those of many of us that are NOT taking these simple daily actions and for good reason... value. Your phone, keys, wallet all have inherent value to you, so you remember them when you head out each day. We want to make your reusable cups, bags, and to-go containers just as valuable to you.

Our Solution:

So we did just that... meet TraX, the first mobile app to track and reward your reusables everywhere you shop, every day!

 

See real incentives are what move us, pain debilitates us. The recent bans, fees, and penalties keep us in line... but they do not inspire us into action, they force it. This issue is not only about a reusable cup, bag or container (although we do have some sweet perks for you), it’s about changing patterns, and our everyday habits, and that can be tough for all of us.

We believe that by offering you cash credits for your actions, we can grow this movement towards reusables and then onwards towards even greater actions. Reusables is just the beginnging for TraX!

By contributing to this campaign you are saying:

  • YES to reusables

  • YES to being acknowledged

  • YES to real action

  • YES to impact

  • YES to removing SUD waste
  • YES to up $1 per day for actions you already do!

It isn’t just about being green, it is about doing the right thing. The health of the planet, our kids and the future depends on us to do something positive today.

TraX is an on-the-go mobile app that tracks your actions for you and rewards you everywhere you already shop.  So, We are incentivizing you, not punishing you.  By rewarding you directly, giving credit everywhere credit is due TraX offers you a consistent experience at every store.

The TraX App: Features

The initial version of the TraX mobile app will be released with the following:

Welcome / Sign-in / Sign-up - this is the landing page for the app to create a new account or to enter TraX. Easily sign up with Facebook, Twitter or email... it’s that simple.

My Actions - TraX rewards you for reusables anytime that you offset SUD waste at stores when shopping. You self-track an action when using a qualifying reusable item. TraX partners then reward you for reusable bags, cups, to-go containers, bottles, garment bags, straws and cutlery sets. The app displays your in-store actions for you in real time.

My Stores- TraX connects to the Foursquare database to access all US stores to help you locate names while shopping. Locations are a crucial component of TraX. 

Reward Me- This page displays your current rewards credit balance accrued on a digital Tango Card. Each action is valued at 25¢ and you will see the balance increase by that amount for each TraX action you perform. Now you can redeem for cash*, retail gift card* or donations to non-profit partners. You can immediately start redeeming rewards after your first action.

*Redemption fees - There is an 8% processing fee taken out for cash and donations in order to mail checks. For example, if you have $10 to redeem as cash, you will personally receive a check for $9.20, minus this processing fee.

Thank You's - Links to the store/company/brand that provided your 25¢ credit. Optional further information and contact details about the partner company is provided here also.  

Share It - This page is about sharing your good deeds, viewing your impact and the rewards you are accruing by using TraX. This share page represents our early campaigns that you can start NOW.

Real Rewards- We offer you the chance to take a photo of your reusable, tag it with the TraX hashtags (#TraXcup, TraXbag, etc.), share your store location and post it to your favorite social sites (Facebook, Twitter, Instagram). This will help spread the word and let our partners know how active you are. 

Meet Team TraX 

Jared & Heidi enjoying Philz Coffee, SF

Jared Brick: Founder + Director

Jared has been contemplating related questions since he was a teen in NJ. He grew up with a wonderful father, who happened to design and manufacture retail consumer packaging as a living. Now as a father himself, he wants to show his son that he did something, he took a stand, Jared got creative and re-imagined our world. He choice to be part of the solution, not the growing pollution. In 2010, as his son was being born he began an MBA in Sustainable Management from the Presidio Graduate School. Jared seeks to harness the powers of business as a mechnism for change. He is an avid eco-entrepreneur, bold strategist, innovative marketer and inspiring speaker. As his second child is soon to arrive at the end of the campaign, the urgency to action this needed ventiure grows greater day by day.

Heidi Smith: Co-founder + CTO

Heidi recently joined TraX to manage the technology components of TraX. In her role as CTO, Heidi brings over 13 years of technical and managerial experience for Software as a Service (SaaS) applications in the energy, environmental, financial services, and e-commerce industries. As a strong proponent of software solutions to combat climate change, she worked for 6 years first as a senior developer, then CTO at Carbonflow, which develops a software solution to assist organizations to manage their carbon credit projects.  She is passionate about Trax because every change to our daily routine makes us think more seriously about how we interact with the planet.  Encouraging change through technology combines two of her passions and she is excited to take TraX to the next level to reduce waste.  Heidi graduated Summa Cum Laude from Vanderbilt University with degrees in Mathematics and German.

Fred Schechter: Campaign Manager

Is an experienced and passionate crowdfunding advisor. He’s an industrial designer, UX designer, product manager, father, a mediocre race cardriver and father.  He is excited to be working for a company whose mission is grand and can impact society.

Saba Mohammad: Social Media

Saba feels strongly about the mission and vision of TraX and is excited to share it with the world.

Jenny Sant'Anna: Sustainability Coordinator

Jenny was an MPA classmate of Jared's at Presidio and started Bag the Bag to engage with stakeholders around regional plastic bag bans in the US.  She brings her passion for reusables and connections at the city level to assist TraX. 

Advisory

Catalyst Startup Program: with Josh Krammes

Since TraX won the SF Pitch Club sponsored by SoftLayer, we now have full mentorship and advisory from one of the top companies in cloud hosting.  Josh will be assisting us in crafting our investor documents, pitching, strategy and connections to new clients.  

FAQ Section:

So...who pays for my 25¢ rewards?

The short answers is... it depends on where you track your reusavle. TraX plans to partner with large retail chain stores, small local stores, eco-product companies, and other sustainable organizations.  Depending on your action location, an appropriate partner will reward you when you use the app. For example, if you use a reusable shopping bag at a small retail store, that we have not partnered with yet, an eco-product partner will credit you.  If you use a reusable cup at a cafe chain we have partnered with, you will see a direct reward from that same company.  

Can I get rewarded for my actions NOW?

YES...we are very proud of our founding partners, aligned brands, committed companies, and high integrity organizations to support your current actions.

  • ChicoBags - The best reusable and packable bags on the planet.
  • Simply Straws - Strongest and easiest reusable glass straws.
  • Clean Water Fund  - Encourages reusables for cleaner waterways.
  • Tango Card -Our digital rewards partner for gift cards, cash, and donations

During this campaign, we have launched new rewards with each partner company to PAY you for reusables before our app even launches!

This means the TraX rewards program is LIVE now and works! We are using Facebook mobile apps to allow you to share your reusables photos from retail stores and get 25¢ per action, earning up to $1 per day! We will let you know more about which companies are sponsoring rewards so get excited to share! This will be the rewards process until the apps launch for iOS and Android platforms.

Who else will TraX be partnering with?

TraX is forming the first ever retail store alliances that seeks to actively reduce retail disposables, while rewarding consumers.  

We are already signing up large and small retail stores to the app platform, pre-release.  Stores can choose how to best reward you for bringing reusables used in their stores or simply reward the entire users base... it’s up to them in the end. New partners can fund the rewards and easily become a part of our system. If you know of any companies that we should talk to, or have introductions for us, please contact us! For large corporate partners please contact us directly at partners@traxactions.com.  

Below is a list of the types of example partners (from local to international) we are reaching out to for TraX. If you are a potential partner or know someone who could connect us we’d love to hear from you at partners@traxactions.com

  • Cafes -  Starbucks, Peet’s Coffee & Tea, Seattle’s Best, etc.

  • Grocery - Whole Foods, Safeways, Lucky’s, Raley’s, Shopright, etc.

  • Pharmacy - CVS, Walgreen’s, Longs Drug, Wall Drug, Walmart, etc.

  • Convenience - 7-Eleven, Circle K, Gas stations, etc.

  • Retail - Walmart, Target, Ebay, Gap, Old Navy, Costco, Macy’s, etc.

  • Donation Organizations - Sierra Club, National Parks Service, etc. 

How can I get my favorite local store onto TraX?

The best way to do this is to track your actions at your current stores, to help us to identify them.  Once we recognize the store as a new location, we will contact them and let them know TraX Action Heroes (aka YOU) are shopping at their stores.  Or if you would like us to reach out to them, please let us know via email!

Send us a message to: partners@traxactions.com

How exactly do stores pay TraX to become a partner?

Our large retail store partners pay a monthly subscription fee based their level of engagement on the platform.

Local small retail store partners pay low monthly usage fees or per action fees based on realtime usage to control for tighter budgets.

Eco-product and sustainable companies pay a per campaign fee to advertise new products/services to you, and provide in-app education tools for you. Who better to thank you, than your already favorite stores, reusable products and great donor organizations.

What are Tango Card credits?

Tango Cards are the most flexible way to reward you for your daily actions on TraX. They are a great rewards company that redeems cash, retail gift cards, and even donation options. TraX wants you to have the most flexibility for your rewards possible.  You can incorporate or even add other unused retail gift cards to add more rewards credits as you see fit.  It is the ultimate way to manage control your reward credits.  

Learn more about them here: https://www.tangocard.com/what-is

How does TraX control for fraud or per day action limits?

Often we get asked about how we will protect the authenticity of these actions since we are giving you a real financial reward. So we have designed in some safeguards to ensure that your actions are credible and real. Rest assured fraudulent users will be removed and blocked from using TraX.

Since, we reward you 25¢ per action with 4 redeemable actions it is limited to $1 per day. In most normal scenarios, we do not shop at more than 4 stores in any given day... so these limits seem realistic. The most rewards an individual user can earn in one month is $31.

Necessary steps to redeem rewards:

For each action each user must locate a real store that a reusable was used in. Foursquare will be used, just like your experience on Instagram or Facebook to validate each store name and address. 

Can I share my actions to social media?

Sharing your actions, while not required is encouraged on our platform. For this effort to grow we need to tell others (friends, family, colleagues) about TraX and the benefits of using it. We also feel that by sharing user actions, this will discourage not encourage fraudulent misuse of our the rewards program.

What actions does TraX NOT reward for?

These actions are NOT rewarded:

  • Home, personal, or office usage of reusables (unless at a company cafe or cafeteria with a $ purchase). Each action must be related to a purchase.

  • Multiple reusables per trip. If you are re-filing 3 reusable cups for co-workers at Starbucks, you may only be rewarded for one action at a time. If your friends and colleagues have the TraX app, they can get rewards based on your helpful actions.

  • When declining disposable items, as it isn’t the same as bringing a reusable item. We currently do not track this action and thus it currently is not rewarded.

  • Recycling, composting, biking/walking/carpooling to work, and other wonderfully helpful actions.  We can not reward you for these actions, since there are often no purchase based aroud it. We can recommend some other wonderful apps, simply email us for more help. 

What’s the $50k needed for?

We have created the wireframes and prototypes of the mobile app and now it is time to develop it, to get it into your hands.  Experience matters, so we are leaning on the talents of a great local firm in SF, for the first versions of TraX. You’ll be glad to know that we will develop for the Android and Apple iOS platforms simultaneously!

If you have more questions regarding TraX and our fundraising needs, please add your comments here or email us: hello@traxactions.com

PERKS + PARTNERS

We have partnered with amazing reusable product companies for this campaign. View all the perks on the right side to learn more. 

Since we are a service company about actions, we seek to minimize the need for various physical items, extensive shipping, wasteful packaging and other related pollution. Please reuse, recycle or compost all packaging from these perks. 

Stay tuned for new partners, photo-sharing rewards and much more as we release updates for the campaign!

THANK YOU!

TraX is all about you... what you do on a daily basis makes a great difference to us all.  We decided to crowdfund TraX for this reason and welcome you to join us. 

Thank you for all that you do everyday. We are grateful for your contributions and excited to see what you save!

Action heroes are people that are willing to stand up and take action for what they believe to be right... Please Join Us!

SEEKING ACTION HEROES
